The only thing I will have to say though is I hope they cut down the sugar content of their ice cream as it was way too sweet after the first few bites.  For me, if they tone down the sweetness some, I would be tempted to visit again sooner.  I might go and try some other flavors. Next time I will ask if anything is not as sweet.
author: Andrew N.

description:
Oolong Tea ice cream at Humphry Slocombe is my top 3 ice cream ever!! 
I love ice cream and I'm pretty picky about it...it can't be too sweet...hehe I know, it's ice cream so it should be sweet but...have to be the right amount of sweetness.
I've never had oolong tea ice cream in general before my first visit at Humphry Slocombe. And it was mind blown. If you've never tried it, just ask the ice cream scooper to try a sample---they are always nice!
Oolong tea ice cream is my perfect ice cream because of it's...
-Yummy flavor --- Not too sweet, has a slight slight bitterness from tea flavor. But not as strong as coffee. That balance is perfect for me.
-Dreamy creaminess --- If I want something not too sweet, why don't I eat fruit sorbet...unfortunately, it's not that easy!! I still want ICE CREAM, not sorbet. Imagine, oolong tea married to rich milk and their lovely baby is this ice cream!
All the ice cream lovers who enjoy and value the flavor of ice cream, it's worth trying!!! It's boooooomb!!
author: Fumie N.

description: Had the Blue Coffee Vietnamese coffee icecream today.  Had to be one of the better coffee ice creams that I have have.  The Brown Butter was really good too.  The Thai Chili Lime Sorbet, not so much.
author: Bob F.

description:
I love my Bi-Rite when it comes to ice cream joints in the Mission, but last weekend when we were out here, our friends took us to Humphry Slocombe to give it a shot. In the middle of Sunday afternoon, there was no line and no trouble getting seats at the tables outside the store, which made it nice for us to just sit in the alternating patches of shade and sun to enjoy the ice cream. If you're looking to come here and get your standard sundae or flavors, you're in for a sore surprise - they really do specialize in all sorts of interesting and funky flavors.

My fiancee and I shared a two-scoop version with Black Sesame and and Harvey Milk & Honey, both of which were extremely delicious. I've had sesame-infused deserts before, but the one thing I liked about the ice cream here is that they maintained the sweetness from the dairy aspect of the ice cream without letting it get overwhelmed by the more savory aspect of the sesame. The milk and honey was also delicious, mainly because it was quite a bit sweeter than I expected - the heavy-handed sweetness of the honey was mellowed down significantly by the milk.

There are several other flavors I'd love to come back and try, but alas - I don't live in SF, and getting to the Mission when you're an out-of-towner ain't that simple. But the flavors here are unique yet tasty, and prices are pretty reasonable as well. Definitely worth a visit, particularly if you're not hankering to stand in line at Bi-Rite for a while.
author: Asuka N.

description:
so i had some free credit on caviar (yay referrals) so i used it to try a new place without leaving the house. ordered a pint of Vietnamese coffee and secret breakfast - they were kinda amazing! we tried equal amounts of both initially, but went back for more secret breakfast.  

only thing is it's kinda expensive, paid $11/pint. but i get that it was real quality stuff, and it was very much a treat - something i would (try) not to get on a regular basis. also it seems that not all of their ice creams are available for delivery, and/or not all are available as a pint - i'm not sure, but the caviar menu was pretty limited to what i found on their website. would love to have more crazy flavors delivered the next time when laziness and my sweet tooth collide.
author: Antoinnae C.

description: The iced cream is fab at this popular bougie establishment. But the Mexican hot chocolate is nothing more than spicy chocolate water. The fancy marshmallows do not replace milk. It's not even piping hot.
author: Trent P.

description:
Great ice cream in the Mission. There was absolutely no wait when we came.  We ordered the secret breakfast which is ice cream infused with bourbon (yes! bourbon!) and little cornflake clusters.  The bourbon was a little too strong for me, but paired well with the Vietnamese Iced Coffee ice cream.

My favorite was the olive oil ice cream.  I loved the subtle flavor and the lemon zest made it taste so fresh.
author: Hieu H.

description:
Ice Cream is bliss in a cup and Humphry Slocombe takes that joy to a whole new level.  This is some of the best ice cream I've had outside of the gelaterias of Italy.

A note of caution, this is not for everyone.  Their signature flavor is Secret Breakfast which is bourbon ice cream with cornflakes.  You're not going to come here and find Moose Tracks, mint chocolate chip or french vanilla.  Most of the negative reviews of this place I've seen are because people didn't like the strong, unique flavors.  I didn't like all the flavors they served, but that doesn't mean it deserves a negative review.  I wasn't a fan of the peanut butter curry.  It doesn't mean that it deserves one star.  I don't want even the best peanut butter curry ice cream.

For some reason when I was there it wasn't busy so I got to try a lot of the flavors.  I didn't like the peanut butter curry, olive oil or Jesus Juice.  I loved the Secret Breakfast, Vietnam coffee and some caramel one.  

I ordered a dish of the Secret Breakfast and loved it more and more with every bite.  It was so interesting.  It haunted me for days.  In some ways I didn't like it.  It wasn't the super sweet, pure cream, ice cream that I'm used to.  It was almost savory and sweet at the same time.  The more I ate though the more it warmed and cooled me at the same time. 

The shop is tiny and the people are nice.  They use tiny metal spoons for the testing, which you put in a jar for them to wash.  It was nice that they didn't throw away 10,000 plastic spoons a day.  They also use biodegradable dishes I believe.

Go to the website and look at the list, then pray the flavors you want will be there out of the 8-12 in the case.
author: Ryan L.

description:
A funny thing happened during my visit to Humphry Slocombe: I couldn't decide which ice cream to choose. Not because I loved all of their unique and creative creations; quite the opposite in fact. After sampling roughly six or seven different flavors, and seriously testing the patience of the guy behind the counter, there was not a single flavor that appealed to me enough to want a whole scoop of.

That is, until I tried my eight flavor -- Secret Breakfast. What is this enigmatic ice cream you ask? It's bourbon and corn flakes. Sure, it's not for everyone, but as a fan of bourbon (and cereal) I was in hooch heaven. And having it in ice cream was like killing two delicious birds with one stone (or scoop). The only problem was that the ice cream was really soft, either because the alcohol did not fully freeze up or because the freezer case was too warm.

So how do I rate a place that has seven strikes but one home run? As much as I loved the Secret Breakfast, based upon the other flavors, I really can't give this place more than 3 stars.
author: Paul L.

description: As my friend and I walked in, we were immediately greeted and asked to try any samples we wanted! As much as I loved his kindness, he did get my order wrong. Is been awhile since I've gotten Humphrey's so I did not notice. Despite the one flavor incorrect, nothing ever goes wrong having Humphrey's ice cream! Definitely need to get the blue bottle Vietnamese coffee!
author: Erica Vanna C.

description: What a fun little place. Walking through the mission for a whole in a wall was definitely worth it. They have very good flavors of ice cream that can be seasonal and very very exotic like their secret breakfast with bourbon and cornflakes or vietnamese coffee using blue bottled coffee. They give nice portions and are nice. Although i know this place is very famous and has been for a while something was missing to me compared to other ice cream parlors I've been too. Unfortunately this place can't make me wait 30 min patiently and drive all the way out here for their ice cream. I've enjoyed my experience here. And would come back when I'm in the city but other than that I do very much appreciate their flavors and how exciting it is to see combinations such as strawberry and pepper comes to play.
author: Leme K.

description:
I happily dug into the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee and Peanut Butter Chocolate.

Creaminess. 4 stars. Even and thick texture. Check!

Flavor. 5 stars. Both scoops captured the intense taste, smell, and experience of the coffee and the peanut butter. I must say, I've never had bolder flavored ice cream before.

Density. 2.5 stars. Creamy yes, but these scoops of ice cream melted much too quickly, even so on a drizzly, cloudy day. Perhaps more ice is the solution to this temperature problem. I was bothered by the liquifying ice cream and found that the only thing to somewhat remedy the issue (not really) was to finish these babies as quickly as possible.

Enjoyment. 3 stars. Unfortunately the fluid-like consistency of the ice cream put a damper on my rating. The bold flavors of coffee and peanut butter became a bit overbearing after the first 5 bites and I didn't enjoy the ice cream as much towards the end of the experience as I did at the beginning.
author: Cici T.

description:
great place, sf is soo gifted with so many great ice cream places that just make mitchells seem like no big deal even tho theres so long of lines.

HUmphry is one of my faves. I don't come as often as I'd like too. 

This place is very comfortable and the ice cream is soo rich and smooth tasting.
I love the texture. 

great prices and such amazing random flavors that are soo excellent tasting .

THis is the first time I've experienced that bacon ice cream is really good. 

Thats nothing tho compared to Ancho chile ice cream . ha sounds weird but it is sooo good. 

My favorite is secret breakfast , maple walnut, and carrot Mango . 

They have all kinds of interesting flavors like beet, cheese, mmm chocolate smoked sea salt,  oh oh and cinnamon brittle. 

OH man I used come here regularly when I volunteered at the sf spca. 
I miss it cuz now I just come once in awhile.  

Spread the word that this place is amazing, bring your friends, keep these mom and pop spots alive.
author: Luke S.

description: Still still love this place and the nice blonde man at the counter said "how are you?" and really meant it, not everyone in sf actually cares when they ask that so, honestly, that was a nice touch. I had the wicked matcha green tea flavor and holy cow it was amazing.
author: Kendra S.

description:
For the Guinness gingerbread, I could not taste any Guinness at all:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/humphry-slocombe-ice-cream-san-francisco?select=j_urlg_52AV0Lhun3P6_gA#j_urlg_52AV0Lhun3P6_gA
But the gingerbread part was great, with very good chunks of gingerbread cookie mixed in.  But for a Guinness-centric confection, I instead recommend either the Shakin' Jesse at Rudy's Can't Fail Cafe, or the Dublin Honey Float at Ice Cream Bar.

The "Fluffer Nutter" is loaded with way too much salt.

The Tahitian Vanilla ice cream is by far the best ice cream for an affogato.
author: Scott F.

description:
this is probably my 2nd favorite ice cream joint in the city.  1st being BI-RITE =)

anyhow, i came here on a wednesday afternoon.  no line!  i was the only customer.  i didnt feel the rush, so i sampled each and every flavor they had.  they were all pretty interesting.  i opted for the vietnamese coffee.  it really tasted like vietnamese coffee!  but it was ICE CREAM!  so that was even better!  

just keep in mind that they change their flavors daily.
author: mong linh n.

description:
harvey milk and cookies ice cream is delicious and tasty! i love the combination of sweet, creamy and chunks of cookies thrown in. Its a genius flavor. it tastes exactly like milk dunked with sweet cookies. i am in love with this flavor.

secret breakfast, it was ok to me. everyone raves about it but it didn't really float my boat. i felt like the taste of bourbon overpowered the flavor of ice cream. i thought it would have been more subtle and tasted more like pancakes or some sweet breakfast foods. 

definitely would come back to try other flavors. =)
author: Stella J.

description:
Red hot banana ice cream, how I love thee. 

I sampled Secret Breakfast and some others but red hot banana made me go "WOW" after first taste. Banana ice cream is a rarity, especially done right. Humphry's does it right-- creamy and full of banana flavor with small pieces of red hot candies. This is the perfect combination.
author: Michelle M.

description:
I'm unsure of what the hype is all about. I was at HS yesterday with a group of friends and don't think any of us were excited about the experience.

I tried several flavors and service was fantastic, but there's a lot to be desired in terms of the flavor and texture of the ice cream. NOT ALL ICE CREAM IS CREATED EQUAL! For an ice cream fanatic, I think I have tried all of the most popular places in the city + some in Oakland + I've made ice cream. Some would say that I'm ice cream obsessed.

I got the Blue Bottle Coffee flavor. The flavor notes were on point, they were delicious, creamy, and had a strong coffee kick. What I disliked was the fatty, filmy texture left on the roof of my mouth after 1/4 of my scoop was eaten. It's so hard for me to waste food let alone ice cream, but this was one of the few exceptions that I deemed necessary. Maybe I would've been better off with sorbet?

I also got a cup of water at this location, and the water tasted like old San Francisco pipes aka it tasted like copper/metal.

If you're all about service, I would highly recommend this place. If you're all about flavor... look elsewhere.
author: Christina L.

description:
As a professional Hungry Girl, I am inherently suspicious of people who don't know enough to appreciate the elegant appeal of artisan ice cream.  

I was fortunate enough to grow up in a home surrounded by fruit trees, vegetable gardens... filled with the smells of baking and cooking.  This is one of the reasons I chose to live in the Bay Area - for the Food Culture - and perhaps, as a subset, the Cult of Food.

We baked seasonal pies by the dozen, peeling, coring and slicing bushels of apples in the Fall, often having warm-from-the-oven pie with milk and sharp cheddar cheese for dinner.  Summer meant doing battle with the Japanese fruit beetles, racing to pick nectarines that grew heavy in our tree: jam, pies, and cobblers cooled on every kitchen surface.

The towering lemon tree meant sugar-slicked smiles and dueling lemonade stands operated by rival teams of siblings.   Just typing this memory conjures the grinding whiirrrrrr of the old ice cream maker, the perfume of sun-warmed strawberries, the crunch of rock salt and chipped ice.

I have my upbringing to thank for my infatuation and great weakness for frozen dairy treats.  It is also to blame for my inability to appreciate most commercially available product because it simply isn't "rich enough".  It just depresses me to look at the packaging and see "Low Fat" or "Reduced Fat"  - to me, it may as well read: REDUCED PLEASURE.

These days, I'd much rather have a single dip of an ethereal ice cream (sorbet or gelato) from a lovingly edited collection; I turn my nose up at encyclopedic flavors and toppings.  I scream for ice cream boutiques!

After an insufferably dismal "meal" at a pretentious vegan place, I practically skipped several blocks and burst through the door, rosy-cheeked and breathless with anticipation.  The shop is warm and cozy, the decor is simple and bright.  

My eyes searched for the Boccalone Lard Caramels, which I discovered at the Ferry Building several years ago.  It is my habit to purchase whatever quantity is in the glass jar, to smile winningly as I ask for ALL of them to be added to my order. The marriage of sugar, salt and fat is luxurious.  It's an olfactory jackpot.  

The first time I sampled this otherworldly confection, my knees trembled so violently, I had to sit down.  My eyes glazed over.  All my senses were mesmerized by the symphony of sweet and savory; the delicate wrapper glistened with body-temperature porcine unctuousness.  I dabbed it behind my ears.  

Boccalone #Cinque - the ultimate in seductive scents.

No Lard Caramels in sight... But behold:  Bacon Brittle.  Yes, please!

I oohed and aahed and Mmmm'd, tasting my way through half of the selections.  There were a few that I almost skipped because I had to remind myself that theirs is not an ordinary vanilla.  It's the most un-vanilla (wink) vanilla you've tasted.  Like, your eyes roll back in your head and an audible moan escapes from somewhere deep in your being kind of goooooooood.

The Black Sesame was technicolor vivid, tap dancing across my tastebuds: rich, toasted, nutty, creamy, sweet.  It was big, and I liked it.  I chose Brown Butter + haus made brittle to keep it company in my compostable cup.  Imagine my  delight when the sugar cone I'd struck from my order was placed atop one of the scoops.  So my ice cream was wearing a hat, too!

The Amigo let me taste his Sundae: chocolate & vanilla sprinkled with sea salt and anointed with a generous dollop of heavy cream, WHIPPED, FOR HER PLEASURE, densely dairy and hardly sweetened.  Oh, yeah, baby - you know just how I like it!

I wanted to go slow, slow, slow and take my time.  I wanted to savor every spoonful of sweet, creamy, buttery, salty, nutty, cold deliciousness that danced on my tongue.  Alas, 9:00pm came too quickly, as did the bottom of my cup. 

It was a Cinderella moment, to be certain.  One more wistful glance into the freezer case, just a few more hungry gazes over the empty counter top... The once-attentive staff turning quickly, efficiently into mice, scurrying to close up shop, cleaning and tidying.  The clock began to chime: one last look, as I turned and stepped out into the street -

There I stood, for a brief moment in the darkness.  The whirrrrrrrr a phantom whisper in my mind, the fragrance of sugar and cream clinging to my hair,  a sticky smile upon my cream-kissed lips.  

Life is so very sweet.
author: Kim D.

description: This ice -cream  place has very interesting and unique flavors! I ordered their famous secret breakfast and coffee! Their coffee was my favorite. The secret breakfast can be described as corn flakes with a hint of bourbon. You can taste the liquor, which tricks you into thinking you're drinking lol. I topped it off with some almond crunch, with I really recommend. It adds a nice crunch!
author: Vy T.

description:
Interesting flavors but weird texture. 

I did an ice-cream crawl with some friends and this was one of our stops. We tried the carrot mango and salt & pepper ice-cream. Cool concepts in theory, not so great in execution. 

The carrot was too sweet and needed more mango tartness to balance it out. The salt and pepper was a little too salty. I was expecting a sea salt-chocolate kind of flavor combo, but it was more like salty ice-cream with a few grains of sugar. Not exactly what I'd call refreshing. The carrot mango was supposed to be a sorbet, but the texture was a little too creamy and elastic-y (if that makes sense). 

We weren't fans of either. :/
author: Josephine L.

description:
Secret Breakfast is like taking a shot of Jack Daniels followed by a shot of vanilla followed by a spoonful of corn flakes. If only it had actual alcohol to it, then it'd be probably the best thing ever. Can you imagine taking shots of ice cream to get drunk? Wait does that exist?  Can someone get on this idea? Like, soon please? Serious business here folks. 

Anyways, ignoring all previous alcoholic tendencies, I would love to come back to this place. There were so many more flavors that I wanted to try out, and I want to try them all. I shall be back!
author: Sean H.

description:
Decided to stop by Humphry Slocumbe again to check out what flavors they had.

I tried two flavors I never had before and they both gave me a wake up call.  Jesus Juice (Red Wine and Coke) and Thai Chili Lime sorbet.  Jesus Juice was pretty good, it made me want to try making some at home of the non frozen variety.  I don't think my mouth was ready for the Thai Chili Lime.  Unlike the Peanut Butter Curry, it made me jolt and was pretty strong.  I might give it another try though some other time as I decided to skip the ice cream that day and try their Bourbon Coke Float.

So how can you make their famed Secret Breakfast even more indulgent?  Take two scoops of it and add some Coke and you have their Bourbon Coke Float ($5).  Here's a pic of it (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw&select=RKn1ulqHGt11-NTYmt_Eng). That was good in a crazy way!  I thought it was strange having a Coke with Corn Flakes and a hint of Bourbon (which was pretty strong by the way), but the whole thing worked for me.

Sadly once again, the famous (or infamous) Prosciutto Ice Cream wasn't available that day. *Sad Face*  It'll have to be another time for me.  Still another 5 Star Experience for me!
author: Rodney H.

description: The Secret Breakfast is obviously a winner since it's been on the menu from day one. To my palette, it tastes similar to butter pecan flavored ice cream, but it is even more sinfully delicious knowing there's bourbon in there. I paired it with Wicked, which is probably a seasonal flavor while the musical is in town. Green tea ice cream with black and white cookie pieces... I mean... the textures are phenomenal.
author: Vinney L.

description:
tldr:: Interesting flavors. A bit on the pricey side for a scoop of ice-cream. 

I came here on a Wednesday afternoon around 4 pm because it was hot AF here in SF. I have been meaning to try out Humphry Slocombe for a while now because I have heard good things about this place.

Ambiance/ Appearance:
It is a small little shop with some seating in and outside. It's very cute and simple. 

Service:
The girl working there was really nice; when it was our turn, she promptly offered us samples and what not. 

Taste: 
I sampled the Secret Breakfast and wasn't a big fan of it. I don't really like the taste of alcohol, and I can sense even the slightest amount of it in my food, so this was not for me. But, if you don't mind it, I'm sure it would be delicious. I also sampled and got the Strawberry Crumble. I liked that there were bits of graham crackers? in it that gave it some texture and crunch. I thought that the ice-cream was too sweet and it melted REALLY quickly. Usually, you have a good few minutes before things start dripping, but mine melted right away. It might of been the weather, but my friends' didn't melt as quickly as mine. The cone was really good, one of the best I have ever tasted. Also, the scoop she gave me was nicely sized, but it was so lopsided, which could have also contributed to how fast it melted. I tasted my friends' Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee, and it was pretty good; it was nice and creamy. 

A single scoop w/ a cone costed $4. For ice-cream I think it is a little bit on the pricey side. I don't think I would be returning just because there are so many other places to try out in the city.
author: Vivian Y.

description: I may be partial to Humphry Slocombe because of the two-headed calf on the wall, but I really do love their ice cream. The brown butter is remarkable, in the brown buttery sort of way. It's a perfect foil for the frosted almond topping. The smoked salt chocolate is great, too--I like it with the Amarena cherries (they're sweet and chewy and perfect with a not-so-sweet ice cream). The staff members are usually very patient if you want to sample the assortment of unusual flavors. Whatever you order, you can't go wrong.
author: Dara M.

description:
3.5

Service is great, ice cream has great texture, but honeslty, I don't know whats so special about the flavors.  The Vietnamese Coffee tasted like regular coffee ice cream.  I'm a little disappointed but my opnion probably shouldn't matter since I'm not an ice cream fan anyway.
author: Linda N.

description:
Well we all know i came here for the secret breakfast. And it lived up to everything i had imagined it would be. Creamy bourbon-y goodness and crunchy cereal clusters. Who could ask for anything more. But of course, before i decided on the other two flavors i chose, i sampled to my hearts content, and the employees didn't give me funny looks, they wanted me to try everything. Just when you don't think it can get any better you notice that their choice of music is awesome, and adds to your eating experience. 

Don't forget to pause and sing along, i know you remember the lyrics.
author: Doris S.

description:
Salt and Pepper, Jesus Juice, Secret Breakfast. They don't sound like your average ice cream flavors but they are here at HS and with their rotating menu of flavors I NEED to come back and experience all their flavors. (Great news to my taste buds...not so great to my waistline!) With that said I'm slightly obsessed with their Secret Breakfast - one of their signature flavors of bourbon, caramel with chunks of cornflakes. 

So which SF ice creamery is my favorite? It's hard to say. In a city full of great artisan ice cream I know many have been perplexed and conflicted with this same question.
author: Esther A.

description:
Secret breakfast and the black sesame are the BEST. Vietnamese coffee was okay. Long line, relatively short wait. Staff was frendly and funny when they put out condoms for "Happy Father's Day". 

Also someone project shat all over the single bathroom they had-- no idea who did it but I feel bad for the staff who had the clean that shit up (pun intended). Welcome to the Mission? They put a sign up today on the bathroom that said "closed due to terrible poop aim". At least they have a sense of humor about it.
author: Stef S.

description: This place is kind of in the middle of nowhere - but it's definitely worth the visit! The honey and graham cracker flavor is AMAZING and even has chunks of softened graham cracker in it. And the black sesame is so unique and delicious!
author: Ally M.

description:
Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee. Hands down one of the best flavors of ice cream I've ever tasted alongside the Salted Caramel at Bi-rite. 

It's a hard choice to choose between Humphrys and Bi-rite that are within a mile of each other SO, I did what any foodie would do and went to both! I liked Humphrys because I felt like their flavors are so creative--Secret Breakfast (Bourbon and cereal), Buttah Beer (made with stout beer), Black Sesame and so many more fancy flavors! They were all delicious but, the Vietnamese Coffee was a definite favorite and Black Sesame being my second favorite. 

Unlike Bi-rite which, is extremely sweet, I felt that Humphrys ice cream choices were salty..but, in a good way. Salted just right to bring out all the great flavors which, actually made me want more. Although, I love Bi-Rite (and it is still my favorite), I could only ever have about a scoop of it because it's richness was a bit overwhelming. I also really liked that you could see specks of black sesame and coffee beans in my ice cream.

Definitely worth a try if you're in the area.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Not to be missed! On my way to Humphry Slocombe, I was cautioned against the secret breakfast ice cream (because "It's really not that great...") -- but, no -- it IS. Bourbon and cornflakes may sound like an odd combination (much like bacon, prosciutto or tarragon -- all among their other flavors), but it's wonderful. The bourbon isn't overpowering, or overly sweet, and the combo is just delicious. I also had toast & jam, which was incredible. It actually tasted of jam, melted butter and toast crumbs -- which is perhaps not what you might have considered as a dream ice cream flavor, yet somehow, it really works. 

I couldn't bring myself to try Jesus Juice (red wine and coca cola), but I wanted to. 

I will definitely be back!
author: Katie M.

description: i still like bi rite better even though this place has a lot of unique flavors. I got secret breakfast but it wasn't anything special. It did taste a lot like bourbon though. I also got the Vietnamese coffee but wasn't too impressed.
author: Andy H.

description:
Another great ice cream place in SF.  Unique flavors and very creamy!  They rotate flavors, so there are different flavors each week. 

My favorite flavor is the Secret Breakfast (Bourbon and cereal!)  My friend said the salt&pepper, and the olive oil flavors were good, but they didnt' have it there when I went :(
I sampled the Peanut Butter Curry (whaaaaat?), and to me, it tasted mostly like peanut butter.  The Vietnamese Coffee is really strong for those of you who are into that.

Workers here are very friendly and helpful :)
author: Cathy T.

description: Tried the blue bottle Vietnamese coffee flavor and it does indeed live up to the hype!  The other flavor I tried was the hot banana one. I wasn't too fond of that one, but overall, Humphry Slocombe has some interesting ice cream flavors. I would give 4 stars, but the worker who was helping me out seemed to despise his job, and he wasn't very friendly. My favorite ice cream will always be at bi-rite! They're friendly 100% of the time!
author: Corinna T.

description:
Once again, had a taste bud blowing time as I savored my Secret Breakfast on top of my Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee.  A somewhat conventional combination, but it is like ice cream crack for me... timed it perfect, any later and we would have been stuck at the end of a line that was way out the door.  People were double parking on Harrison and running in... parking was a B-word that afternoon and I was lucky to get a spot 2 blocks away.

Also, tried the White Chocolate Lavender, which was fantastic, of course!  Very powerful lavender - not for the meek.  One of these days I will have to try the Jesus Juice Sorbet.

On a side note... everyone working was very cool and patient - good customer service is still important, even when a business is doing well - and this group did great that day.
author: Scott P.

description:
2 words: SECRET BREAKFAST. 

Who knew burboun and cornflakes would make such a winning combo? Humphry Slocombe, that's who. It's my favorite flavor here.

Other awesome flavors include the sweet summer corn (yup, corn), and browned butter (for all the butter aficionados out there). Savory ice-cream goodness.

Next time I want to try their calimocho flavored sorbet (coke and redwine). I think they call it  "Jesus Juice."
author: Evonne L.

description: I was suggested this place by my friend because I wanted a place a dessert close by. The line was quite long but not bad. Great is that you can get a free sample to try before buying. I was impressed with the taste more than the look itself. Reasonable price. Clean small area. Would go again! Recommended!
author: C G.

description:
Humphrey Slocombe is by far my favorite ice cream spot in the Bay Area. They keep things very simple. There's nothing particularly flashy about their shop. But their ice cream flavors are phenomenal. My favorite flavor has got to be the Secret Breakfast.

They also have a location inside of the Ferry Building that's just as great, but a little harder to find parking for. At the end of the day, the quality of the ice cream trumps everything and Humphrey Slocombe has no equal in my books.

If you're itching for amazing ice cream, I highly recommend grabbing a scoop of the Secret Breakfast here!
author: Mickey C.

description:
Okay, it's ridiculous how happy this place makes me. As if ice cream by itself didn't make me happy enough already, come here....BIZZAM: BEST DAY EVAR!

So I was tired of going to Bi-Rite and decided to come here by the suggestion of a friend. It's so easy to miss, nothing on their store front has anything huge to indicate it's Humphrey's but don't worry! It does say "ice cream" on the top so you can still find it.

Ended up sampling: Secret Breakfast (Bourbon & Cornflakes), Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee, and Toast and Jam. The guy serving us was SO nice and gave us huge samples! And super friendly too :)

Anyway, although the alcoholic in me really loved the Secret Breakfast (really does taste like bourbon! So good) I couldn't resist on settling with Toast & Jam which they just rolled out.

Perfect marriage of blackberry jam and pieces of crunchy french toast-y bread. BOMB. 

A definitely must come for great ice cream and unique flavors. Sorry Bi-Rite, this is my new go-to place!
author: Vicki L.

description: I came to this store with great anticipation because of their reviews. However, I was disappointed by their customer service. The staff spoke to me in a mocking tone and I overheard him whispering derogatory remarks about me to his co-worker. I will never come back again.
author: Sebastian N.

description:
Humphrey has good ice cream with unique flavors and it's an experience to be had if you haven't tried them, but compared to other gourmet ice cream shops in the bay, there's really nothing special about them. 

Personally, I like thick, creamy, flavorful ice cream and Humphrey's is on the mild, slightly icy side. The ice cream has a lot of air pockets (reminiscent of cheaper, lower quality ice cream) and it melts pretty fast. The ice cream doesn't taste cheap or anything, but it doesn't have the wow factor. 

I still prefer other ice cream shops like Bi-Rite and Smitten in SF, and Ici and Fentons in Berkeley. 

If you do go, Secret Breakfast is a must! Corn flake/brown sugar chunks in vanilla ice cream spiked with bourbon. Yum.
author: Deanna Y.

description:
This place well deserves FIVE stars. The scoops are huge. I'm overwhelmed after devouring two scoops, but it's worth it. You can also try ALL the favors that are available. 

My all time favorite
-Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee
-Oolong Tea

The ice cream is creamy and reminds me of gelato. One thing, I disliked was that it melts quickly. No worries at all though because it's consumed right away.
author: Lisa T.

description:
My favorite specialty ice cream shop in the city! It has a really creamy, smooth texture and they keep it fun with lots of different, unique flavors.

Their Secret Breakfast and Fluffernutter are some of my all time favorites, but I like that they play with different flavors and even textures. My most recent trip I tried the Jalapeno Cornbread (not really spicy, but a nice corn flavor) and the Toast and Jam, which literally had toast crumbs in it. 

Also a good place to bring people. Don't tell my boyfriend, but it used to be one of my "go-to" first/second date spots.
author: Christina R.

description:
I love ice cream and I was looking forward to trying a new place. But sadly, this place didn't do it for me. First off, the vibe at this place was weird for me. . . Like it's understandable taking pride in your product but there was an air of pretentiousness that I felt from the two individuals manning the shop that night. But I can overlook whatever airs the employees might have if the ice cream rocked. From my group, I got to try a number of flavors. 

Secret breakfast -- the only thing I enjoyed was the texture from the cornflakes. I love sipping bourbons,  but it came across harsh in this ice cream. And it was bracing against the bright and refreshing ice cream base.

Apple miso -- lack of consistency since getting a chunk of miso here and there ruined the experience

Fluffernutter -- tasty but became quite one note after the fifth spoonful

Malted chocolate -- mild chocolate flavor, no maltiness at all, and again, monotonous after a few spoonfuls

Vietnamese coffee -- this was the only one that succeeded for me. It hit the nail on the head with the coffee flavor and just the right amount of sweetness

Guinness gingerbread -- like the secret breakfast where one ingredient overtakes the while thing, the molasses is the only note that I got. . . And it really hits you over the head right away as well
author: K. S.

description:
I've been wanting to come to Humphry Slocombe for the longest time! I'm so happy I waited to try the Mission location instead of the one located in the Ferry Building. We walked about 5-6 blocks to kill some time while running errands in the Mission. 

The ice cream scoopers were so nice and friendly, definitely felt welcome. My bf and I tried a sample of the Secret Breakfast, but it was too bourbon-y for our taste. We tried the Jasmine Lychee and it was amazing!! It tasted like a jasmine milk tea with a hint of lychee. SO GOOD! I would get a whole Pint next time. 

My only concern was when I left, my ice cream in the cone wasn't secure enough and fell out of the cone as I was eating it. Luckily, I caught the scoop in my hand and put it back on the cone (haha!). I would've been super sad to pay $4 for another scoop. Definitely going back again to try another flavor!
author: Leah F.

description: I'm sorry, but I'll pass.  The photo looked great, but the flavors were not my cup of tea.  It was so overly sweet that I couldn't tell what flavors I had.  I had one taste and into the trash it went.
author: Julie C.

description:
Cornflakes and bourbon? That is just absurd! Who would mix the two? Humphry did and it works!!! I wouldn't have ordered that flavor but thanks to the unlimited sampling, I was able to taste why this place is so bomb.  So with no hesitation, check out this flavor- SECRET BREAKFAST. Its no longer a secret.

I also enjoyed the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee flavor.
author: Earlene C.

description:
Humphry Slocombe has the most unique flavors and you tell they use nothing but fresh ingredients.  Here are some of their yummy flavors:

Elvis: The Fat Years (banana, peanut butter & bacon)
Fluffernutter (like the cookie sandwich)
Honey Thyme (self-explanatory)
Tahitian Vanilla (self-explanatory)
Carrot Mango (so refreshing!)
Boccalone Prosciutto (sounds weird but is good)
Secret Breakfast (corn flakes & bourbon)
Jesus Juice (coke & red wine)

They rotate their flavors so I'd like to try others.  I'm hoping I can get a hold of their foie gras ice cream sandwiches one day...
author: Rose A.

description:
Best ice cream ever! 
Frozen novelties are my weakness especially when it comes to ice creams and sorbets.. Even during severe snow days in Buffalo, NY, frozen treat is my daily treat.
Every town I visit, I like to try local ice cream shops and this place was highly recommended from my friend who lives in the area.
This is a cute little place with super friendly staff. They offer unlimited sample and if you want you can sample every single flavors they have that day.
Their flavors very creative and unique- bacon, mushroom, Prosciutto, Red-hots, Salt & Pepper, Peppercorns, Jalapenos, Hibiscus Flowers, Ancho Chilies, etc.

Some of flavors my friend raved about were not available when I visited there -  Mcevoy olive oil, peanut butter curry, salted watermelon and foie (made with foie gras). 

I sampled  Secret Breakfast (which is one of their the most popular flavors that is made with Bourbon and cornflakes),  Toast & Jam ( blackberry jam, crunchy french toast crumbs, malted brown butter), Oolong tea, Thai chili lime sorbet, Black Sesame, Vietnamese Coffee, Government's Cheese, Cucumber, Chocolate Smoked Sea Salt and some random flavor a staff offered to try. 

They all were good and unique flavors and I had hard time to narrow them down as I was going to pick two flavors. 
Black Sesame, Vietnamese Coffee (Strong coffee flavor made with famed Blue bottle coffee) and Thai chili lime were my best and couldn't give up any one of these three so I ended up getting all three. 
Unlike I expected,  their scoop was very generous. I usually get a "baby scoop" or two at my local ice cream shop so I was thinking their portion would be similar. I was wrong but I was glad I was wrong! It didn't take me too long to devour them all and I fell into ice cream coma with brain freeze. 
Humphry Slocombe, I miss you and love you!
author: Kye S.

description:
Ask for Samples! I cannot say this enough. I ordered two scoops on a cone: 1. Harvey Milk and Honey Graham. 2. Peaches and Popcorn. I give this place kudos for being adventurous and trying over the top flavor combinations. My husband ordered the blue bottle Vietnamese coffee flavor and if you like coffee flavored ice cream, this one is probably at the top of the list to try. I should have stuck to my advice above and tried the peaches and popcorn flavor before ordering it. It was/is the most disgusting tasting ice cream flavor I have tried. I understand that not all ice cream mashups can be a hit, but this was a HUGE miss. The best ice cream I have tried here is the Secret Breakfast: Bourbon and corn flakes. YUMMY! The ice cream taste is almost a spin off of Momofoku's Milk in New York City which has ice cream made out of cereal milk, from cornflakes and milk. This place is worth going too, but be prepared to find a place to eat the ice cream and fast (especially if you ordered yours on a cone). Space is limited (extremely) inside this small shop. 

Service 4*
Price 5*
Taste 3*
Creativity 5*
Seating 3*
author: Kristina Nichole D.

description:
Get the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee ice cream!  This is the best coffee ice cream you will ever have.  The guy behind the counter recommended the Black Sesame to go with it!  Try it!

The POG (Pineapple, Orange, Guava) sorbet was refreshing, but I'm an ice cream kind of guy.  The other ice cream flavors are very creative, creamy, and good... I wish I could take some of that coffee ice cream home with me.
author: Kevin C.

description:
just do it.

also ( so sorry to the staff ) - try every single flavor if you have the guts to be THAT person :) 

it's amazing.

holy shit.
author: Selina W.

description:
Not far from Harrison and 24th sits an innocent-looking ice cream parlor. But looks can be deceiving.

Their simple exterior hides a spate of eclectic art and merchandise: a mutie cow[1] overlooks details of their offerings, iconic soup cans labeled with flavor names, plus mugs and t-shirts with their logo.

And their ice cream? Humphry Slocombe turns out imaginative flavors that are smooth, hip, and compelling. Their Secret Breakfast - Jack Daniels and corn flakes with a vanilla base - is popular[2], perfect for even a cool day. Besides that boozy breakfast flavor, many of their combinations simply work, including a sweet cinnamon brittle. I'll be back for their Guinness Gingerbread, once I figure out when to go - their lineup changes regularly.

[1] A two-headed cow is mounted on the wall.
[2] Admit it: wouldn't you sneak a nip of whiskey into your cereal?
author: Dave L.

description:
TOP NOTCH ICE CREAM!  

I can't add a ton to all the other reviews, but I am here to INSIST you try the secret breakfast - it is life changing. 

Love this place for the flavor integrity and creativity. The quality is on-par with Bi-Rite, both places are PACKED with intriguing and interesting flavors. The menu changes daily, so you can always try something surprising and new (but luckily I'm pretty sure they have secret breakfast on the reg). 

Also similar to Bi-Rite, the portions are a bit small for the money, but that may be a good thing because if you sat me down with a vat of it I'm 105% sure I'd finish it off. And the staff's love of ice cream shows - they are extremely helpful and willing to take you through a tasting tour. I know some Yelpers complain about waiting while other sample, but I don't mind at all - mostly because I know I'm going to want to do the same thing when I get up to the front!
author: Catie F.

description:
I like the toast and jam. The secret breakfast was too bourbon-y and definitely not my liking. The blue bottle vietnamese coffee was really strong, but could be good if you're in need of a caffeine boost. 

My first time here was nice- quick, quiet (wasn't full of people, so my friend and I enjoyed people watching while eating our ice cream). Service was good- they're really friendly and nice and don't get irritated with trying a ton of flavors. 

Overall, I thought this place was just OK, nothing too fancy.
author: Faye F.

description:
One of the top 3 ice creams spots in SF and I can see why! Thick, creamy ice cream made in-house and as good as 'ice cream' already is, Humphrey Slocombe somehow manages to kick it up ten more notches!

The flavors here are fun, super creative, and you won't be able to find them anywhere else! Their selection changes often, but the popular flavors like Vietnamese Blue Bottle Coffee and Secret Breakfast stay. Today I was feeling a little indulgent and went for two scoops - Death by Moodlight (brown butter ice cream with blueberry jam) and Secret Breakfast (milky bourbon ice cream with cornflake cookie bits). *drool*

Parking tends to be a little tough here on the weekends so you may have to park a little further.  way and walk.
author: Joanna Q.

description:
Yum. I love ice cream. Who doesn't? Came here on a chilly Tuesday afternoon with the intention of completing my San Francisco ice cream trifecta - Bi Rite, Mitchell's, and Humphry Slocombe. This is my friend's favorite ice cream joint out of the three, so being an ice cream fanatic, it was a given that I would be making a visit whenever I would be in the city next.

It's a small joint, just like most ice cream places. To be honest, the two-headed cow mounted on the wall scared me a little. Why is it there?! Anyways, I tried Secret Breakfast first, and I think I knew I was set on that scrumptious flavor, but Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee was tempting. Thank goodness my boyfriend got BB Viet Coffee while I got Secret Breakfast. Both flavors were amaaaaazing! The bourbon in Secret Breakfast was a little too strong for me when I took a bite that was overwhelmingly ice cream and lacking corn flake, but I devoured it in minutes nonetheless. BB Viet Coffee has a really strong cafe sua da flavor, so if you're not accustomed to in-your-face-Vietnamese coffee, then it might not be enjoyable. It costs four bucks a scoop, but they give some pretty generous scoops!

In conclusion, I love you, Humphry Slocombe! I can't decide which joint in my trifecta reigns supreme, but that just means more ice cream for me to love through SF. And to be honest, that makes me happier than one ice creamery alone.
author: Daisy T.

description:
Not a crazy ice cream fan
but I could eat Secret Breakfast every single day of my life.

Seriously my favorite ice cream ever.
I tried to find something similar in LA and bought a couple
bourbon ice cream, but they don't compare.

I'm hoping a LA shop is in the works in the future.
author: Caroline J.

description: Definitely one of the top 20 commercial ice creams on the west coast. The line is much shorter than BiRite.
author: John L.

description: We were in the mood for ice cream but didn't want just the run of the mill stuff you can get at the grocery store so we found this little spot.  I had the Secret Breakfast and the Blackberry Crisp and I must tell you it was delish!!! And so glad they're open late too!
author: Maria D.

description:
Never been to this kinda of an ice cream parlor. Me and my friends walked 6 blocks to get there and  it was all worth it. They had about 10-12 flavors which is good because too many flavors available, the harder it is to decide which scoop to get!

They by far have the most strangest flavors of ice cream I've tried in my life! I had a scoop of salt and pepper and a scoop of the vietnamese coffee. Both were very delicious in my opinion but my friends didn't like the Salt and pepper one. They thought it tasted like the Kettle Potato Chips: Salt and Pepper flavor. I liked the pepper taste with the salt and sweet together. 

My friend had the Honey Thyme flavor and it was good as well. 

I would only guess that they change the menu once in a while and I would definitely go back and try their new flavors!

A must try if you feel like being a little adventurous and loooove ice cream at the same time!
author: Altoni Leen C.

description: Just ok for me, and definitely not something I will order again.  They have interesting flavors for sure.  The line was long though so I decided to just pick two rather then sample a bunch.  I ordered jazmine lychee that was just kind of flavorless but I enjoyed the flavor of the ginger.  What really didn't do it for me though was the texture.  I like my ice cream creamy and smooth and this really didn't have that amazing texture.  A bit more like Bryers, where it is kind of crunch.  It wasn't ungodly expensive for a scoop shop, but nothing special for me either.
author: Ben S.

description: Visiting San Francisco for the weekend and had simply the best vanilla ice cream ever tasted. Period, end of story!
author: Alan B.

description:
With so many other excellent ice cream places in San Francisco, I have to give this place 3 stars.  The staff was great and the ice cream flavors were definitely different, that's about where the greatness stops.  I had the blue bottle coffee and the secret breakfast.  Blue bottle coffee was pretty good, but then again, most coffee ice creams are really good.  I personally didn't see what made the Secret breakfast a must have.  To me, it was just corn flakes in ice cream.  

Another  thing that didn't make the experience great was how FAST the ice cream melted.  Given that this is San Francisco and it's never HOT says something about how quickly this ice cream melted.  I felt like I was stuffing my face to keep all of it from turning into ice cream soup.  

I might give this place another shot one day.  Maybe the temperatures were too low the day I went, or I didn't pick the right flavors.
author: Kay A.

description: Asked for a scoop of caramel apple on top today. The flavor had ribbons of caramel along with real apple slices. Sadly the slices were rather large and frozen right along with the ice cream. Literally large icy chunks in an otherwise tasty ice cream. Luckily my trusty coffee was on the bottom. As always, love of blue bottle Vietnamese coffee still stands. It's buttery smoothness just keeps me coming back for more!
author: Elaine Y.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said?  Secret breakfast and blue bottle are my go-to flavor.

Delicious small batches ice cream, always up to standards!

Delicious, friendly, always have to stop when we are in he city!

Don't miss out on this little must-do when in SF!
author: Alexis A.

description:
People are probably going to hate me for giving this place such a low rating but here goes.

My friend was super stoked to bring my other friend and I here because he claims it is the best homemade ice cream places in SF. Apparently he loves bringing his friends from LA and they all love it... too bad I don't.

Maybe it's because I'm more of a conservative ice cream eater and usually stick to the fresh taste of fresh fruit gelato or the main ice cream flavors. But anyway, I read other people's reviews and decided to test the patience of the employees and tried like 7 different flavors including the famous, Secret Breakfast (Bourbon and Cornflakes). That was just weird. I've never experienced so many different flavors it felt like I really was eating breakfast in an ice cream. I had a taste of the Beet Gelato and that was even weirder. Probably one of the worst flavor I tried was the Salt and Pepper flavor. How can you guys like that?! Once it hit my tongue, I knew that flavor was definitely not for me. Probably worst flavor I've tried in my life (just a warning).

I ended up picking the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee just because it was one of the closest "normal" flavor offered that day. The flavor was strong and so rich that I really felt like I was drinking coffee from a Vietnamese restaurant. 

Although I probably would not come here again, my friends said they would. 2/3 guess that's pretty good?

Besides that parking was easy, there are a couple of metered parking in front and across the street, but less than a block away is all residential and free! 

The atmosphere was unique from most ice cream shops. I'm assuming a two headed cow is their mascot because I saw a two headed cow head poking out of the wall followed by the same picture imprinted on their mugs that they probably put up for sale. I grabbed a free postcard and left feeling I experienced something definitely different.
author: Lauren K.

description:
Oh man, Humphrey Slocombe was the perfect way to end the night/last meal of my trip. Their ice cream is innovative, staff is super friendly and most importantly, delicious. 

We came here about an hour before they closed (9pm on weekdays!) and place had a bunch of people, both inside and out, hanging around. Very cool. We tried a bunch of the flavours as he kept on offering (so nice of him) - tried the tahitian vanilla, Jesus juice sorbet, oolong tea, cinnamon brittle, etc. Should have also tried the sour apple sorbet, next time I guess!

Anyways, we each got a single scoop of:
- Mcevoy olive oil ($3.25) - super refreshing and you can taste a bit of lemon too. 
- Blue bottle Vietnamese coffee ($3.25) - got mine with a cone. I'm not a huge coffee fan but I couldn't stop eating this one. Delicious. Yum yum yum. 

Definitely should be on your list of places to visit, especially if you are in the Mission area for dinner. Grab dessert here!
author: Jonny M.

description: Best ice cream I have had, was pretty sure i was going to get a scoop of the Coffee ice cream, but was curious about the secret breakfast and asked for a sample of it, who would of thought bourbon and cornflakes would make such a tasty ice cream flavor. I ended up wit a cone of the secret breakfast.
author: Adam G.

description: Came here on a Monday afternoon and there was no line. I ordered the matchadoodle and I forgot what my friend got ... But I think it had sea-salted caramel?? Anyways, their flavors are unique from what you would find at any other ice cream place. My matchadoodle is a mix of matcha green tea and snicker doodle cookie chunks in it. It was pretty good!!! Can't believe it's $4 for a small scoop!!
author: Lorina L.

description: WOW! One of the best ice creams I've had. Super smooth and creamy. They have unique flavors. At first I was very skeptical of the secret breakfast. I knew it was their more popular flavors but the thought of bourbon ice cream was weird. It was one of the most delicious flavors out there. It definitely tasted better as I ate more. Mixed with vietnamese coffee flavor and it was a "complete breakfast" like the staff said. Two scoops for $6.
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
Regardless of the weather, I can never pass up on Humphry Slocombe ice cream. Their ice cream is as delightful during the cold winter nights as they are in the hot summer days. 

I've gone here several times. I always order two scoops: one must-have for me is "Tahitian V*nill@" & one other flavor. In my most recent visit, I had the "Harvey Milk & Honey." I absolutely loved it. It has "milk flavored" ice cream with honey & graham crackers. 

Other favorites are the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee & Secret Breakfast. 

I've tried samples of others & although I can't remember which ones, they all did not disappointment.
author: Katrina R.

description:
On a 1 day business trip, I decided to make my way and stop by for a treat at Humphry Slocombe since any chance i get, I want to slowly mark off the restaurants list on the 7X7 Big Eat. What was nice too that it was also on my way back from Union Square to the airport so it worked out perfectly.

I had 2 scoops, which was roughly $4.25 ish, and choose the famous Secret Breakfast and the Chocolate Sea Salt ice cream. The Secret Breakfast has a slight kick of bourbon which you can still taste. The Chocolate Sea Salt is very rich. I like the flavors here because they're really intense. You can tell that it's all home made and made fresh. 

However, if you aren't used to these exotic flavors, you might be in for a surprise. I do like rich flavors and I can't wait to go back and try the other flavors. Parking can be a pain in the butt, as it's mostly stree/and meter parking. I also didn't see a sign outside of the ice cream parlor, just look for the blue awnings.
author: Stanley C.

description:
Humphry Slocombe is one of the top ice cream places in America for a reason! I love ice cream places with unique flavors (Bi-Rite, Scoops, etc.) and this one has got to be the most unique. 

The area is a little sketchy so I recommend going during the day. Also be prepared for a long wait. The Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee is good and so is the Lavender. I tried out the place specifically because my friends told me about Secret Breakfast. What an insane flavor! It's really good. Definitely worth the wait and can't wait to go back!
author: Shaina J.

description:
I keep dreaming of the Secret Breakfast. 

Such creative flavors. I want them all!
author: Jess L.

description:
The two things I love in life other than my honey and baby sister are donuts and ice cream.

First stop Dynamo Donuts for their Bacon Maple Apple donut. It turned out to be a failed mission in the Mission because Dynamo is closed on Mondays. Aw, nuts. I should have checked the hours online first on one of the numerous iPhones I was surrounded by. To salvage the day, we continued on for ice cream. Humphrey Slocombe! I have been wanting to try it forever and I knew they had pork fat ice cream. No bacon donut substitute but close enough to and for an oinker. It's like garlic ice cream. Sounds gross (and tastes gross) but you just have to try it. 

I sampled my way through Humphrey and indeed they had some insane flavors like salt and pepper, chocolate smoked sea salt, and Jesus Juice sorbet (cola and wine). I found the flavors really innovative but a tad too weird to consume by the scoopful. A teaspoon was enough. And yes, rather than ice cream tasting the ice cream tasted very salty, very peppery, very smokey, and quite wrong. Cool, but wrong. The La Quercia prosciutto tasted like fat residue on a pan. How can people consume this stuff? If savory is your palate then you'd be in sweets Heaven.

I opted for a pint of Secret Breakfast (Bourbon and vanilla) and Blue Bottle Vietnamese coffee. Amazing, delicious, and oh so San Francisco. I only got to eat a small cupful of the flavors since I had to skedaddle back to NYC. In a sense, I left my ice cream heart in SF. Cry. This ice cream was so good I can still taste it when I close my eyes and dream about it. That Secret Breakfast was not faint of a shot of alcohol. You can taste the Bourbon, oh yes you can.

I'll be back Humphrey. Even if it takes me 60 years to get back to SF. Scoop one for granny.
author: Rachel A.

description:
I might be one of the few that thought Humphry's was just "ok" but my taste buds don't lie. Sorry in advance if this review is unpopular... 

The location is pretty central in the mission and the shop itself is small but has a couple seats (both indoor and outdoor). The guys working there seemed pretty "whatever" about their customers. They were helpful when asked for things like samples, but didn't offer any sort of friendliness I would expect from a neighborhood joint. 

The ice cream is where I had a problem. Firstly, the flavor selection was pretty minimal and in honesty, pretty strange. I love unique flavors like they have at Bi-Rite in the city or Chinatown Ice Cream Factory in NYC but the one's at HS's didn't seem too have too much mass appeal. They had traditional vanilla and chocolate but that was it for the non-adventurous flavors. 

I went for Vietnamese Iced Coffee which sounded way more delicious than it actually turned out to be. It was GOOD, don't get me wrong.. but I wanted it to blow me away with all the hype.. Also, seemed like most of their ice creams didn't have much in the texture departments (crunchies, chips, nuts, toffee, whatever) and so it was kind of boring to eat.. if that makes any sense. 

In any case, I would probably go back here if that was the group consensus but HS did not make me want to ever return on my own.
author: Carmen K.

description:
I have been to a lot of ice cream places and I have to say that the flavors they offer here are rather interesting. 

I sampled Root Beer and the Lime Thai Chili Sorbet. The Root Beer did have a fizzy texture which was nice. The Thai Chili flavor was unexpected. It hit me really hard LOL. 

I ended up getting their version of classic Vanilla which was sweet and smooth on the palette. I also got a scoop of Secret Breakfast after which tasted like vanilla, what seemed like cereal and a hit of bourbon. I liked it but if you don't like the taste of bourbon, this ice cream has it come on a bit strong.

Overall, a really good experience.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
After coming here again, I think I'm going to settle on 3 stars since it's been pretty consistent from the last time I came here.

Tried the honey thyme, Vietnamese coffee (Blue Bottle), and oolong flavors. I feel that the flavors didn't really pop until the fat disperses in your mouth a few seconds later. Maybe there is an incorporation issue, but for the most part, I feel like I am just eating sweet cream, which also, by the way, quickly forms a film at the top of your mouth if you savor it in your mouth.

The line here is not nearly as ridiculous as Bi Rite Creamery's. Thank goodness, if I am desperate to fill my ice cream cravings.
author: Dianna D.

description:
Came here with Marlene M., Gloria C., and 3 others the other day after a few drinks and wanted to get some ice cream on our way back home.  Well, after feeling a little nauseous from some alcohol prior, I wanted to try their "Secret Breakfast" flavor (the one that's written about in the 7x7 big eat SF list).  Well, I took a little sample, and it made me feel even more sick.  The taste of the bourbon didn't sit well on my palate that evening, although it probably would taste better without alcohol in my system.

Instead, I tried the Vietnamese coffee flavor, which was really good and tasted a lot like "cafe sua da", complete with finely grinded coffee grounds...which was delicious.  I got the kiddy scoop for $2.75, similar to how much one'd pay for Ici in Berkeley or BiRite.

I'll probably come back here and try their Secret Breakfast...but on an 'emptier' stomach, if you get my drift.  Perhaps then the alcohol taste would be more palatable.  

We came here around 8 pm, and there was a small line forming outside.  Fortunately it moved pretty fast, and the workers were able to give us samples quickly and were very friendly.  

Another great thing about this place is that they take credit card.

I'll be back, for sure, next time I'm en La Mission!  Hasta luego, helados!!!!
author: Matthew L.

description:
Whew.. such interesting flavors, what to choose from?

When we went some of the flavors I HAD to sample were: Salt and pepper, Jesus Juice sorbet (cola and red wine), Thai chili sorbet (hot hot hot!) and Secret Breakfast! 

Ended up going with Secret Breakfast and Vietnamese coffee while my friend went with Limoncello and Jesus Juice sorbets. I kind of regret the coffee flavor.. it was TOO sweet and made my throat hurt.
author: Cat S.

description:
We originally tried to visit the new location at the Ferry Building... but after paying for parking and arriving there we realized it was still not opened.

We didn't want to end our journey there so we made it out to visit the Mission location. I'd say it was worth the try just because the customer service was great! We literally wanted to try all the flavors and they were happy to let us try.

I really digged the Brown Butter, Secret Breakfast and the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee flavors. Yum!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I tried all the flavors that normal people wouldn't choose just to be an ass.

I had the proscuitto. I'd rather vomit in my mouth. That was straight nasty.
Never again will I be an ass in an ice cream shop.
author: Sharon B.

description: Another great San Francisco ice cream shop! I love humphrey slocombe. I have yet to try everything, but some of my favorites are tahitian vanilla, jasmine lychee, blue bottle vietnamese coffee, secret breakfast, and POG sorbet. The wait is pretty short, especially in comparison to Mitchell's and Bi Rite. There is no explicit express line for people buying pints, but if you do buy one, you won't have to wait in line with every one buying scoops. Will definitely be back for more! Leave some time to find parking or come with someone so they can pick up your ice cream.
author: Breniel L.

description:
I've actually heard mixed things about this ice cream joint, but as one of the "smaller" ice cream houses/chains in SF, I am compelled and obliged to try it.  Finally made my way down there to a part of the Mission which has dramatically transformed over the last 20 years.  I like the vibe in this area of the Mission over the "main corridors" which can be a bit much sometimes if you don't have your hipster game face on.  So, pretty much immediately, I was in a more relaxed state of mind.

Even though it was a chilly evening the night I went, ice cream almost always is a welcome treat regardless of the weather.  I ordered up their chocolate malt and 4 Barrel coffee flavors.  While their menu had many of the trendy "now exotics", I tend to stick with the classics and slight derivations.  Sure, maybe not the most adventurous here with new ice cream flavors, but my previous forays into other new and unusual flavors typically leave me disappointed despite the "quality" of the ice cream itself.

So, as we all have our particular taste bud proclivities, I must preface my personal ice cream criteria with a few fundamentals, and that includes density and creaminess.  I do not like airy, fluffy ice cream, chalky consistencies, or too sweet. 

On those points and more, the 2 scoops I got nailed it.  Really, really liked it.  I didn't find any of the ice crystals others have complained about.

I would be happy to return and recommend this ice cream joint to my friends and plan to return with my wife and 2 boys who will certainly swoon.

The final bonuses about Humphry Slocombe: no line around the block, welcome service, and no up-street snooty attitudes. :-)
author: Patrick M.

description:
Probably the best ice cream ice ever had. Anywhere. And I've been around the world a few times! Haha
The Vietnamese coffee ice cream is out of this world!
Also the whacky flavors are insane. 
Secret breakfast. Jalapeño corn bread. What?!?!? Sooooo good creamy sweet salty deliciousness in your face!
author: Abram M.

description:
I went here several years ago. It was the first specialty ice cream shops that I went to. Shortly after I went to several in Santa Cruz and Berk area. 
I like how they change out their flavors and how they are sooooo creative with their flavors. It tasted really good and I just have to say any place that gets Humph's delivered to their store ain't the legit business. If you want to taste this goodness you got to come to the OG shop or it won't taste the same. 
Can't decide if I like this place better or Penny's in SC.
author: Dan K.

description:
[Featured:  Outrageous Foods (Food Network) at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ydAypmWUT1g; Bizzare Foods with Andrew Zimmern (Travel Channel)]

Wow, for a place as cold and windy as San Francisco, we sure are blessed with such an amazing and vibrant ice cream culture.  It's ironic, don't you think?  Seriously, it's like rain on your wedding day, or a free ride when you've already paid...but I digress.

Let me be the first person to write a review on Humphry without mentioning Bi-Rite...whoops, too late, dangit.  But yes, I love this place.  It also seems as though I love this place much much more than others, and that's fine.  I was wondering why so many folks seem hesitant and hold back on that final star.  Looking at the reviews, it appears that people think that giving five stars to Humphry somehow means they're cheating on Bi-Rite, the recognized king of SF ice cream.  C'mon folks, plenty of room at the top.

I'm glad I finally made it.  And thanks to yelp, I was prepared.  I came knowing about the cash only payment and determined not to let the Secret Breakfast and Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee be the "good advice that I just didn't take" (that would again be ironic, don't you think?).  Both flavors were really really good, very smooth, perfect texture and consistency.  The Secret Breakfast had a delightfully sweet bourbon taste with bits corn flakes and caramel.  Delish!  And I normally do not like coffee ice cream, but I'm glad I made an exception for the B. Bottle Vietnamese Coffee here.  So many flavors, I wish I was in a situation when I have 10,000 spoons when all I need is a knife.

Yeah, I've been trying to hit as many ice cream shops with the intent of making a ranked top ten list of ice cream places.  I can tell that I'm going to have a problem soon, as my experience at Humphry was every bit as memorable as Bi-Rite and it's going to take careful reflection to make that list.  At the very least, both deserve five stars in my book.  And who would have thought it figures.
author: Angel S.

description:
This is a very unique ice cream place.  They had odd flavors like 'butterbeer', 'prosciutto' and 'afternoon delight'(that had chocolate covered potato chips).  

These were more savory ice creams and were definitely worth trying, but I guess I'm more of a sweet ice cream kinda person.

Humphry Slocombe is a place tourists should try.  It is a place that should be had at least once for the experience, but when I want ice cream again, I'd go to a place with more traditional flavors.

Of note: They have 'Square' for credit card checking out.  Since I have that on my phone as well, I didn't have to pull anything out, I just had to say: "Put it on Jason Stevens", and it is charged to my Square account.  Really awesome, I hope more places start using 'Square wallet'
author: Jason S.

description: The most amazing ice cream ever...seriously, it's that good.  Buttery, creamy, tastes just like what it's supposed to, can't wait to come back and have more!
author: Tiffany B.

description:
A+ for originality. We are all craving something unique when we venture out (especially to the Mission), and I am surprised that more places don't offer a little something special. 

Enter Humphry Slocombe, purveyor of fine cereal and bacon-filled ice cream. I would recommend trying as many flavors as you can with a straight face and an environmentally-friendly reusable metal spoon (not to be reused within the same tasting session, of course). We actually thought they should just save the trouble and charge customers $5 or even $10 to save time and get a quick taste of every flavor, and call it a day--we gladly would have paid for that and spent less time deciding.
author: Mike G.

description:
Yes, I'm a fan.  Although I've only hit this place up three times.  What makes this place special is the fact that you can't find these flavors anywhere in the world.  I mean, who makes Peanut Butter Curry flavor? It's just fun to come in and try all the flavors.  Really awesome service, in that they let you try all the flavors without rolling their eyes and making you feel like a moochie slouch.

Last time I went I had the Brown Sugar Fennel.  Tasted a bit like licorice.  Very nice.
Very unique.  Makes your day special.

I think Secret Breakfast is my favorite.  I think they should add raisins to that and then it would be even more fantastik-er!
author: Darien R.

description:
Ok so it is as good as everyone says it is. After many, many attempts at trying and failing (that line is too damn long sometimes), I had my first taste not at the store but over at Public House at ATT Park, with Secret Breakfast. Recently there was a huge heat wave and we arrived in the area somewhat early for our dinner over at Saison. So being the heat and timing we decided to pop in right before closing. Luck would have it, small line!

After perusing the wall and craving the Boccalone Prosciutto ice cream since I heard of it ages ago, I got a scoop of that and the Foie Gras ice cream sandwich. Gotta praise a place that makes interesting/cutting edge flavor combos. Oh man was that stuff delicious. I just wish it wasn't such a hassle to go here but man, was it worth it.
author: Kim N.

description:
Secret Breakfast was so delicious! I walked in fully expecting to get the Vietnamese Blue Bottle Coffee ice cream, but a little sample spoonful of Secret Breakfast was enough to change my mind.

I never would've thought bourbon and cornflakes would go together, but they did -- the flavor was light and sweet and a perfect complement to the tapas I'd just had at Lolo.

I took off a star because Humphry Slocombe hasn't quite won my heart the way Bi-Rite has; that said, the Secret Breakfast is fantastic and is absolutely worth a try.
author: Kelly R.

description:
There's freakin' bacon chips in the ice cream!!! This little piggy died and gone to hog heaven.

Leave it to Humphry Slocombe to come up with this awesome salty, creamy, banana-y, nutty ice cream called the Fat Elvis (bacon, banana, and peanut). (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/47OC_X6KkiDDQ4jwoCUjFg?select=izV2lVWXlD2PpQ66Dp8Nkw)

It's about $4 for a scoop of their bacon ice cream but the workers are all super cool to let you sample all their other funky flavors. Secret Breakfast (bourbon and cornflakes) and Jesus Juice (red wine and coke) are other faves. 

* If you're doing a Bacon tour make sure you try their bacon peanut brittle and check out Dynamo down the block for that apple maple bacon donut.*
author: Earl G.

description:
If you have never been here, you must try it! NOW.

1) There was barely a wait when I went, which is usually expected at amazing ice cream shops. I'm down!

2) Awesome service! The workers are really nice and patient, and let you sample as many flavors as you want. I always feel pressured when I select a flavor, so it was really cool that they didn't have a limit to how many samples you could try and that there wasn't line of people waiting for me to hurry up.

3) AMAZING, unique flavors, which I believe they change everyday! I tried Special Breakfast (bourbon + corn flakes -- definitely one of my favorites), Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee (never fails), Jesus Juice (red wine + coca cola - more sorbet-y), Black Sesame (strong taste, but good!), and Malted Milk Chocolate (super sweet). 

I ended up getting a generous scoop of the Coffee for $3.75, which is a good price for this exotic flavored ice cream. I got it in a cone but they also gave me a cup to eat it from. It was a substantial amount, which normally isn't the case with these types of places. 

I used to be a faithful Bi-Rite customer, but I think I've found a new favorite. Thank you Humphry Slocombe, you did not disappoint!
author: Hye-Min O.

description:
This place is so. good.

Absolutely the most intriguing ice cream flavors I've ever tasted. 

Did you know stout ice cream was a thing? I didn't but it was soooo good. We had a milk stout with chocolate wafers and the black kolsch which was delicious. The Blue Bottle Coffee was the best coffee ice cream I've ever had. Seriously, all of the flavors we tried were so different than standard ice cream and SO MUCH BETTER.
author: Maggie W.

description:
Oh my, let's get real! The raving about ice cream is ridiculous. My mom and I got their unusual flavors yesterday and it was just like any other ice cream we're used to getting from grocery stores. I not sure what people are raving about- this is expensive ice cream, and mostly psychological marketing success, like the Blue Bottle coffee place across the both (ferry building). 
Portions are smaller than Coldstone or Baskin Robbins. Flavors are different day by day- but that's what other ice cream purveyors also have...
author: Bryan S.

description:
Humphry Slocombe is haute creamery*, fo realz!  

The flavors are fancy and are executed well.  Everyone should try this place, at least once, in order to diversify that sweet tooth palate.

My favorite flavor: Jesus Juice.

*I totally came up with this by myself.  I keepz it real.
author: Diane N.

description:
This is probably my favorite ice cream shop in the Bay Area, and with 2,800+ reviews, I'm not the only one who thinks that! It reminds me a bit of Salt&Straw (Portland, OR) b/c of their wacky and crazy flavors but boy, this place is good. 

We came on a Sunday evening and the lines were manageable and we were able to order in no time. Tried a few samples but ultimately ended up with Secret Breakfast and their Banana Chai. Mmm sooo good. It's on the pricier side: one scoop ($4); two scoops ($6), but it's worth it.

If you're in the Mission, stop by Humphrey's!!
author: Rosie C.

description:
I don't know when or where I first heard of Humphry Slocombe, but when I went, I knew it would be one of my favorite ice cream shops. Flavors like Secret Breakfast, Jesus Juice, or Elvis: The Fat Years can be overwhelming as you try to figure out what's in them, but you can easily solve that dilemma with unlimited tastings. Just know, they're all good and some are spectacular.

My suggestion if you don't know what to get: start with something that seems familiar, whether it's chocolate, mint, or coffee, and ask what your second scoop should be (yes, get a second scoop). The staff are amazing at suggesting complementary flavors, even if the combination seems unusual. Some say Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee and Red Hot Banana = mind blown.
author: Pamela N.

description:
Okay came back and was way more impressed with their flavors this time. Always a fan of everything grapefruit, I loved their tarragon grapefruit sorbet. The smoked sea salt chocolate was like Bi Rite's salted caramel  .. but far better! It's pretty intense though, so good to have tempered it with the lightly bitter grapefruit. My friends enjoyed the Vietnamese coffee and Szechuan peppercorn (you can really taste the peppercorn)!

PS one of the staff members put on a song for a patron and everyone started having a mini dance party. Uh I love dance parties.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Honest moment: I have no idea how I ended up at Humphry's. Last I remember, it was 4 PM and I was buying a lovely brownie from a soccer mom in Dolores park. Next thing I know, it's 8pm I'm half way through a Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee in the middle of the Day of Dead parade on 24th. It is really has a nice bitter coffee taste, which some ice creams cut out in favor of cream and sugar. 

Will this ice cream hit that sweet spot? I certainly think so. If not for the novelty of the flavors (hint: everyone should try the Secret Breakfast), then for a welcome break from the deliciousness of Bi-Rite. Sometimes you've got to mix it up and try something new. Advice for both ice cream and relationships. 

Also, be careful with the brownies in Dolores. I'd suggest eating half and saving the rest for later.
author: Jake B.

description: I have never  such amazing ice cream before. This old mom and pop style soda pop place takes me back to the good old days and the ice cream isnt half bad.
