Two words: Secret Breakfast.  That's the name of the flavor of ice cream here that tastes like corn flakes and bourbon.  Yes, it's made with real bourbon and makes our hero want to try what a secret breakfast actually tastes like without ice cream.  Time to go wild turkey with Tony the Tiger.

PROS:
- Very inventive selection of ice cream flavors.
- Free samples.
- Friendly staff.
- Crispy cones.

CONS:
- The long lines.  This creative ice cream is in high demand!
author: Albert W.

description:
What is there to say that a thousand others before me haven't already said? Well, nothing, really, so this will be short. The guy working the counter was super nice, even though the three of us hemmed and hawed over what we were getting for at least five minutes. He was very cool about giving us samples, too, and I had to try the infamous Secret Breakfast, which was even better than I expected.

Of course, I actually don't remember what we all got, but it was over a month ago. I'm pretty sure I got Butter Beer and a salty chocolate ice cream, which I don't see on their website. I think one of us got Pepper & Mint Chip, and I'm not sure what else. But everything was very good, and I'd say well worth the value for the excellent quality and taste you get here.
author: Amanda P.

description: I dunno about all the other ice creams. But the minute I tasted that vietnamese coffee icream, I had to get a scoop! BOMB
author: David K.

description:
An ice cream store that is not afraid to sell you foie gras ice cream sandwiches on gingersnap cookies is an ice cream store we can all live with.  One that will offer to hold a couple for you until you stop by the next evening is even better.  This is that store.  They have some of the most off-beat flavors, and the flavors change often.  They seem to have off-beat scoopers too, but they've always been nice to us.

When one considers that they took their name from two very quirky characters in a seventies British sitcom, it all begins to make sense.  Or at least as much sense as it's going to make.  We were sorry indeed to see their double headed calf logo get replaced recently.  But heartened to see meat flavored ice cream make its comeback.  And beer flavored ice cream.  And cucumber.  And salt and pepper.

Parking can be difficult, but we've always found a free on-street space or two within a couple blocks ( look around 22nd and Harrison ).  There can often be a line ( only time there was no real line was one day we got there right when they opened ).  The line can be slow because they are happy to let you sample *everything*.

Ice cream texture is just fine, though variable as anyone who's tried to make offbeat ice cream at home would expect.  The flavors are almost always clear and clean - truly a great feat.  The small restroom was functional last time we visited, which in that neighborhood appears to be an even greater feat.

Really - these guys are my favorite ice cream shop in the city ... not necessarily the best single scoop, but reliably offering something truly unique and plenty delicious, visit after visit.  Just be prepared to wait if it's a sunny weekend afternoon.  The line at Bi-rite is longer, but the ice cream here is much, much more interesting.

Oh.  And if you like vanilla, they have that too.
author: Albert H.

description: My favorite ice cream spot in San Francisco. The most random ingredients you can think of is placed in a delicious scoop of ice cream will take you to heaven. A must try but beware you may become addicted!
author: Food L.

description:
Vietnamese Coffee icecream is the ish right hurrrr!  omg...and my bf had something with butter in it....lol.  super good too!  its not over hyped...its really delicious...i wish we had something like this in san diego!

parking sucks around here.  beware.  =p
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Peanut Butter Curry Ice Cream and Lemon Ginger Sorbet.  Great flavors. Try them. Maybe not together though. But try them.

Mean muggin' little emo boy was a bit off putting. Its an ice cream shop for cripessake! Ice Cream makes everyone happy. How can you not smile when handing someone a scoop of ice cream and hearing them squeal like a 5 year old girl? Especially when its a burly, 6 foot tall, 275 pound construction worker doing the squealing. Come on now!
author: Mary P.

description:
The flavors here are REALLY WEIRD!! 

For example, peanut butter curry?!?! EW. However, the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee is really good!! The other stuff is just too strange for me so I only gave it 3 stars because I wouldn't recommend people to come here..

4 STARS FOR THE BLUE BOTTLE!
author: Sophia L.

description:
A small, quaint-looking ice cream shop made my warm summer day a month back.

Was lucky enough to have the Harvey Milk + Honey and a flavor I forgot the name of :( Can't quite track it down on the website's flavor site either, but it was salty and chocolatey, so salted chocolate maybe...?

No indoor seating and minimal outdoors seating, but there are boxy looking benches on the block/next block that you are free to utilize.

Line went out the door, but it moved quickly, thanks to helpful and friendly workers behind the counter. My friend and I each tried two flavors and agreed on the two aforementioned.

Boy, were they a great pair. Tried each flavor separately and noticed that they complemented each other really nicely, so started eating small bites of them together. The Milk + Honey flavor was smooth, creamy, and so refreshing, both cool and light. It really rejuvenated my taste buds with its sweet, dairy perfection. Though the salted chocolatey one was also yummy initially, after a while we noticed that it was way too salty, and had to eat more of the Milk + Honey to even out the taste. The richness of the chocolate was great though: it stood out, despite the saltiness threatening to drown it out. 

Prices were reasonable, portion size was nice, and the ice cream itself was very flavorful, smooth, and satisfying. Would absolutely stop by here when in the neighborhood again... Or convince friends to make the drive with me ASAP :) They also sell pints of certain flavors each day, so I may get me some and speed home to preserve the ice-cream-goodness!
author: Tina Y.

description:
Very close to my house.  Very dangerous for my belly.

Every time I go there there are different flavors to try out.  I've taken home the Secret Breakfast, the Candied Ginger, the Fluffer Nutter...

The bourbon & Coke float is a bit too much for me.  Super sugar rush!

All good, but not perfect.   Something about the texture is always a bit off.  Maybe its the tiniest bit icy.  That keeps it from getting the extra star.
author: Michael N.

description:
Secret Breakfast (bourbon + cornflakes). Its so delicious.
They've got a ton of crazy flavors and rotate them. Just ask for a sample if you're in doubt and default back to Secret Breakfast if you're not convinced.

Close to Cesar Chavez 101 exit too, so no excuse not to stop here on the way in/out of SF.

Staff is friendly too. Now.. back to my double chin.
author: Norman P.

description:
Not sure why but I've been here twice and I don't really love their ice cream as much as other people seem to. 

I've had the Special Breakfast, which everyone loves and is their best-seller, but I'm not crazy about it. They do have a lot of selection in terms of flavors, but they are not all always available at the same time, everyday. They alternate their flavors every now and then (I'm not sure how often). The staff are nice and cheery.
author: Lori L.

description:
Not sure what the hype is about. I came here and got a small cup of the Vietnamese Coffee ice cream. When I sampled it, it tasted fine. But once I started working on my cup, I began to notice more and more how weird it really tasted. It had a weird salty taste to it and also had a strange texture. It wasn't smooth at all and had a lot of ice chunks in it. 

Don't plan to come back.
author: Malyssa C.

description:
secret breakfast + vietnamese blue bottle coffee 
k. the end.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Literally the worst ice cream -- the worst dessert, actually -- I have ever had in my life.

One taste of the carrot sorbet and I nearly vomited. I love carrots. I can eat pounds of the stuff raw, love carrot cakes, etc. They managed to take all the worst flavors of carrots and distill them into a truly snot-like texture. It tastes worst than it sounds.

I had to fight to hold it down till I found my way to mouthwash and toothpaste.

All this was five minutes ago.

What is wrong with you people?
author: Perci N.

description: I tried a couple of other flavours and they were still pretty tasty. One of them had peanut butter and marshmellows and the other one had blueberry pie in it? I don't remember the names of the flavours but they were yummy. It's super satisfying on a hot summer day.  I overheard some Slocombe virgins discussing what flavours they wanted. Not sure what they got but I hope they enjoyed them. Secret Breakfast is always a must! I had it this time around with chocolate and I was blown away. It's an awesome combo. I think maybe next time I'll try the olive oil flavour.
author: Amy J.

description:
Simple looking, rich flavor ice cream in a nice paper bowl with a cute spoon. 
Subtle but unforgettable!
author: Sophia Z.

description:
I must say, that after hearing all the hype about this place I was a bit disappointed. I went on a chilly Tuesday afternoon, so virtually no one was there. The young girl at the counter was extremely friendly and offered me several sample tastings. Although some were good, I just couldn't imagine eating a lot of it and then others were just plain odd and fell flat to my palate. 

I finally decided on the Vietnamese Coffee figuring I couldn't go wrong as I love Vietnamese coffee. It definitely tasted like coffee although a bit weak and flat, but it didn't taste anything like Vietnamese coffee. The girl then told me that it is made from Blue Bottle Coffee and that explains why it doesn't taste like Vietnamese coffee, since none of Blue Bottle's coffee comes from Vietnam! I also had the Tahitian Vanilla, but that too was weak in flavor, but creamy.

Was the ice cream good?.... yes. Is it anything special? no. The flavors just aren't that bold. Friendly service, and priced accordingly for what you get though.
author: Michael B.

description:
There's already 900 plus reviews on here, I really don't think I'll say anything different then what's already been stated. 

Believe the hype.
The ice cream is that good.
author: Cristelle J.

description: Humphry and Birite and Smitten are the only three possible places for icecream in the Bay. I'm glad I don't live nearby them; dangerous.
author: Wiley W.

description: Secret Breakfast ice cream + Vietnamese coffee ice cream goes well stacked together.   Any place that can produce a good ice cream with alcohol AND executes it smoothly gets a fiver from me.  People at the counter and even the customers we lined up with were nice and friendly.  The place just gives off a happy vibe.
author: Peter H.

description: Oh my, this ice cream is wonderful.  I tried the secret breakfast and the brown sugar fennel, both were amazing.  The staff is friendly and the ice cream is perfectly creamy.  I can't wait to try out more flavors!
author: Juliana K.

description: Flavor are amazing, I have returned for secret breakfast (bourbon and cornflakes) a few time. Location and ambience is a slight con. Can't wait until they open at the ferry building. Yum.
author: Jane B.

description:
My date wanted me to try his favorite ice-cream of all times and brought me here. Sunday night, no line, and until I read my fellow yelpers' reviews, I had NO idea this place was so popular! I'm sad to say - and was sad to disappoint the one who so wanted to impress me - I still prefer my out-of-this-world salted caramel ice-cream at Bi-Rite.

He had the Secret Breakfast which was his all time favorite. After trying quite a few flavors, I picked the Peanut Butter Curry. Was it good? Yes. Was it amazing? Not really. And I still preferred mine than the 'oh so hyped' Secret Breakfast my lovely date was so crazy about. 

I just went through their vast menu and learned they rotate. Some of the flavors, like the Malted Dulce de Leche, Balsamic Caramel, or the Sweet Summer Corn stood out to me. I will come back and keep trying, after all it might not be the case of love at first bite, but it could still turn into a lusty relationship down the road. ;-)
author: Simone W.

description: $4.25 for two small scoops of ice cream seems a bit steep, but I guess it is SF & ice cream is a competitive staple here, so people are willing to pay the big bucks. I tried the Secret Breakfast that everyone loves so much here on Yelp, but to be honest, I'm not the hugest fan. Maybe the bourbon taste was a little too much for me, but I did like the crunch of the corn flakes. I ordered the banana pecan & cinnamon something or other, both of which had great flavors, but were just a little too runny for me. They don't have a great variety of flavors either (maybe 10 at most), but I guess what they do, they do well!
author: Lori N.

description: My favorite ice cream spot in SF.  Secret Breakfast is always delicious but it's worth trying some of their rotating flavors because they always have something new and delicious.
author: Bennett H.

description:
Okay, I'm pretty sure all the 4* and 5* reviews are from people who love alcohol. Which makes sense, because who doesn't love alcohol, right? Lame people. Like me.

Tried the Secret Breakfast that everyone gets their panties in a twist over, and not only was I not impressed, I actually disliked it. In that "bleh, alcohol" kind of way, I guess.

Didn't try the Jesus Juice because my body can't handle wine.

Tried Butter Beer, and again with the "bleh, alcohol."

Tried Hibiscus Beet because it looked really pretty and I've never eaten hibiscus before. But um, it tasted like flower. And not in a good way. Guess I should've seen that one coming.

Tried a couple of other non-alcoholic flavors from friends, and they were all very sweet.

Ended up getting ~Blue Bottle~ Vietnamese Coffee; good, but got too sweet halffway through.

I appreciate the unique flavors and sweet service, but I'll leave Humphry Slocombe to the boozers ;).
author: Rachel Y.

description:
expensive ice cream, friendly staff, comfortable setting, interesting flavors, high quality ingredients, but too sweet for my tastes...also its not a full fat ice cream which i prefer...tastes like half and half vs heavy cream...would be 3 stars if i didn't enjoy the concept and didn't want to try new flavors...

Blue bottle vietnamese coffee - too sweet but very strong coffee taste...can tell they didn't skimp on great ingredients

sea salt chocolate - again, good balance of sweet and salty...high quality chocolate...slightly too sweet

olive oil (w orange peel) - basically just tastes of orange peel...nothing else to it...didn't get the olive oil taste..name is more interesting than the taste...

peanut butter curry - flavors went well together...good amount of cumin / curry flavor...but also very sweet...

bottom line - i would come back again to try out new flavors...i really want to try the foie gras ice cream but heard they don't have it often...but i have to admit i don't have a craving for them because it was too sweet...
author: Simon L.

description:
I came in here one evening with my boyfriend.  Several years ago, he owned and operated two ice cream shops and knows a lot about making high quality ice cream, so we were excited to give this popular place a try.  

He had the Vietnamese coffee ice cream.  It was so-so.  Not bad at all.  But not great.  I had the sea salt chocolate.  Granted it's title had the words "sea salt" in it, I expected it to be salty.  But, it was waaaay too salty.  After a few spoonfuls, I couldn't tolerate it anymore.  My boyfriend didn't want it anymore after one taste.  We got rid of it.

Next time, we will be sure to visit our time and time again favorite ice cream shop..... Bi-Rite!
author: Gloria Y.

description:
Get the Secret Breakfast! 

Bourbon & corn flakes, not too sweet, crunchy, delish.

Other flavors have been misses. I got something with bacon one time and nearly threw up. Guinness is a no go. Vietnamese coffee is like a frozen vietnamese coffee injected through an IV. Humphry Slocombe might just be too exotic.
author: Mel L.

description:
This is one of my favorite, if not the favorite, ice cream place of mine. You wont find your regular run of the mill flavors here and I think that's why I love this place so much. I've tried a lot of their flavors and while some are a miss, I've definitely had more hits. My favorite of all time at this place is their Peanut Butter Curry. I've been a good amount of times but they never seem to have this flavor often. I've had it once and to this day, I cant get over how the flavors just blended so well together. I hope they have it again soon because I rave about it all the time!

Other flavors I've had are:

Secret Breakfast (Bourbon & Cornflakes) - delicious
Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee - SO FREAKING GOOD
Rosemary's Baby (Rosemary and Pine nuts) - surprisingly delightful
Brown Butter - a definite favorite
Sweet Summer Corn - so so so good!
Salt and Pepper - ehhhh. Pepper is way overpowering
Salted Dark Chocolate - amazing!
Applebutter - Tastes just like butter
author: Kathleen R.

description: Secret Breakfast & PepperMint Chip ice creams were amazing!  The line was out the door.  Even tho it was 62 degrees and drizzling, the line was about 10-12 people deep.  Yes, we stood in that line.  Secret Breakfast - cornflakes & bourbon, excellent!  PepperMint Chip - black pepper, mint ice cream and choc chips, very interesting yet addicting.
author: Troy H.

description:
Would you like some bourbon in your ice cream? 
How about some peach sake? 

No they don't check ID when you purchase....though I wonder if they should! 

This little ice cream shop stands out in the Mission neighborhood with it's crazy, unique flavors and the line out the door. This place makes their ice cream with ingredient combinations you may not find anywhere else that may sound weird, even gross, but may surprise your tongue. 

Samples given in real metal spoons  (eco friendly!). You MUST try the "Jesus Juice Sorbet" (come on a name like that you gotta try it!) and the "Secret Breakfast" (Bourbon + corn flakes). The Jesus Juice is red wine + coke classico, you really do taste a tinge of red wine with the sweetness of Coke. 

If you aren't feeling particularly adventurous they have some near-normal flavors like Malted Chocolate - sooooooo creamy and not too sweet, it will leave you licking your spoon wondering if you should have ordered a bigger scoop.....
author: Eva H.

description:
Before writing about my food adventures at Humphry Slocombe, I would like to say this. If you are going to eat ice cream, please don't complain about the calories or about how "fat" you are. You're eating ICE CREAM for goodness sake! Just eat up, indulge, and enjoy it. Otherwise you'll wake up at 2am in the morning thinking about that flavor you should have had (well, at least I do). 

Rant done. Onward to my notable favorites!

I always have a different experience at Humphry Slocombe but the outcome is always satisfying. Ready? If it is available, try:
- Secret Breakfast: bourbon and corn flakes for dessert? Yes, you heard me correctly. And they definitely do not skimp on the bourbon.
- Peanut Butter Curry: for the Asian in me.
- Jesus Juice: red wine and coke. One word, godly!
- Brown Butter: literally tastes like brown butter. If you're not a fan of butter, perhaps a small sample will do.
- Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee: strong Vietnamese coffee in its ice cream form. Probably not the craziest flavor I've had but definitely the best back-up flavor when I'm feeling "traditional."

Need a bigger adrenaline rush? Try the Bourbon and Coke Float! Yes, I am serious. Bourbon, coke, and scoops of Secret Breakfast ice cream. Need I say more? The alcoholic taste is strong so it may not be for weak stomachs (or people with low tolerance, kidding!).

Life is short so be adventurous...in your ice cream choices :)
author: Christine L.

description: Great ice cream, and while not my favorite in SF, it is a solid contender with a far more convenient location.
author: Tasha D.

description:
On a whim out of curiosity after hearing my brother and sister-in-law talk up this place, I decided to trek over to Humphrey...on a realllly cold day (ironic?...maybe. but then again, maybe not so much since it's SF)

Decided on the Vietnamese coffee and peanut butter curry (yes...curry and peanut butter together). Both were very very good...though I might be a little biased on the peanut butter one because I like all things peanut butter. (and I also like coffee...) Hmm, also noticed my choices were also "all asian" (so maybe I'm biased on that note too?...STILL.)

Staff was very friendly and willing to help with suggestions and ample samples (which was especially appreciated since it was my first time here). 

(Only "bad" thing...that I suppose isn't "bad" is the fact that it's soo rich that I had a little discomfort in my stomach later...)
author: G L.

description: I have screen shots of the Humphry Slocombe Twitter account cussing at me in multiple Tweets. Completely unwarranted as I simply asked them a question about ice cream availability. No answer at all would have been better. The next day the Tweets had been deleted from the account so I called to ask. The woman who answered the phone said it had happened before and that the owner says really awful things when he gets drunk. OK. Sounds like the business has a serious problem at the very top and that trickles down. The quality of the ice cream seemed like it had degraded since first opening so I guess I won't miss it.
author: Braxton C.

description:
Inventive ice cream that could use a lighter touch. 

I liked the flavors that I ended up getting (Vietnamese Coffee and Olive Oil), but there was something a little bit off about every flavor. 

The Jesus Juice was interesting, but WAY too sweet. I couldn't even stand the sugar content of a spoonful, so I couldn't even think about a whole scoop. Brown sugar fennel was very heavy on the brown sugar and low on the fennel. Candy cap mushroom was decent but unremarkable. 

Oh, and the SALT. I love me some salt on ice cream. Salted caramel ice cream, with sea salt sprinkled on top? Orgasmic. Humphry Slocombe's ice cream, though, was just waaay too salty for me. 

The Vietnamese Coffee, though, was strong on coffee and had a nice touch of milk. The McEvoy Olive Oil had an interesting citrus twist - maybe they put some lemon zest in the ice cream? 

I'll come back, since I NEED to get a scoop of the Secret Breakfast. And maybe next time, the ice cream won't be as salty...
author: Thomas S.

description:
I've wanted to go to HS for probably 3 years now, and finally made it for the first time about 3 months ago, and have been back twice since then.  Have not been disappointed yet!  I am a huge fan of the strange and unusual, and if you're looking for strange and unusual ice cream, this is the place to go.  My first flavor (and still one of my favs) is brown sugar fennel.  also really like the olive oil.  Recently took some of the pre-pack home (peanut butter curry) YUMMM!  

Very glad they don't have an outlet in the East Bay.  I'd weigh a ton.  Employees are very friendly, and will let you taste test prior to ordering.  Planning my next visit now......
author: Craig B.

description:
Humphry Slocombe's ice cream was such a nice treat on a very hot weekend in the city.

My cousin and I ventured here so that we could sample more of the cool treats the city has to offer. I sampled the balsamic caramel and the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee and boy was it good! The balsamic caramel was definitely balsamic-y! I don't think I could've eaten a full scoop of that! The sample sizes were generous and so were the scoops!

Of course, I had to have a scoop of Slocombe's Secret Breakfast and it was sooo strong. Haha. I liked how all the frosted flake pieces soaked up so much of the alcohol. It was great. My cousin decided to get the Salted Chocolate with the Secret Breakfast on top of that! Had a lick of the chocolate and it was really delicious. 

We literally ate our ice cream like mad women otherwise the heat would've destroyed it first! The store was not busy at all seeing that we went on Friday at dead hour. The staff was really nice and even they get to eat ice cream! Lucky. 

I appreciate the water and the cute dispenser it's in available because it was much needed after finishing.

YUM!
author: Angela A.

description:
I really expected to hate this place because I'm usually disappointed by the over-hyped hip places (like Blue Bottle Coffee...yawn).

The line ran three houses down the sidewalk and moved like molasses which I later found out is because people ask for samples of all the ice creams when they finally make it to the counter of the promised land.

45 minutes later we finally ordered:

Fluffernutter
Secret breakfast
Something with prosciutto 
Black sesame
Brown butter

We basically had a bowl of five white scoops so I think everything starts with the same rich, creamy vanilla base then stuff is added. It reminded me of the wonderful custard we used to get when we lived in the Midwest. Secret breakfast was my fave.

I can't imagine coming back and standing in line on a regular basis but it's a great place to bring out of town guests. Tourist usually enjoy the standing in line for over hyped things way more.

I know first hand they accept credit cards.
author: Kim W.

description: it was an okay ice cream for me. We got vietnamese coffee and cantaloupe flavor.  Somehow, vietnamese coffee was fatty enough to feel oily around your lips and after taste. Cantaloupe flavor was refreshing. 2 scoops for $6. I would still go try other ice cream places.
author: David W.

description: Miss this place since relocating to Seattle. I have had a few different favors but my favorite ice cream is secret breakfast and the Meyer lemon sorbet is delightful. Yum!
author: Tiffany L.

description: I can definitely appreciate unique flavors and this place definitely has a lot of unique flavors! I got their most popular 'secret breakfast' which was vanilla with bourbon and corn flakes, and I would definitely come back to try the others.
author: Nancy H.

description:
Yes! I would love to be served HUMPHRY SLOCOMBE. Who wouldn't fall in love with amazingly smooth and delightfully concocted ICE CREAM? 

This place had me at first sight - when I saw the store name on a friend's instagram, I knew I had to visit just to pay homage to the time my mom and I spent together watching "Are you being served". Apparently none of my friends had any idea what the name alluded to, so I felt especially proud and cultured.

We knew the ice cream was popular, but we weren't expecting a line to the door on a cold, Thursday night. We tried the black sesame and the Jesus juice (worth trying just for the name). Neither of us particularly liked either - the juice is red wine and coke and literally tastes like red wine and coke, which might be a dangerous combo for some. We ended up getting the secret breakfast (on the 7x7 2012 Big Eat list) and the vietnamese blue bottle coffee (because I heart BB). I'm drooling just thinking of the sweet perfections now! The coffee was noted as the best coffee ice cream either of us had ever tasted - you can see the actual coffee grinds inside, so you get a real strong flavor. And the secret breakfast was just as, if not more amazing - I love, love, love vanilla ice cream with bourbon (or whiskey) and the corn flakes give it that extra oomph! 

I will definitely be on the lookout for HS wherever I go in SF since they partner up with a lot of other favorite local places. I can't wait to try Smitten and Mr. and Mrs. Misc to compare.
author: Jen L.

description:
I could try to front, seeing how this is kind of a hypemonsterofthemoment type of spot and all, but fuck that because this shit is delicious. I was already following their menu on twitter by the time I had like the third bite in my mouth.

Buttery, like you won't need lip gloss afterward.
Delicious, like you are about to develop a really bad habit.
Inventive like a mug.

I tried a lot - basically like one fewer than what I'm pretty sure gets you a "bitch, please- move on!" but even with all of the wacky flavors, my favorites were straight up lessons in simplification-McEvoy olive oil and the pepper and mint. The black pepper is genius with the fresh mint cream - it's yin and yang, warm and cold. The olive oil is just good, creamy, fatass fun.

I tasted secret breakfast - strong, tastes like a slumber party dare "I dare you to eat this box of corn flakes that I filled up with bourbon or else I'll tell everyone you (insert here worst thing ever when you are 13)...Vomitting ensues.

Rum raisin - mmm...

Jesus juice - see slumber party reference above, but substitute red wine and coke (soda coke, you fucking rich kids and your drugs and whatnot...) pretty disgusting, but probably would be strangely appealing on a stank ass hot day...

Disappointed there was none of proscuitto ice cream - I'll be back. On the right day, too, because I'm stalking them on twitter already, I told you.

Vibe: lots of boocha boocha booch type music, nice enough people who grow slightly bored with your sampling, small shop very limited seating, more adulty than kiddie. 

The clear winner in our Bay Area ice cream crawl. I imagine a long line would be brutal and totally worth it.
author: T B.

description:
This place has alcoholic ice cream. Do you really need another excuse not to try it out? Well, unless you are a recovering alcoholic.

The flavors are all very local and unique. Not all of them contain alcohol however for those looking for non-alcoholic ice cream.

Some of my favorites are Jesus Juice if you like red wine ice cream, Secret Breakfast is fantastic, the Vietnamese Coffee was interesting and the Burbon flavor was redonkulous. Check out their website and Twitter feed for what new flavors are currently there. Can also order ice cream to take home as well.

The ice cream is made fresh and locally right there. The service is always very colorful as the flavors they offer. The only drawback is there is not much of a seating area. It can probably only seat about a handful of people.
author: Terry C.

description:
Charlton L best summarizes this spot as a, "...the Jelly Belly of ice cream." I couldn't come up with a better analogy as that.

Ever since I heard about the 7x 7 Challenge, the strategy to my trips to SF are way different than how they used to be. Most of my decisions are based on what restaurant I could try that day and start my adventure from there. I love ice cream and am always on the hunt for that perfect black sesame ice cream (unfortunately, none of that here). The list said try the Secret Breakfast, which is corn flakes and, I'm sorry, infused with...bourbon? The corn flakes were a nice crunch and I wished there were more of it, the bourbon made my tongue a little numb I think. Worth a try for a first time, but I think I'll try something else next time. Jesus juice anyone?

I also had the blue bottle Vietnamese coffee, as everyone seemed to rave about it. Nice, a little sweet for my taste. I'm not really a huge fan of coffee, but if you are, this is for you. My boyfriend had the Tahitian Vanilla, and it was a very nice light flavor I was looking for. I sampled the Salt and Pepper just for kicks. A little weird, but I can dig it. The novelty of this joint is it's unique and albeit, weird, flavors, I think it would be cool if they came up with a sampler platter. Kind of like how BJ's has a sampling of their different beer's? It's hard to decide what flavor to pick with their strange names, and as fast as the employees work, I'd hate to hold up a line to because I wanted to try 8 different samples.

As usual in San Francisco, there's always a line for something. Line was pretty fast, and possibly even faster than Bi Rite. Neighborhood isn't as appetizing, but it works. Pricing is pretty good, shocked me even.
author: Aileen A.

description:
Balsamic Caramel ice cream is full of magical yumminess.  If you go in thinking caramel, you're not going to get that insane sugary sweetness.  If you think you're going to get pucker-lipped tartness, you're wrong.

What you end up with is a velvety-smooth creamy taste sensation like you've never had before.  This is quite possibly my favourite ice cream flavour of all time.  Succulent, memorable.  My mouth is just watering thinking about it.

Thank you, Jake & Sean.  Your ice cream innovation is so very much appreciated.
author: Marc S.

description:
The people here are SUPERB. The humans operating the concept are wonderful.  The concept is fantastic. 

The ice cream is sub par, lacking ANY complexity - it's extremely over sugared.  The sheer level of "sweet" is overwhelming, destroying any unique offering in the concepts.  The flavors turn out to be little else than a witty name, masquerading the overwhelming lack of depth.  The Bourbon and Cornflakes (the famous secret breakfast) or the Fluffernutter had zero marshmallow nuance. The bourbon cornflake coke float taste like bad honey mixed with flat coke and it was horrid.  The Vietnemese coffee was ok... but also far too sweet.  The only one that had a nuance of complexity or layering was the Beet ice cream which had a hint of that musty soil.  Between 4 of us there was about every flavor for the day... the beet is the only one that was interesting in any way.

I was expecting some very complex, layered stuff.  I did get to pay with my credit card via an ipad. That was neato.  But if you want complexity... maybe Bi-Rite is better for you? I don't do hipster ice cream often, but when I heard they were doing meat, etc... I was thrilled. 

It's sweeter than A&W, without the depth you would expect.  Go expecting cutting edge gastronomy, leave with a terrible stomach ache.  (I got sick later that night, but maybe that was from sampling 8 flavors from 4 friends...  of the most overly sweet things I have ever eaten).

Sorry for the redundancy.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
Now there right be'n many feuds in these states of ours through the years...
And those feuds I reckon
have changed the lay of the lands surrounding 'em.
Those tea guys of Boston, them Rum runners on the seas, the 'shine families in the hills,
The Browns of Kansas, and the great battle out west in
San Francisco, the gateway to the pacific.
Now out there...Ice cream is like gold. Only in the exalted city of Tocumba, Mexico  (the ice cream capital of the world) is Ice cream so dominant.
Now you have two powerful clans: the Birites and the Mitchells that if you are from the City, well you are damn near born into one of them.
Them Mitchells in the south mission tend to be more down earth, friendly, and family types. Now that ain't to say one o' two of 'em don't got a mean street in them.
But them Birties...
Them Birites, seem to cater to the young upstarts and finance driven. And damn will they line up twenty folk deep 
and push their way to the front if you don't watch it.

Now don't mind me.
I could care less,
about either two families. 
They can go on and squabble about who is better all they want.
Second place is not normally a fight many people pick to start.

The revolution, salvation, the motherload, fattie holyland; is at Slocumbe.
Yep. 
Humpry Slocumbe. 
The best damn ice cream I have ever had.
*continues eating Vietnamese coffee and brown sugar butter ice cream
yep. 
The best.
author: Rossi H.

description:
The battle of the ice creams...ding ding ding. 

Anyone who knows me, knows I love me some Mitchell's. It unpretentious and old school i.e no hipsters, entitlement  or gentrification here thank you very much. If you talk to a local (yes they do exist in this city) they will tell you of their child hood memories of going to Mitchell's on a hot summery night (again those also exist) or as a reward for a job well done. I love those kind of down home places that have strong memories in the community because they do something great and simple. 

Humphry Slocombe is NOT that and I don't think that's what they want to be. They like serving to the hipsters, they want to be that place where people go "ohhhh have you tried secret breakfast" as they play the "have you been to/eaten yet?" one-upping game. And that's okay. As a customer you just have to know what you're getting into and what  to expect. For example I don't expect anyone in the Bi-Rite line to be from the Bay Area or even know the history of Dolores Park as they smoke and drink there every weekend. And sometimes my tolerance level for that is high and sometimes it isn't and when it isn't on I move. 

Knowing what to expect and also coming on a slow night and raining (Wednesday) my buddy didn't have to wait in a line and got to try as much as 3-4 samples before we settled. I got the McEvoy Olive Oil and The After School Special. While sampling the Secret Breakfast, and the Flamin' Rum Raisin we sat outside and talked to some drunk dudes from out of town who were a hot mess and people watched some interestingly scary people walk down the dark street. We enjoyed our ice cream. It was delicious and complex, the service was a bit dry but I imagine explaining 12 flavors all day to wannabe- critiques like myself can be annoying. 

Overall very good but Mitchell's still holds a place in my heart for nostalgia purposes alone.
author: Jade W.

description:
Oh Humphry, I'm not sure if I can eat you anymore. I remember the Salt&Pepper ice cream I had last time I was there and had been craving such savory goodness for a while until I had it again last night. Not the Salt&Pepper ice cream, but the Banana Mint and the Chocolate Smoked Sea Salt. Whatever you do, DO NOT eat something sweet with the Chocolate ice cream, it'll be a struggle to get the ice cream pass your tongue because it's so salty. The Banana Mint was good, but very messy, or I'm just a messy kid cause I got the sweet sticky caramel all over my hands, face and pants. 

Maybe I'll be back next time something interesting pops up.
author: Anh P.

description:
Ice cream is such a crowded space with premium store brands flooding the supermarkets, top restaurants spinning their own concoctions and artisan shops popping up everywhere.  The base of cream, milk and sugar is simple and many folks have established great ratios.  The real differentiator at this point is the game is unique flavor innovation.  And that is where Humphry excels!

Limoncello: This had a more bitter, peel tasting flavor than simple lemon Italian ice.  It was pretty much on par for Limoncello, except without the alcoholic buzz.

Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee: Very good and creamy coffee ice cream.  Hard to really distinguish it as "Vietnamese".  I guess there was some bitterness hiding under all the sweet cream similar to the espresso-like coffee base of typical Vietnamese coffee.  Just thankful they haven't made a Pho ice cream yet...

Bad Romance: Lady Gaga is everywhere!  The fashionable pink Champagne paired glamorously with ostentatious milk chocolate chips is indeed inspired.  Like Lady Gaga, this Bad Romance brought forth an experience I've never had before.  Wonder what flavor they'll make for her duet with Beyoncé...
author: Adam B.

description:
This place has some weird flavors. I sampled the cucumber flavor and it was disgusting. I give them points for making it taste exactly like a cucumber but it's not my idea of a good ice cream flavor. I really wanted to try the bacon flavor but they didn't have it when I went.

After much deliberation I eventually got the Vietnamese coffee in a cup and it was amazing. I loved it. I'm getting the secret breakfast next time! It's a small place but we sat down to eat our ice cream and left promptly to make space for the swarm of people waiting.
author: Bommy C.

description: you have to try the secret breakfast & the olive oil icecream!
author: Joan K.

description: I've been fortunate enough to find Humphry Slocome in other places (like Mission Street Food) but was fortunate enough to finally make it there in person. The staffi very friendly, the flavors are wild (Thai chili lime, pumpkin Five Spice, balsamic caramel and McEvoy olive oil to name a few) and the product is simply delicious. I feel in instant love with my Blue Bottle Vietnamese coffee and want to steal the recipe for the Ancho Chocolate. Definitely worth the trek.
author: Nicole M.

description:
MmMmMmMmm so after going happy hour at the Brickhouse with Vincent K., we decided to grab some ice cream before we headed back home. Since Humphry has been the hot pick a bit now, I really wanted to try this place out. Vincent originally wanted to try out Bi Rite but we both haven't been here before and it's almost gonna be my birthday so I got to choose. Humphry it is!!!!!!!!

Like Vincent said, it was located in a neighborhood I have never really been to so the area was new to both of us.. The place was pretty busy. The worker there was really friendly and let us sample the flavors we wanted to and even told us the #1,2,3 most popular.... I sampled the secret breakfast, viet coffee, and milk chocolate passion fruit. My fav? Secret breakfast. Viet coffee was good but I rarely drink coffee and when I drink Viet style ones, it's got to have lots and lots of sweetened condensed milk in it. But it was still yummy! Milk chocolate passion fruit? Ummm wasn't really my flavor. Tasted a little off to me but that's just me..

I ordered a scoop of just secret breakfast. I wonder whats the secret? Alcohol and breakfast.. Yumm.. maybe add some bacon crumbs then that will be the best breakfast for dessert ever!

Kids (one flavor) - 2.25
Single (1-2 flavors) - 3.25
Double (2-3 flavors) - 4.50
Pints - 7.50

They even serve sundaes and ice cream sandwiches ($3.75)!!! I definitely have to be back for that!  They also baked cookies and brownies! Cookies, brownies, ice cream, ALCOHOL.. Best things in the world!!!

Remember to bring cash! Knowing me, I always never have cash and just bring my hello kitty plastic.. Walked in, used the restroom, lined up, saw the cash only sign.. FUCKKKK... looked for a BofA. VINCENT got us lost and walk the total opposite way!! Walked back, used a ATM on the way back... 

1 kids scoop Secret Breakfast = $2.25
1 scoop Secret Breakfast/Viet coffee = $3.25
Tip = $2.00
ATM & BofA charge = $4.00
____________________________
Total: $priceless$ only because it was so damn good, good service, and there was alcohol in it which that made me smell/taste like alcohol for the rest of the night!!! LOVE IT!!!
author: Juliane N.

description:
Yes, Secret Breakfast was delicious, in that life-altering ice cream experience sort of way, BUT, I do think that there's something to be said for these trendy/hipster type places that everyone sort of jumps on the bandwagon for, just because they think it's the cool thing to do.

I'm not knocking HS for their ice cream, I'm just saying, I think some people are inflating how good this place is, just because their ice cream has unconventional flavors and cool names... 

Try for yourself, you be the judge.

half star: I will add though, they have a super cool IPad that they use to swipe credit cards instead of a generic machine. Yay for technology!
author: Ieesha C.

description:
Secret Breakfast I LOVE YOU.  The vietnamese iced coffee was alright.  

Something about their ice cream... was very soft and delicious.  Though Bi-Rite wins with flavor, this place wins with its texture and consistency.
author: Angelica D.

description:
So, yeah...I ate Humphrey Slocombe twice one week:  Brown Sugar Fennel one day, Secret Breakfast another.  

I have no excuse.

The ice cream here is well worth the self-loathing that I feel after eating it.
author: Tigre K.

description: I came in today to get my Secret breakfast ice cream. The server gave me melted ice cream. I am not happy and won't be back for a while.  Thanks for ruining my night.
author: Jess T.

description:
Weird flavors. But surprisingly tasty.

This is not a 31 flavors type of place. The flavors change fairly constantly, but I heard about the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee Flavor, and had to make the effort to find it and try it. Very interesting. It DOES taste like Vietnamese coffee.

They also have olive oil flavor, balsamic caramel, and some others that forget to note. I didn't think anything else struck me as much to get a full scoop, but the experience was fun. 

Too pricey for ice cream, but fun experience. Carneval was also in the Mission this year, so the walk from Tartine through the streets of Carneval was also a unique experience.
author: Debby L.

description:
'The Secret Breakfast' is my fav......Humphry Slocombe was a unique experience.  They offer a number of novel flavors you wouldn't expect at an ice cream shop (for example:foie gras flavor ).So far they have the most creative ice cream flavors I have ever seen, there are: Jesus juice sorbet , Harvey Milk , browned butter ,salt and pepper, cucumber ice cream, honey thyme, thai  chile lime....etc.I love that they're so adventurous with their flavors.  I had a spoonful of the thai chile lime and was pleasantly surprised by the lovely mixture of spices and lime!
I absolutely love this place, they are step out of the box.
author: christy l.

description:
Either I came on an off-day or my expectations were just too high, because while I enjoyed the ice cream I had here (mainly because it was a very hot day), I wasn't blown away or particularly awed by the flavor combinations of the selections that I made, and I made those selections based on things I personally love (I chose Balsamic Caramel, Milk Chocolate Passion Fruit, Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee, and McEvoy Olive Oil because I love all of those things individually). 

For sure, though, the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee flavor is the best coffee ice cream I have ever had in my life. But the others were just okay for me. I still would like to go back on a day where they have Meyer Lemon, Salt & Pepper, and Black Walnut, and hopefully update my review accordingly.
author: Aivy C.

description:
Humphry Slocombe is undoubtedly one of the most famous ice cream shops in the United States, but I found it to be quite overrated. Being located in a neighborhood, it certainly boasts a very charming characteristic. Additionally, the unique offerings really give it a sort of edginess not found in most creamed dairy establishments.

For possessing such high accolades, I thought HS was a touch overrated. My first taste had an amazing texture for the most part: the chocolate smoked sea salt ice cream. It was bordering on some of the most awesome ice cream that I have placed into my mouth. Overall, just creamy, sweet, and savory. Then, it went downhill.

The Vietnamese coffee had a little too much ice crystal, and that is a huge turnoff; good flavor, though.

The black sesame could have used some bolder flavor. I am Chinese, so this flavor needs to really pack a punch.

At $3.25 a scoop, and not a big one, at that, the scoop that an ice cream institution provides me much truly be something life-changing. The salty chocolate was indeed delicious, but the rest sort of dragged my experience down. And the pricing....
author: Solomon W.

description:
I enjoy the product (pretty good burbon and corn flakes), but I'm REALLY irritated at the service.

I arrived at 9:12om, and the doors were locked. There were at least 12 customers inside, some still in line, slowly sampling flavors. All I wanted was to buy a pint of ice cream. Pre-scooped pints, sitting in a cooler behind the counter. Seriously, it would have taken maybe 1 minute to ring me up and I'd be out of there.

I drove in to San Francisco just to pick up a pint of ice cream for my friend who's having surgery out of town. He loves Bi-Rite but I wanted to give him something a little different. I just wanted that pint for my friend, that's all.

But the cool scarf-wearing kids working the counter ignored me for as long as they could, and then kept signaling they were closed with their hands (though still serving people). I tried to signal back, to tell them that I'd be really quick, but they continued to ignore me, not even bothering to come out. I think I stood there longer than it would have taken to get ringed up a mere 12 minutes earlier.

Super rude, and they just lost a customer. Though I will miss that secret breakfast.

Bi-Rite service is so much better anyways, much more family-friendly. Plus they have a far superior product. Though they use the same Strauss dairy cream base, somehow bi-rite does the rich texture better.
author: Jess L.

description: I was addicted to the Peanut Butter Curry Ice Cream. It was velvety. It was salty. It was sweet and it was spicy. I could not take my mind off that sensation after the first bite. It was my first encounter with Humphry Slocombe Ice Cream and I was immediately held captive by the strangeness. I refused to give in easily. I waited. I sampled a couple more. Secret Breakfast, Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee, Pink Apple, Thai Chili Lime... none of them were as striking. By then I knew exactly what I want. My mind would not settle until I was holding a cup full of Peanut Butter Curry Ice Cream. There were a big smile on my face when I took that second bite.
author: Mona W.

description:
I can't believe it took me this long to try this place.  The ice cream here was everything wonderful and more.  The unique and intriguing flavors were so mind boggling. 

After staring at the flavor options for about 10 minutes, I finally decided on one scoop of the secret breakfast and once scoop of the Blue Bottle Vietnamese coffee.

It was absolutely heavenly!  I'll definitely be making a trip back in the near future for more yummy ice cream from Humphry Slocombe's.  =o)
author: Vindy C.

description:
Living less than a few blocks from Ici in Berkeley, I have the delusional idea that I can now consider myself an ice cream connoisseur. But the only way to truly validate that is to go to all the ice cream hot spots in the bay area, including Humphry's.

If you see a line, don't worry - it moves quickly and there's probably a lot of dogs parked outside and so you'll be thoroughly distracted.

Had to get the Secret Breakfast - bourbon and cornflakes ice cream. In my head that sounds great, but I was secretly skeptical that bourbon ice cream could be delicious. I was wrong - whiskey really is God's gift to mankind. The bourbon is subtle and never overwhelming, and the ice cream is airy and light.

5 stars to their ambitious flavors ( like jesus juice - red wine + coke; it's like living in Spain but in my mouth), but 3 stars to execution. Tried their sesame ice cream and it's definitely better at Tara's Organic. The cones are also pretty forgettable, and I alway appreciate a tasty and well-baked cone.

Its novelty and creative flavors though are enough to have me coming back!
author: May I.

description:
Given that the Current Crush section of my Yelp profile has read "Banana Pecan mixed with Peanut Butter Curry at Humphrey Slocombe" for the last year, I clearly have been infatuated with this place; however, the crush is over. Just as I stopped crushing on a guy in high school when I realized that he smoked as much as I studied, H.S. has fallen out of favor with me. 

The last two times I've been here, the flavors have been weak and I've found myself agreeing with my dining companions who, more often than not, have wondered why we were waiting in such a long line for such pricy ice cream. It's not that it's bad, it's just not as great as it was or should still be.
author: Katie I.

description: Soooo good!!! I'm visiting SF this weekend and my friend who lives here told me I had to get the ice cream here. I tried the Secret breakfast and I liked it, there was a strong bourbon taste initially. I had a single serving of the chocolate sea salt and that was very good. You do need to like salty/sweet combo of course. My friends had the coffee flavor and that was really good. Very nice. Authentic coffee flavor, not artificial like you get sometimes. All the flavors were very creamy and delicious. Also the service was quick and efficient.
author: Molly M.

description:
The ice cream is so good here that you'll want to smoke a ciggie after you're done.

The ice cream here is unbelievable.  If you are a foodie and like odd food combinations, this place is for you.  My favorite is secret breakfast (mix it with a scoop of coffee and you've got yourself a serious hangover cure).  Bourbon and cornflakes have never been so delicious.  There is even a little burn, just like drinking bourbon, after you take a bite.  

We've all had salted caramel, but who new pepper and mint was also a great combination?  Jesus juice (red wine and coke) is great too.  If they served this stuff at communion I might have considered becoming Catholic.

For those who aren't into crazy flavors, there are flavors like vanilla, coffee, strawberry, etc.

Bonus points to this place for not being stingy with the samples. Also, for using metal tasting spoons and being eco-friendly!

BONUS TIP:  Yes, the lines here can get crazy. However, if you show up at noon on the weekend (that's when they open) you'll be able to walk right in without a wait.
author: Lara O.

description:
oh my oh my! Im glad we beat the rush of patrons when we came on a Saturday afternoon. The flavors are totally unique and not your average baskin robbins flavor. 

I loved the vietnamese iced coffee and the secret breakfast! My friend got the lemon ginger and that had a kick to it, a good one. :)

One downside is that the guy who was serving us was such a jerk. Super unfriendly and BORING and mean. Ugh, not cool dude.
author: Jeena L.

description:
Yummers!!!!!!

My df and I had an hour or so to kill while my e-ring was getting resized (it fit, but kept moving around so I was always paranoid) after eating brunch at slow club, so we decided to head out to Humphry Slocombe (after discovering it on Yelp the day before).  I already knew what flavors I would attack:  Vietnamese blue bottle coffee and Secret breakfast. Well,  I wasn't so sure about secret breakfast but I was sold after I sampled it.   I'm so glad you can chose two flavors for one scoop.  My df had the Vietnamese blue bottle coffee and he enjoyed it as well.  

Actually, I thought I'd like the coffee better, but I think I really like the Secret Breakfast.  After we were done, I wanted to sample other flavors but I was so full, I knew that it wouldn't fit  even in my second stomach.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Dawn D.

description:
I was looking for dessert in the vicinity of Humphry Slocombe, and I decided to give it another shot. I sampled the Brown Sugar Fennel and Chocolate Smoked Sea Salt, and ended up getting 1 scoop of each.

The Brown Sugar Fennel was an interesting combination for me because I really like fennel. The licorish taste of fresh fennel was very prominent, but the brown sugar rounded out the experience by adding a sweet component. Definitely a novel ice cream flavor that would be an acquired taste for non-licorice/fennel lovers.

Upon sampling the Chocolate Smoked Sea Salt, I likened it to Bi-Rite's Salted Caramel and immediately ordered a scoop. However, about halfway through the scoop, I started to get really, really overwhelmed with the taste of salt. Whereas Bi-Rite's Salted Caramel is more of a "back-of-the-tongue" saltiness that hits you after the initial sweet caramel taste and fades away, HS's Chocolate Smoked Sea Salt was a full-on frontal assault of saltiness that listed throughout each spoonful. The saltiness became the overriding flavor more than chocolate. 

Overall, HS is A-OK, but I'd still rather go to Mitchell's and Bi-Rite.
author: Monelle A.

description:
My cousin told me about this place, and I knew had to check it out. I love icecream, but not the super creamy and dense type.  Humphry's icecream is definitely more on the icier side- but don't let that rub you the wrong way. They have very unique flavors, alot of savory and sweet combinations, and combinations you wouldn't of thought of! 

I really liked their black sesame...it was so delicious.  their secret breakfast is also good if you like boubon- I found it a lil too strong for my liking.

Either way, 3.75 for a small (2 scoops) seems reasonable. Go early on a hot day, there's going to be a wait!
author: Connie C.

description:
I was completely underwhelmed by Humphry Slocombe. My friend and I decided to go there after she heard such amazing things about this place. We both entered and were disappointed that the cool names didn't match the hype. Jesus Juice tasted like it was made before Jesus was born...if fermented wine is your thing...you'll really like this flavor.... Magnolia stout  was equally as bad. I ended up on Honey thyme which was way too sweet and honestly thyme is best left for the seasoning of poultry as opposed to being churned in my ice cream.  Secret breakfast was good but bourbon is good in anything. After leaving here I wish I had gone to a conventional ice cream spot just to clear my palate from the overly sweetened  honey thyme ice cream.

The people that work there are really cool but I think this place falls a little flat.
author: Julian J.

description: I like that they don't have the normal flavors you see everywhere else at ice cream shops. Though I tend to like my usual coffee flavored stuff they make some pretty good alternatives. Been here twice already and I wanna go back again!
author: Khanh L.

description: I'm so hooked on secret breakfast it's my favorite.  Get in here and try them all you can't go wrong with any of the flavors.
author: Carb Q.

description:
After a fantastic dinner at La Taqueria the girlfriend and I decided that we needed some ice cream to top off our amazing meal. We took a bit of a detour to reach this place, but after some time we made it. Quite the distance it was too.

After pondering on a bit of options, we finally decided on the "Secret Breakfast" and the "Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee." Both were quite fantastic! We're definitely going to come back to pick up a pint of that and try out the other flavors. These guys officially have some regulars!
author: Michael N.

description:
Prepare for the tastiest brain-freeze of your life! 

I see that there are a ton of reviews out there for this place but I'm throwing another positive one onto the pile because Humphry Slocombe Ice Cream deserves it.

The shop itself is small with only a dozen ever-changing flavors but it's always busy with a line-up out the door and there is a reason why. This place makes kick-ass ice cream! Try the Secret Breakfast (Bourbon & Frosted Flakes), Fluffernutter (Peanut Butter & Marshmallow) or the absolutely astounding Balsamic Salted Caramel but be prepared to wait! And wait I shall again because this is great ice cream, there are so many other flavours to try and I look forward to it!
author: G C.

description:
My all time favorites are the Blue Bottle Coffee and Secret Breakfast!  I've also had their grape sorbet and it brought me back to Hawaii.  Tasted like Li Hing :)  I would definitely get the grape sorbet again next time, if they have it (since they rotate their flavors), but Blue Bottle Coffee and Secret Breakfast is always there.

The also have some really interesting flavors such as Jesus Juice.  Coke and Wine... sounds quite interesting.  I wasn't brave enough to try it, but the girl infront of me did and she said "Oh, that tasted like wine and coke!"
author: Veronica N.

description:
If I could give this place a billion stars, I would.
So many excellent flavors.
It's always tough narrowing it down to just 3 scoops...the bourbon & coke float is a perfect creation.
Some less than awesome reviews of HS claim they didn't have a certain flavor or the flavor chosen wasn't enjoyable.
Look on twitter for an updated list.
Sample many before you choose--sorry if that's Ice Cream 101 but if I had ordered the Fennel & something or other I tried once, I'd probably be way less enchanted.
Line can be loooooong, they're unflinching as you try multiple samples.
Five bucks for 3 scoops! Free cones on top!
I want to marry Humphrey.
author: Crystal N.

description:
recently visited Slocombes and it was amazing. I'm not a huge dessert person, I don't like super sweet foods. I've had the blue bottle coffee, the breakfast surprise, the Clementine sorbet and the myer lemon and olive oil topped with baslamic vinigar 

All were amazing but the latter was my favorite.
author: Kortni S.

description:
Secret Breakfast + Vietnamese Blue Bottle = :)
Whoever created secret breakfast is a genius. 
$3.75 for two scoops if you're wondering.
I tried the Jesus Juice Sorbet, that's good for anyone who likes wine. The taste of wine in it is pretty strong. 

Nice little ice cream shop. You know your ice cream shop is damn good when there's a bunch of customers even on a cold, rainy day.
author: C. Z.

description:
Being the foodie that I am, I dragged my roommates with me to Humphry Slocombe. I was convinced I would land up getting the Secret Breakfast, but was not impressed when I tasted it (it could be because I can't stand the taste of rum). However, I decided to get the olive oil ice cream despite how unappealing it sounded. 

The young lady working behind the counter told me it was her favorite and assured me I would be pleasantly surprised. SHE WAS RIGHT! It is by far the best flavor I have tasted and I find myself craving this constantly. Another favorite of mine is the blue bottle coffee, which was surprising because I cannot stand coffee flavored anything.

Since this place is located in the Mission, you can only imagine how many hipsters you run into. The line was non-existent the first time I went, but the second time it was a bit warmer and took me almost 40 minutes to get ice cream (well worth it). I wish I would have liked more of the flavors, but the olive oil one is the only one that has a place in my tummy =).
author: Surge C.

description:
Today is a rainy day, and I happened to be in the Mission to meet up with a friend, so on my way home, I made Humphry Slocombe one of my stops.  This place is a hipster ice cream staple, indeed, but today there were no lines.  I like going to normally crowded shops on rainy days so I don't have to wait.  :-)  

Of course I got a pint each of their two best flavors, Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee and Secret Breakfast.  $7.50 a pop, $15 total.  

I tried a spoon tasting of some Hibiscus Beet flavor.  I'm not sold on the vegetable/fruit sorbets yet, but the ice cream is legit.  I'll try to taste other flavors next time.

--------

Other tried and true, notable places to get frozen treats (ice cream, gelato, sorbet) are:

In San Fran:
- Mitchell's Ice Cream (http://www.yelp.com/biz/mitchells-ice-cream-san-francisco)
- Bi-Rite Creamery (http://www.yelp.com/biz/bi-rite-creamery-san-francisco)
- Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous (http://www.yelp.com/biz/mr-and-mrs-miscellaneous-san-francisco)
- Smitten (http://www.yelp.com/biz/smitten-san-francisco)
- Swensen's Ice Cream (http://www.yelp.com/biz/swensens-ice-cream-san-francisco)
- Joe's Ice Cream (http://www.yelp.com/biz/joes-ice-cream-san-francisco)
- Three Twins Ice Cream (http://www.yelp.com/biz/three-twins-ice-cream-san-francisco-2)
- Bombay Ice Creamery (http://www.yelp.com/biz/bombay-ice-creamery-san-francisco)
- Holy Gelato! (http://www.yelp.com/biz/holy-gelato-san-francisco)
- Gelateria Naia (http://www.yelp.com/biz/gelateria-naia-san-francisco-2)
- Polly Ann Ice Cream (http://www.yelp.com/biz/polly-ann-ice-cream-san-francisco)
- Marco Polo Italian Ice Cream (http://www.yelp.com/biz/marco-polo-italian-ice-cream-san-francisco)
- Ghirardelli Chocolate (http://www.yelp.com/biz/ghirardelli-chocolate-san-francisco-2)

In Berkeley/Oakland:
- Fenton's (http://www.yelp.com/biz/fentons-oakland-2)
- Scream Sorbet (http://www.yelp.com/biz/scream-sorbet-oakland-3)
- Tara's Organic Ice Cream (http://www.yelp.com/biz/taras-organic-ice-cream-berkeley)
author: Kay N.

description: I absolutely LOVE ice cream! I love being creative about it, making it and MOST importantly eat it! Even though I have had a fair share of artisan ice cream in the past, Humphry Slocombe definitely comes up very high in my list. One, because they churn an interesting selection of ice cream flavor combinations; such as Secret Breakfast (bourbon and cornflakes), Thai curry peanut and white chocolate lavender, all of which I have uploaded pictures for. Secondly,  because I appreciate the fact that they take time to craft their ice cream, even if it means fewer flavors available each day, as compared to other creameries. Which overall, speaks for the quality of their sweet treats. I really appreciated the fact that the ingredients for each ice cream contributed both flavor and texture to the final product. For example, Secret Breakfast was more smooth and fluffy, due to the addition of alcohol; and thai peanut curry was much thicker and creamier due to the possible coconut milk or peanut butter in their custard base. What was equally fascinating is how each ingredient's flavors stood out. I must say that if I am willing to go all out into mission, while bearing 40F cold weather, just for their icream...it MUST be that good. So have a go for yourself and explore the wonders of Humphry Slocombe! It will not disappoint.
author: Jenny Z.

description: Tried their oolong tea flavored ice cream and it was nice. It was rich and creamy with a good amount of tea flavor, sort of like an oolong milk tea.
author: Angela T.

description:
The first time I had their peanut butter curry I thought it was the bee's knees. I talked about it like a proud parent. But when I went back a few weeks ago I was unfortunately unimpressed.

HOWEVER, the rest of their ice cream rocks. The cinnamon brittle is phenomenal, and the eight ball stout is killer.

I dropped to 4 stars simply because of the wait. I'm used to waits in SF, but that doesn't make me like them. You gotta try it though, it's worth the wait.
author: Ross A.

description:
After being a big fan of Bi-rite for a while now,  I noticed more and more creamery's and ice cream places opening up all around the city. 

I tried a few different flavors and ended up settling for the all famous secret breakfast. Who would have known that combining  corn flakes and alcohol in an ice that it would be good??? Had a double scoop of that.  Can't wait to come back and try more flavors. Thanks for taking me here big sis ;)
author: Jonathan W.

description:
3.5 if I can give half points. I've had a lot of ice cream in SF this past week, and I was really excited to try Humphry because I heard about their wonky flavors. Unfortunately, I came on a day where it wasn't that crazy. The ice cream is creamy and just fine... but it didn't rock my world. I had gotten a small of Fluffernutter and Vietnamese Coffee, and I can barely taste the difference between the two. The coffee wasn't as strong or impressionable as I would have liked it to be. The fluffernutter was essentially all peanut butter, which did stand out but the marshmallow was missing.

I sampled the Jesus Juice and I thought it was refreshing - red wine & coke. It doesn't taste like red wine, and it would've probably paired well with the Salted Watermelon.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Absolute deliciousness. 
Secret breakfast and chocolate with sea salt are my favorites so far.
But these people keep changing the flavor, so who knows...

Friendly staff

Thumbs up!!!!
author: Nico R.

description:
If I loved the feeling of eating clogged arteries, this place would get 5 stars - but I don't. I'm just not a fan of the old-fashioned style ice cream. It's too heavy for my taste. I can do about 3 bites before I'm done. But in all seriousness, if you like old-fashioned ice cream, you'll probably like this place. Me? I prefer something a bit on the lighter side.

I'd give 2 stars, but they get 3 for originality in flavors. The ice cream isn't bad exactly, I just don't like super sweet, old fashioned style ice cream.
author: Sami A.

description: The white chocolate lavender is delicious but I didn't care for the rest of the flavors (lemon poppyseed had no flavor at all, the one thats a mix between wine and coke is disgusting)..not as good as Ici or tara's and def not worth 3.25 a scoop.
author: Layla L.

description: The line was very short one warm weekend around 2PM. I had the blue bottle Vietnamese coffee ice cream and a scoop of black sesame. I had a taste of the pumpkin spice and that was good too. One of our friends got the sundae. It was the balsamic ice cream sundae on brownie with whip n cherry.  I would not personally order it because it didn't knock my socks off. My remark was...  very interesting.
author: Sandra L.

description:
waited in line for this ice cream, because it was the best according to multiple sourced. we ordered

carrot mango 
Vietnamese coffee 

the texture was not right, the ice cream was not smooth nor creamy.
author: Char Y.

description:
Whoa. Humphry Slocombe has some crazy flavors. As in crazy good. 

I had a taste of the McEvoy olive oil ice cream. It was rich and creamy and tasted like olive oil in a good way. I couldn't see myself finishing a whole scoop though. I settled on the Blue bottle vietnamese coffee ice cream....yummy, but a teensy bit sweet for my taste. I'm one of those people who drinks black coffee....so i'm the weird one. They also do not have cake cones...just sugar cones. :(  Its alright because they are nice and crunchy and fresh tasting.

Try it out. I wish you could get a 'flight' of all their ice creams...a spoonful of each.
author: T. C.

description:
Fluffer nutter? Sure, I'd like a scoop of that. 

Bf and I finally got to come out to this ice cream joint after seeing them featured on Bizarre Foods. I tried the Schezwan Strawberry Sorbet--all 
I have to say is, I am not even a big sorbet fan...AT ALL, and I liked this sorbet very much. The Fluffernutter was rich with peanut buttery  deliciousness! Can't wait to come here again!
author: Lynn C.

description:
Very unique combination of ice cream. I had the one with a splash of rum in it (I forgot what it's called - one of the popular flavors) but I didn't like it that much. I also tried the original flavors like Coffee and it was good.

The texture of the ice cream is very milky and soft, unlike other places.
author: Sara D.

description:
Oh man, the only reason I was able to find this place was because of their sign chained to the intersection - otherwise, I would never have thought to look behind me for the small, nondescript looking building. I came here at night around 9, right before a rush of people started to line up. Thank goodness, because it takes so long to get through the line. I think that's because of all the taste-testing, and maybe caus they seemed to be understaffed for their demand (the same person scooped ice cream for my friend and I, and then walked to the register to take our money).

There's maybe about 6 seats inside, but there were a couple small tables outside, so we were able to sit and eat our ice cream! I got the Secret Breakfast (Per 7x7), and the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Bottle. For a little under $5, I'd say it's on the pricier side to what I'm used to paying for ice cream, BUT. Both flavors were very well made and did not feel too heavy. The Secret Breakfast was a little weird at first, with the bourbon and cereal combo, but I kind of dig the weird whisky kick you get in every bite. My friend got the Lime & Thai Chili along with the Secret Breakfast, and while I'd have to say that that was also well made, with a initial lime flavor until the chili peppers came in, it was a little too strange for me.
author: Melody L.

description:
Currently, my favorite ice cream spot in the bay area. I like them for their bold and unique flavors for mature and sophisticated palates. You won't find your vanilla and cookies and cream here. No, no my friend. Here you'll find interesting and complex flavors like peanut butter curry and cornflakes & bouban, and oh, FOIE GRAS ice cream... 

Mitchell's is good classic ice cream, Bi-Rite has some unique flavors. But Humphry took the crown and officially have really neat flavors.
author: Justin L.

description: Stopped by recently and had the Jesus Juice Sorbet. It's wine and coke! It tastes like Sangría Señorial. Very refreshing on a warm day.
author: Daisy S.

description:
I give Humphrey Slocombe two thumbs up for their strange and unusual flavors. 

Another two thumbs up for their San Francisco steeze....because, let's keep it real...only in San Francisco will you find an unusually named local ice cream joint filled with yuppies and people of all sorts of shapes and sizes in the middle of the mission district--I counted a total of 5 taquerias from our car to the ice cream shop, and even spotted some scary looking ganster in braids riding a fixie. I love San Francisco! And I love how yummy treats bring people together.

Despite Humphrey Slocombe's promising name, flavors, and location...I give the local ice cream joint just one thumb up for their taste. And another one thumb up for their back stock. It was only a little past 2pm and they were already out of Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee flavor and Fudgesicle Chocolate. Sad day.

I chose the Honey Thyme because it was oozing with real honey flavor and had just the perfect hint of thyme in the background. After a while though, it just started tasting like vanilla because my taste buds could no longer differentiate between honey flavored cream and vanilla flavor (my boyfriend ordered the Tahitian Vanilla). I will admit though that their Grapefruit Sorbet was ridiculously good and realistic in flavor! It tasted like I just popped a grapefruit slice in my mouth when I tasted it. 

I advise all people to ask for samples because the creative names are a tad bit deceiving! Jesus Juice, for example, I found utterly disgusting. But that's because it was way too strong in alcohol flavor for my liking. 

Humphrey Slocombe is a local jewel that is sure to please any foodies palate, considering the fact that they have a multitude of flavors to choose from (everyday is different so it's an adventure). I hope next time I visit, their fudgesicle is full in stock! :)
author: Jasmin W.

description:
It's official.  I'm hooked on Humphry Slocombe ice cream.  I've come here twice within an 18-hour time frame.

I can't get enough of their Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee and Secret Breakfast ice cream flavors.  The Vietnamese coffee flavor is exactly what you imagine a Vietnamese coffee in ice cream form should be.  Strong coffee flavor, sweet condensed milk, and very smooth and creamy finish.  The Secret Breakfast consists of bourbon vanilla ice cream with huge chunks of corn flakes--it's what some people would consider a breakfast of champions.

I was able to sample other flavors like Guinness Gingerbread (another favorite, especially with the chunks of gingergbread you'll find in each bite), Red Hot Banana (interesting combo, but not my cup of tea), Balsamic Caramel (a little too savory), and Valrohna Fudgesicle (extremely rich--perfect for the chocolate lover).  Because I came back within such a short period of time, the flavors were pretty much the same from the night before.  

They've only been open for about 3 weeks and the lines are getting long.  Everyone working here is really nice and happy to see the crowds.  On a Friday night, two of the guys were just chillaxin and sipping on beers while helping out customers.

A single (two scoops of 1-2 flavors of your choice) is $3.25 and a double is $4.50 (you can choose 4-5 different flavors).  They aren't offering sundaes, have cones, or have pints for sale at the moment...but soon!
author: Diane L.

description:
O.M.G. I've never had ice cream this good in the Bay Area. Their ice cream is smooth, unlike the ice cream at Bi-Rite, which tends to have small chunks of ice still in there. The flavors are all so incredible that it's hard to pick just one. The staff at the counter let you try as many flavors as you want; awesome for the person in front, but not so great for the long line of people waiting for their turn. I was lucky enough to stumble upon this place on a quiet day, so I managed to avoid any long lines. :)

They do a great job of being adventurous enough to keep things interesting, while still keeping their flavors balanced and pleasing to the palate. True to its name, the olive oil with lemon and orange flavor had refreshing citrus notes with the moderately strong, yet pleasing flavor of olive oil. I also found the secret breakfast and brown butter flavors to be particularly good.
author: Melisa K.

description:
Mango Carrot and Blue Bottled Vietnamese Coffee. DELICIOUS. PERIOD.

Don't ever try Salt & Pepper, its literally like putting salt and pepper on vanilla ice cream.

Great thing is that they let you sample as much as you want, but its only 8 flavors each time. They do change it up , but i haven't had a chance to go again since parking is kind of weird there.

My advice: Just try it. It doesn't hurt and who knows the weirdest combination of flavors maybe the best ice cream you will ever have.
author: Lisa C.

description: I overdid it here. One scoop would've been enough, but I just had to have two topped with homemade butterscotch sauce. I went for the Milk & Honey Graham and Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee, which were both decadent and insanely stupendous. Other flavors I tasted: Tahitian vanilla, Secret Breakfast, Burnt Butter, and the homemade Bourbon Caramel Sauce, which is flavored strongly enough to catch a buzz.  Final answer: Best ice cream that ever graced my palate. I shall return, Humphrey, because I sure do give a damn.
author: MariAnne J.

description:
Love the playful variety of options at this place, lots of unique and surprising flavor pairings. The people behind the counter were happy to deal with my indecisiveness. After trying several flavors, I settled on Vietnamese Coffee. A little richer and creamier than your typical coffee ice cream -I was happy.

You really can't go wrong here.
author: Suzanne P.

description:
Date & Time:  Saturday January 3, 2009 @ 2:30pm
Company:  Michael & Jack
Crowd:  Cool Hipster Families w/ Young Children
Vibe:  Cheery
Decor:  Charming.   Elevated Counter Seating on Red IndecasaTB BarStool by The Window & CheckerBoard Floors.  Cozy OutDoor Tables for Deux
Service:  Very Nice, Helpful, Efficient
Devour:  All 12 Flavors Written on The ChalkBaord:  Secret Breakfast, Balsamic Caramel, Olive Oil, Thai Chili Lime, Valhona Fudgesicle, Straus Yogurt, Vietnamese Coffee, Coconut, Cream Cheese Chip, Gingerbread, Maple Walnut.  Flavors are Seasonal
Note:  Thanks to Dan M.'s Review
Total:  $4.50 For Trois Kid's Scoops=)
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
1 Scoop of Amazingly Good Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee + 1 Scoop of Uniquely Interesting "Secret" Breakfast = The PERFECT excuse to have Ice Cream for Breakfast (not that I needed one really...)

THANK YOU Humphry Slocombe!
author: Amy C.
