One thing about Vanilla is that you can always tell the quality of cream and vanilla beans used, as there is no strong flavors to hide behind.  This vanilla was simply divine.

The Balsamic Caramel was also outstanding.  I like the bold, slightly acidic and sweet  balsamic flavors and thought it went well with the rich caramel.

It was well worth the 20 minute wait.
author: Paul K.

description:
This is the new Bi-Rite!  I obviously tried most of the flavors, and ended up going with Jesus Juice (Red wine & cola) Sorbet and Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee.  I didn't like the Jesus Juice as much after three bites,  but the coffee was delicious.  

They don't have too many chocolate options, which was a disappointment for me.  

You can hug a server for a $1, do it! It's for charity (open hands).
author: Anoo L.

description:
Yay for chili lime!

(unfortunately you can only get this in pints).

Plus one more star now that they've settled into the neighborhood and are a little more friendly.
author: Jean K.

description: Just had their Candy Cap and their Chocolate Smoked Sea Salt flavors today at the store. Delicious, and I love walking through the neighborhood from the 24th Street & Mission BART. Such an interesting walk each time!
author: Malcolm G.

description:
you are amazing!!! 

my fave ice cream in the world (and i've eaten alot of ice creams before) is the vietnamese iced coffee flavor. i love it and wish i could marry it so i know it will never leave me.. 

I love coffee and this is the "omg" of coffee in the form of a dessert....
yes please go and try it for yourself.

my guyfriends all love the 'secret breakfast' flavor. geez, maybe because there's alcohol (whiskey) in it - go figs.

i've also tried the peanut butter curry (good!) and the candy cap (mushroom flavor - good too!).

this place is so unique and creative with their flavors and i'm so glad to have it in my city. :)
author: Cicely T.

description:
I'll be returning when I get a chance! So good!

These flavors are extremely inventive. My boyfriend and I tried the following:
Secret Breakfast
Fluffernutter
Pepper and Mint Chip
Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee

Loved them all, particularly Secret Breakfast. The bourbon came through terrifically. I paired a couple bites with the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee--breakfast with a kick, for sure. Coffee ice cream doesn't get any more coffee-licious than that ice cream. The Pepper and Mint Chip is definitely a fine twist to a classic.  Any ice cream with mint flavor is enticing to me, throw in some pepper and bam, delicious ice cream.  I can't say much other than it was delicious! Fluffernutter was much like a NutterButter with marshmallow.  The BF got that one, I don't care much for peanut butter most of the time, but it was good.  I would definietly return for a pint of the Secret Breakfast, Pepper and Mint Chip or Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee.

I also sampled the McEvoy Olive Oil ice cream: it was light and enjoyable, something I can imagine with some caramel syrup or salted caramel ice cream.

I hope to return to Russian Imperial Stout, Red Hot Banana, Balsamic Caramel, Candied Ginger, Lychee, Oolong, Old Hebrew Ale or Green-Tea Black Sesame to name a few.
author: Emmeline A.

description:
Yeah, you're super cool when you find the smallest shop in the world and say 'OMG this is amazzzzing, have you tried their 'bacon dog food ice cream'? (name your random flavor)  But when it comes down to it, sometimes you just have to realize that it's not that good. 

Bi-Rite and Mitchell's all day any day.
author: Con L.

description:
I've certainly got nothing bad to say about this place.  Just a big "WTF" when it came to the flavors.

It's got flavors you'll never find anywhere.  I like to be adventurous but this required a little more "adventure" if you wandered here alone.  So far though, everything I tried or sampled was far from even "OK."

The workers were relatively friendly, had no qualms about letting everyone try pretty much everything...and it's a good thing too since I don't think most people would take the dive to buy two scoops of an "Olive Oil" ice cream, which I must say was really good!

I had the Brown Butter and Candy Ginger, which I much preferred the Brown Butter.  What can I say?  It's like eating butter with sugar, incredibly good.  The Candy Ginger was lacking in the ginger in my opinion, but was a nice subtle sweet.

The Secret Breakfast that everyone raves about had one thing that I liked but just couldn't take at the time: bourbon.  That was one I had to be in the mood for since the bourbon taste is VERY strong.

Parking is the biggest downside (but it is downtown San Fransisco), we circled a good 20 minutes before we found anything...on a Tuesday early afternoon?  Quite irritating.

Definitely come here with your mind wide open; just because it sounds weird or unappealing certainly doesn't mean it'll taste like what you think.  Try it, you'll be surprised with what you eat!
author: J K.

description:
The service is good, if you get the tall guy.  They let try as many flavors as you want.  He actually scoops a real serving of ice cream for your order.  We were lucky to get him.  We saw a female server give tiny scoops to other people.  Felt sorry for them.  Do you really need to cheapout on a $3+ scoop of ice cream?

Flavors are very different than anywhere else, mostly all bad/bitter.  Ended up with Secret Breakfast (good with the crunch) and Vietnamese Coffee (basically like a black coffee flavor, lacking the condensed milk flavor).

It's not worth $3+ for a scoop of ice cream.  Recommend ordering 2-scoops or 3-scoops because the marginal cost for additional scoop is about $1.  Obviously the profit margin is high since a scoop must cost less than $1 to make a profit.  So if you get one scoop, they earn a gross profit $2+ or 66%+.  Probably in the 80% range.  That's pretty big.  But hey, can't knock on them for generating a profitable business model.  Consumers who want to voice their trendiness (see all the yelp reviews below) these days pay up for marketing and hype.  Kudos to Humphry.

Tall guy server was awesome.  I just don't think the product quality nor quantity is worth the price.  You may get a bad server who doesn't give you a decent scoop.  There's also a line, but it moves quickly.
author: Jon K.

description: This is another ice cream place that I have to schedule in for a cheat day. But OMG. It is so worth it! Their flavors are interesting. I definitely recommend that you taste their daily offerings before making a final decision. They always manage to surprise you. For example, who knew that peanut butter curry would be so yummy? Personally, I'm a huge fan of secret breakfast and pretty much anything related to caramel. Also, I always make it a point to bring out of town friends and treat them to some bacon peanut brittle. Yeah. It's how I coerce friends to visit me:)
author: Joanne R.

description: My favorite overall ice cream joint in the city.  Textures are sometimes off, but they have interesting artisan flavors and you can always find something you like.  Not quite up to Sccops or Salt & Straw, but that's just me being picky, and I absolutely adore their Jesus Juice sorbet.
author: ErUta N.

description:
Humphry Slocombe tries too hard to be different.

After a futile attempt to visit Humphry Slocombe at a perfectly reasonable hour to find that they had closed at 8, I found myself here in the afternoon after a particularly grueling meeting.

A comely Irish lass of perhaps 17, hailing from County Mayo, indulged my request to try three flavors, from old-fashioned stalwarts like coffee to abject monstrosities like proscuitto. I settled on raspberry and coffee -- a fruit flavor and a savory.

The first thing that I noticed about the raspberry was the unappealing gumminess of the texture, as if the mixture was half cream and half marshmallow Fluff (a substance perhaps unknown to Bay Area natives). It was excessively sugary, and combined with its weird texture I ended up throwing away half of it. The coffee was just an ordinary coffee ice cream -- a little too cold, a little too gritty (the beans should have been Turkish ground), and altogether uninspiring.

What I see here, as I've seen in so many non-ice cream situations, is someone who is trying too hard to be different. The exotic flavors are weird for the sake of being weird, and the basic flavors are not executed to a standard commensurate with the prices. 

In fact, my second visit was motivated much more by the devastating charms of the girl behind the counter (who had signed up her cousin between my first and second visits) than the quality of the product. I won't be back until my East Coast friends are visiting SF, in which case they'll want to go to "the place they wrote about in the Times."

Don't believe the hype.
author: Amal D.

description: I call these people professional ice cream artists because what they do is art, done at a very professional level. They are not amateurs that is for sure!
author: Steve P.

description:
Holy shit I think I may have waited in a 30-40 minute line. A transient man walked by, may have been intoxicated, and yelled at everyone in line "WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU WAITING IN LINE FOR???!!!!!" I guess he's had the ice cream at Humphry Slocombe before.

Had 4 samples and they were all pretty disappointing except for the Vietnamese Coffee. It was pretty good. I ended up getting a scoop of it. I was excited for the Balsamic Caramel, but it really didn't work. I wouldn't have been able to handle any more than a taste of it.  

This line is too long. And the ice cream isn't good enough.
author: Brian S.

description: I've been going to this area for La Palma and I've been ignoring this fantastic spot! I had the Secret Breakfast and it shouldn't be a secret at all! It's amazing! nice hint of bourbon and the cereal flakes made a great combination! can't wait to try the other flavors!
author: Gordon O.

description:
My favorite dessert in the city.  It is quite the experience.  We bring all of our out of town guest here.  The flavors are amazing and unforgettable! Love, Love, Love this place.

My one recommendation is they change their price per scoop.  The price is cheap, this I love, but the price per scoop doesn't compute.  It should get cheaper the more scoops you buy.

one scoop - 2.75
two scoops - 3.75
three scoops - 5.00           Hmmmmmmmmm................

Hipsters - great at serving yummy ice cream, not so good at math.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Apparently I love trying new cupcake and ice cream venues (see my reviews), so when a friend (Tinna H) recommended Humphry Slocombe after I raved about Bi-Rite Creamery, I had to bookmark it. 

After tackling another venue on my rolling to-do list (Mission Street Food), I convinced my out-of-town guest to join me in discovering Humphry Slocombe, and its flavors were even more unexpected, unusual, and intriguing than Bi-Rite's - if that's possible. 

I sampled the 'Secret Breakfast' (after seeing it on the Warhol-esque soup cans - clearly it must be a fav) - and though the bourbon and corn flakes scared me, it made me want to try it even more. It was, surprisingly, good - and the flavors blended well together. I also sampled a few other flavors...

I settled on 'Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee' (after seeing it on the menu at Mission Street Food, and after consuming a Blue Bottle latte earlier in the day from Mint Plaza - I just had to) and 'Jesus Juice'. And though I felt a bit guilty selecting 'Jesus Juice' as a flavor, I think it now may be my favorite: it combines red wine with Coke classic, and reminds me of amazingy ridiculousness of 7-11 Slurpees back in college in Chicago after a late night out clubbing downtown, making our way back from Wrigleyville to Evanston and catching the el - with our slurpees in tow. Who couldn't resist something so delicious and so reminiscent of silly, playful memories? 

Can't wait to return on a day when they serve 'Blood Orange' and 'Cantaloupe'! ;)
author: Sally M.

description:
I could have sworn I already wrote a review for this place, but I guess not.

The first time I came here, I sampled several of their flavors and was torn between the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee and Secret Breakfast. I went with Secret Breakfast, which is delicious, but somewhat sweet for me.

The second time I went, they had Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee again so I had to get it. I did try Honey Thyme, which was interesting, but I really needed some coffee ice cream, so I'll save it for next time.

I love their off-the-wall flavors and the fact that they provide water -- ice cream makes me thirsty! -- but like most things in SF, everything is a little overpriced.

So four stars it is, but you can bet I'll be back.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Interesting ice cream selections ranging from vanilla to curry.
Visited twice so far, would recommend Tahitian Vanilla, Secret Breakfast and the Limon Cello Sorbet.

First time here service was great, only problem I had was the music at the time.  Rap songs with plenty of curse words while these little kids walked in.

Second time here service varied. One server was very friendly, bright smile and even danced to the music.  Other server was kind of tired and had no energy left.

Would definitely grab more ice cream from this place as the flavors are unique and some taste very good. Would make for a nice little date destination on a hot day.
author: B M.

description:
You definitely have to give them credit for unique flavors, and I wish I got to try some of the ones people listed on their Yelp reviews. But when I went most of the flavors were "normal" so I was a little disappointed. I did get to try the Secret Breakfast though, and yes it is pretty boozy and awesome. It could have used some more cornflakes.

Aside from the flavors, the quality of the ice cream is just okay to me. I prefer Bi-Rite's creaminess. Humphry Slocombe just isn't as smooth in comparison.
author: Jen K.

description:
Humphry Slocombe has been on my hit list for quite some time now. Following them on Twitter, I got teased every day with hints of delicious ice cream flavors. Somehow, every time I was in the city, I never seemed to make it over to sample their much-hyped ice cream.

It was a beautiful, sunny Memorial Day and I was killing time before the Lykke Li show, and couldn't resist the urge for ice cream. It was so sunny--it would have been a crime not to indulge in ice cream! I wasn't the only one craving ice cream--I found myself in a sizeable line for ice cream at Humphry Slocombe.

The case was full of interesting and unusual flavor combinations, including McEvoy olive oil, Harvey Milk and Honey (with honey and graham crackers), Jesus Juice sorbet (with wine and coke), and of course Secret Breakfast (bourbon and corn flakes). 

After sampling a number of flavors, I decided to do a double scoop with peanut butter curry and Vietnamese iced coffee (made with Blue Bottle coffee). The peanut butter curry was sweet, with hints of spicy curry. The Vietnamese iced coffee was very rich, with a strong coffee flavor. The combination of the two was perfect.

The ice cream here was delicious--certainly worthy of the hype and the wait. The unique flavors might sound a little funky, but they're mighty tasty. And the ice cream itself has a rich, creamy texture. I'll definitely be back to sample more of Humphry Slocombe's ice cream--I just wish I lived closer so I could sample them more often.
author: Raul N.

description: I actually wanted to give 3.5 stars but that's not possible.... (Just like how Facebook doesn't have a dislike button for whatever reason) I only decided to try this place out because it was featured in I think an article written by the SF guardian about weird ice cream joints. (And the fact that my parents were getting a thai massage in the area so I had over an hour to kill) I do agree that they have some pretty weird flavors. Not that they were horrible-weird but they weren't "OMG! I could eat this and only this FOREVER!!!!" kind of flavors. It's probably just that I have more asian-like taste buds and go for the fruity and asian ice creams. I tried the vietnamese coffee, chocolate chip cream cheese one, coconut one, and the olive oil one. In a sense.... All I did was compare this place to Marco Polo gelato. For the price of a scoop of ice cream, I just rather eat Marco Polo's!
author: Mindy C.

description:
Haven't been here for a while. Decided to update my review because:
-It's a good deal - $5 for 3 scoops (brown sugar, secret breakfast, coffee).
-I'm lactose intolerant and still ate half (to the annoyance of my husband).
-They don't bore your taste buds by hiding behind "super premium" (high fat). That doesn't help anything if the flavors aren't there.
-Unique and different, but in a fun, not annoying way.
author: Eme L.

description:
OOLONG TEA is a win. It was my favorite of the scoops that my friends and I got. The flavor was subtle, but that's the way I think tea-flavored ice cream should be. It had a creamy after-taste, which was surprisingly good (I usually don't like very creamy-tasting ice cream). 

BLUE BOTTLE VIETNAMESE COFFEE is in 2nd place. The coffee flavor is strong and sweet. Nothing bad about it at all. Rather tasty, actually. 

I'm not really going to say anything about the SESAME one, because I didn't like it very much. The flavor was too overpowering. 

The best thing about this place is that the ice cream is not gloopy or too creamy, but the texture and consistency is fluffy and light. One of my ice cream pet peeves is when it melts too quickly, but this ice cream stayed frozen and fluffy the whole time. Maybe we just ate it too quickly. :]
author: Lillian K.

description: OMG I had the best Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee and Oolong Tea on a hot day!!!!
author: Deborah V.

description:
Roasted white chocolate lavendar ice cream. While the girls in front of me tried 57 flavors, I knew that was the one, had a tiny taste and immediately ordered a scoop. It was huge, I felt guilty (almost) eating it all, but I made it through. I wasn't planning on ice cream, and I'd been eating my way through the Mission all afternoon, but HS was open, and was just far enough from Heather C.'s house that we could walk off at least a small portion of what we had just consumed. 

Today is Thanksgiving and they have pumpkin ice cream pies. That is what I'm going to say I'm thankful for at the dinner table when my turn comes.
author: Lesly S.

description:
You can try a spoon of whatever flavors you want before you take your pick for a whole scoop.  The people who work here are awesome because they will continue to ask you if they can help you try a flavor, even if you have already sampled two or three.  

If you make ice cream at home like we do, a stop here will inspire you to think outside the tub.  

Worth the wait in line.
author: Elaine S.

description:
I. Am. Obsessed.  Sometimes I dream about Secret Breakfast and am glad when I wake up to see that I haven't slept-walk over and ate a pint (or 3).  It is so good, so fresh, and their flavors are on POINT.

I tried the Jesus Juice last time (Red Wine sorbet type) and almooosttt got that over Secret Breakfast but couldn't bring myself to do it. 

My only problem with this place is that the ice cream gods hate me (or the gym gods love me) and 50% of the time I go by this place it's closed. seriously?!  can you just be open like....til midnight? and when I call last minute to say I'm in the area? and....right now? *sigh* until we meet again.
author: Megha A.

description:
Mind blowing toppings, and even better ice cream. Loved the marshmallow fluff topping (reminded me of Brigham's back in Boston) and the hot fudge but the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee flavor stole the show. I really loved the Brown Sugar, too.

Their Secret Breakfast flavor wasn't my favorite, but it seemed to be the crowd favorite at an office ice cream social. I can't wait to make the trip out to this place in person.
author: christine c.

description:
I'm eating my way through the SF Big Eat List which brought me to Humphrey Slocombe in search of Secret Breakfast Ice Cream. 

This my friends changed my life. 

I dn't know what I thought Secret Breakfast would be but it turns out it's Bourbon Cornflake ice cream. Bourbon and Corn Flakes sounds like a line from a Ke$ha song but even if like me you don't brush your teeth with a bottle of Jack you should still eat this ice cream. Like so many things that seem incongruent at first, they are made for each other. The Bourbon is your loud, funny Uncle and the corn flakes are your Aunt who rolls her eyes at his jokes.

I can tell you though that everything there is good. I know this because I tasted every singe flavor in addition to my cone of Secret Breakfast and i have to say that this place is exactly why I decided to eat my way through the Big Eat List. I wanted to break out of routines and try new things.
I had to brave new civilizations.  I had to boldly go where no M.L.E. has gone before.

Verdict:  Stop reading this.  Go there now.  Empty your bank account to buy ice cream.
author: Emily P.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to try this place after seeing it featured on the Food Network's show "The Best Thing I Ever Ate".  The flavor that was featured by one of the chef's was a prosciutto ice cream!  Anything that has a bacon flavor to it must be worth a try.  When we got there, the flavor was no longer available and the worker helping us wasn't sure when it would be back.  He was so helpful and let us sample any of the other flavors.  We settled on getting the Secret Breakfast flavor, which is bourbon and cornflakes.  SO GOOD!!  The right blend of ingredients in the ice cream, not too sweet either.  He said it was one of their popular flavors, and now one of my faves.

All in all this ice cream shop is a little fun hole in the wall that does get busy quickly.  We will definitely come back to try other flavors, because some of their flavor combos are surprisingly good as an ice cream!
author: JulieAnne L.

description:
Secret Breakfast
Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee
Black Sesame

I tried those three and was thoroughly impressed.  I want to try their bourbon coke float and a little of their bourbon caramel.  

Not much else to say.  Service is very friendly, there's a two-headed cow bust on the wall, and plenty of unique ice cream flavors to enjoy.  Love it!
author: Chris C.

description:
definitely one of the best ice cream parlors in SF. the flavor options alone will blow you away. very original and tasty and for the brave at heart to try!

secret breakfast - my fav
balsamic caramel - yum yum
i always wanted to try boccalone prosciutto but they didnt have it available the last few times i've been.

I am always excited to see what flavors they have. I wish i could have their secret ice cream sandwich though... (saw it on food network or something)
author: Minnow N.

description:
Yum Yum!  I read about this in NY Times a year or so ago, and decided to try it out.  It's awesome.  I had a scoop of the Secret Breakfast with a scoop of the Vietnamese Coffee.  I've never had anything so good!  We also tried something with grapefruit, which we weren't expecting much from, but it was awesome.  This is not Baskin Robbins.

We also later had the Secret Breakfast at a local museum coffee shop, but is was not nearly as good as at the Harrison shop.  Go there and get some!  It's about 6 blocks from the BART station, a decent walk to work off the calories or you can take a bus if you are lazy.

The storefront markings aren't so obvious, but the line out the store is a give away.  And yes, it's definitely worth the wait.  This will be a definite stop anytime we're visiting the city.
author: Lynto L.

description:
Its not like this place needs anymore reviews but I must express my love for this little gem. 

This place has a lot of interesting flavors that will have you guessing before you get up to the tasting line.  Jesus juice is great.  My two favorites are the Vietnamese Coffee and Secret Breakfast.  The coffee flavor is perfect and just how I would like my Vietnamese ice coffee; thick & strong.  The secret breakfast consists of whiskey and corn flakes with a vanilla base.  Oh yes, whiskey and corn flakes are incredible together.  Just don't do it without the vanilla base.  Bitting into corn flake chunks makes my heart sings.
author: Nho C.

description:
I visited this shop specifically because of the NYT article that promised prosciutto ice cream...sadly there was no prosciutto...or anything bacony...There was however the most friendly staff ever!! Who patiently let me taste pretty much every other available flavour. 

Ultimately I chose a double scoop of stout and salt & pepper ice cream. MMM SALT & PEPPER ICE CREAM!

Anyway the bacon flavours are "seasonal" (so I hear) so don't give up!
author: Liora I.

description:
All I have to say is ....thee best birthday present by far hands down..Blue bottle Vietnamese coffee with almond crunch....Mmm..Mmm..G -DOUBLE O-D good!!! Huge explosion of OHH YEAH!!!

My first time here was on a Sunday. We got good nearby parking and the line wasn't terribly long. There's limited seating inside 6-8 diner like bar stools. I can't wait to come back and try other flavors!!!!
By the way..CASH ONLY!!
author: Clarissa B.

description: Secret mutrhahfukkin Breakfast, Jesus Juice, and pretty much anything else.  I really try to make up excuses to come here.  Oh yeah...Thai Chili Lime.  WOW!!!  Do not hesitate.  Do not question.  Do.
author: Andre L.

description:
Finally got a chance to try their ice cream. We drove by en route to nearby Flour + Water for dinner and saw the line out the door with just "Ice Cream" printed on the awning. The name of the store finally appears on the window and I knew we were in the right place. CASH ONLY. 

I tried the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee - a wonderfully strong coffee flavor with ground bits of coffee. It had what seemed like tiny, tiny globs of butterfat in it. At first it reminded me of lumpy, homemade gravy. But, it would melt away on your tongue. The maple walnut was great too. My only complaint is that their ice creams are really, really sweet. Even sweeter than store bought pints of Haagen Das which is a value at $2.50-$3.00 a pint on sale compared to $7.50/pint for Humphry's. 

Jr. Yelper tried the vanilla. I thought it was good, with tiny bits of vanilla bean ground in. We all sampled the "Special Breakfast" and you can taste the booze in it! Hubby was the only brave one to try it - bourbon and corn flakes! 

I like that they serve the ice cream in paper eco-friendly cups and the plastic spoons are made from plant products and recyclable or you can get the cones and eat the whole thing!
author: Ry T.

description:
There was a very short line when I went here. I sampled the Blue Bottle Vietnamese coffee and it was yummy. I got one scoop of the Cucumber Ice Milk. It was ok. My daughter really liked it. 

They have such unique flavors and names for their ice cream. I need to go back and try the secret breakfast.

I am a fan!  We usually aren't this far out, but after a dance workshop, my friend and I wanted to eat in the area.  After dinner at Lime Rotisserie, we figured we were close enough to make our way here.

It's always fun to try all these random flavors with the crazy names but I honestly can't remember what I had in the past, besides the secret breakfast.  This time was different though.  After sample a few different things (the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee sounded great, but too sweet), I went with a scoop of Secret Breakfast and the Harvey Milk + Honey something something.  I have to say, the Harvey Milk may be a new favorite here!  

The place itself is small and unassuming, but it was nice and chill to just sit outside and chat over ice cream.  A little out of the way for me, but if I'm in the area, I'll make the effort to stop here.
author: Tom Y.

description:
Went to Frances for dinner the other night and dessert include a generous serving of some killer ice cream. Delighted, I inquired into the source of said tongue tickling delight. Answer: Humphry Slocombe. So, like any good food whore I went the very next night down the Mission to try some more. 

Flavors: Bourbon + Cornflakes (i.e. "Secret Breakfast") and then some salted chocolate number. 

Verdict: Awesome. You know how sometimes ice cream flavor is sort of dulled compared to, say, gelato? You know, it's like so creamy and all that that the flavor gets a bit muted? Ok, that is NOT a problem here. The flavors are super intense, rich, and wonderful. 

Definitely give it a go.
author: Heather W.

description:
After seeing this place on Bizarre Foods, I really wanted to take a trip here when I went to San Fran. Humphry's is seriously the most fun you will have at an ice cream parlor. It's not in the most convenient part of San Fran, but it's worth the drive :)

When i came here i had to try almost everything. Some of the flavors that day were, Olive Oil, Jesus Juice, Burnt Butter, Oolong Tea, Vietnamese Coffee, and FlufferNutter....It's so ridiculously creative it works XD

The Burnt Butter actually tasted like a melt in your mouth french toast. SOOO good. And the Vietnamese coffee was one of the best tasting coffees I've ever had. A must try for coffee lovers!

BUT, I have 2 words for you. SECRET. BREAKFAST. It seriously blew my expectations away. Bourbon and corn flakes flavored ice cream?!!!!!!!!! YES. PLEASE. It had a great bourbon taste like a nice bourbon flavored cake. But the corn flakes seriously made the ice cream. The amazing crunch of the frozen corn flakes PERFECTLY complimented the bourbon. A MUST HAVE.

Humphry's is the most inventive ice cream shop in the bay area. I'll for sure be coming back there when I come up to visit again!
author: Calvin L.

description:
3.5/5 always good.

it seems a little cheaper, and the variety of flavors is good when you're looking to satisfy your non-salted caramel craving that you normally get at the other place. i also enjoy the walk down 24th getting here.
author: Alvin D.

description:
Read so much about this place and the interesting flavors...glad we finally got a chance to try it.  

Around 8:30pm, there is still a line on a cool night but the line moved pretty fast - most people knew what they want instead of having a taste of every flavor.  Unlike any other time, I made up my mind while standing in line - never been done but partialy because I had to move on fast to stay away from the dog behind me.  

I picked the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee, Balsamic Caramel, McEvoy Olive Oil - all for $5!  The coffee was good, very similar to the dripped coffee you would get from a Vietnamese restaurant.  The balsamic caramel was different, the olive oil was creamy.  The mix of olive oil and balsamic caramel was quite good but the 3 mixed together was surprisingly excellent, yum!
author: Gloria H.

description: This place is great and a mission secret (compared to bi rite, which is practically a six flags attraction). Some of my favorite flavored are the ginger fernet sorbet, black sesame, and of course the infamous secret breakfast.
author: Siva M.

description:
As a fan of Bi-Rite and Mitchell's, I felt the need to try this place. The reason why I came here was because of the alcohol infused flavors. I ended up trying the secret breakfast since everyone seems to get that here. I also ended up getting the almanac summer, which was a beer-infused ice cream.

The secret breakfast was a bit strong for my taste. I felt the same way about the salted caramel at Bi-Rite. Meh, I blame everyone else for hyping up those flavors too much haha. The almanac summer was way better in my opinion. The taste of beer in the ice cream was subtle, without taking away the fact that its more about being ice cream.    

The shop itself was nice and clean. Not too busy since I went on a rainy day. I just wanted to try it and I was in the area. Let me have my opportunities! Workers were friendly though, and were kind enough to let me sample a bunch of other flavors. I remember it was cash only, so yeah, cash only. 

I'd come back to try the other flavors. I also heard Poly Ann's is worth trying. Love the alcohol-flavored concept haha.
author: Loren John B.

description:
/edit

Wait. Guinness Gingerbread is delicious. OMG OMG OMG. LOVE LOVE LOVE.

/end edit

Take your taste buds for a wild ride at Humphry's, and the best part? It's ice cream!

Things you should know about Humphry's:
1.) It has some of the most interesting flavors you'll ever hear. Jesus Juice?Secret Breakfast? Boccalone Prosciutto? Salt and Pepper? Can't find these anywhere.
2.) The service is always nice. The workers there just want to maximize your ice cream experience. Is that too much to ask?
3.) Beware of the art. The two headed cow as the mascot is pretty cool and funky, but if you look at the painting next to the door (and realize what it is)... *shivers*

My only down part is that there is only street parking, and the streets are pretty narrow.

But Humphry's still makes me smile like no other. I'm considering loading up on some gear from there. :)!
author: Jessica H.

description:
I dream of Secret Breakfast.  I've been keeping an eye out for the foie gras and prosciutto flavors. 

Jake Godby is pure genius
author: Ree-och G.

description:
tuesday evening. 7:40pm. no line.
2 scoops. secret breakfast + blue bottle vietnamese coffee = $3.75
pure satisfaction!
author: Helen Y.

description:
If happiness could be described in terms of ice cream, Ben & Jerry's would be a nice day at the park while Humphry Slocombe would be a wild and tantric night of sex where your legs end up somewhere in the air and you picture describing it to your close friends as "some crazy shit." Although it can be brief, the intensity and fond memories will last well into your nursing home days.

So far I've purchased 3 flavors and tried several others. Here's the quick and dirty (emphasis on dirty) on what has graced these lips.

What I've Devoured:
-Secret Breakfast: this is the flavor that put this two-headed cow loving place on the map. Bourbon and cornflakes have never tasted so good. I'm not even a bourbon fan, but I would drink this as a milkshake for breakfast if I could 

-Brown Butter: If Paula Deen could have a show dedicated to ice cream, I imagine most flavors would resemble this. But jeebus it's good. Best enjoyed on a cone. 

-Harvey Milk Honey Graham Cracker: Amazeballs. Tastes just as it sounds... a combination of graham crackers and homosexual activists.

What I've Tried:
-Salt & Pepper: Exactly how you think it would taste... just like french fries doused in salt and pepper, but without french fries

-Boccalone Prosciutto: I never thought I'd try an ice cream that tastes like ham, but here it is folks. And it's not like "oh, it's creamy and has hints of smoked ham flavor." It's exactly like you stuffed a plateful of your Christmas oinker in your mouth. It's easy to forget you're eating a dairy product.

-Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee: This one tasted a bit too much like coffee grinds for my taste, but I get why people like it. It also could have been the batch I tried. Willing to give this one another go the next time I'm in. 

-Thai Chili Lime Sorbet: That's a spicy meatball!  (for ice cream, that is)


What I Want to Try More Than Anything:
ELIVS (THE FAT YEARS)
author: Jared S.

description: This place was so delicious! Hands down artistic expression at its best in a sweet environment for cool treats!
author: J R.

description:
waiting for a gourmet meal, bearable. Waiting for ice cream, a little ridiculous...

As mentioned earlier, the wait during a busy, warm weekend day can go up to 30-45 minutes. but if you're lucky, maybe half of that. But I cannot deny the true satisfaction when I got my fat on. yes. it was so damn worth it.

Flavors:

they always have about 12-14 flavors on hand, and I've been told they change them (not all) daily. I've tried their:

Breakfast Surprise, which was surprisingly very tasty. It's a blend of corn flakes and rum. Doesn't sound appetizing? well grow a pair and give it a try cause it's def. worth the 30+ minute wait. Its reminiscent of a rum raisin with out the raisin. It's not overpoweringly sweet, and the rum flavor is not unbearable. It's just something you need to try.

Blue Bottle Coffee Company Vietnamese Coffee, sooo delicious. Perfect balance of the bitter, roasted coffee taste and the sweet milky flavors. It's 1000x better than actual Vietnamese coffee, but doesn't lose any of the true essence of what it actually is. Best flavor yet!

Highly recommend... that is, if you have time to wait. :D
author: Alex C.

description:
I'm usually not a fan of super creative ice cream joints. I always tend to leave with my taste buds more confused than happy. This place, however, has awesome flavors. The only disappointment was not being able to get a scoop of all the ones I liked during my taste test run. I decided on a scoop of the horchata-- yummy! My bro got a scoop of the secret breakfast, which I did not try because cornflakes in my ice cream did not sound appealing whatsoever. But then I tried a taste of his as we left and suddenly found myself glaring at my scoop of horchata with resentment. It's a decision I will regret until the next time I go and get a scoop for myself. It is, in fact, so good that even when his secret breakfast turned out to be the ''dirty breakfast'' (found a strand of hair.....), he couldn't find it in his heart to toss that cone away, neither did we encourage him to do so. Sigh. Instead, we dreamed of our next visit to Humphry's where hopefully we would get a clean secret breakfast. 

One star knocked for the hair and that large disturbing painting/poster on the wall of a guy with what looks like bugs crawling all over his shirt. Why?
author: S K.

description:
I'm vising from NYC, and my former roommate told me about Mitchell's and was raving about how it was the best ice cream she ever had. So I went, waited 45 minutes for my ice cream, ate it, and left. It was a pretty mediocre experience.

My other friend who lived in SF for quite some time told me about Humphry and told me I had to go before leaving. So I went, waited 5 minutes for my ice cream (only because I couldn't decide on which of the wacky flavors to choose from), ate it, LOVED IT, and left. I got the chocolate & salt (something like that), and it was super creamy and delicious. The salt was a nice hint and not overpowering.

I'd wait 45 minutes for ice cream at this place, but not again at Mitchell's.
author: London G.

description:
I tried this a few days after Bi-Rite to compare the two, and came to the conclusion that I love them both LOL

Humphrey S. has a different menu where it plays with alcohol, which I am not against hehee.

It also has outdoor seating which is a plus.

The staff was very friendly and patient with everyone.

I ordered Jesus juice and the secret breakfast.  

Jesus juice reminded me of a plum granita that I had in Italy with less ice.  It brought back some good memories :)  I would order this if I was in the mood for something in the realm of a sorbet.  

Secret breakfast-MMm bourbon, creamy ice cream, and cereal!  The bourbon was not overpowering, and the creaminess of the ice cream just wraps your tongue, and the cereal was like a little surprise each time :D

I am a fan of both and was surprised that the alcohol did not take over the ice cream.  The cone was good too!  I ate everything!
author: Michelle S.

description:
I don't know if it's because the novelty has worn off or what's going on, but I felt it wasn't the same this time.  We tried 6 flavors between 4 of us, and they were all a little too sweet compared to last time.

The single servings include 2 scoops, I think next time I'll just ask for one.

We had the secret breakfast - good but overwhelmingly sweet, the brown sugar fennel (good) the salt and pepper (OK) the Honey Wort (too sweet) the here's your dam chocolate (good)
author: Kym P.

description:
I had a slightly strange ice cream gorging experience at Humphry Slocombe the other day with friends.  We had just slithered over from Taqueria Vallarta after stuffing ourselves with cheap (and damn tasty!) tacos, seeking a little local sweetness to finish it off.   Of course, this was one of the few, rare sunny weekend days in San Francisco, so the line in front was a bit brutal.  Those sorts of lines lead to ice cream shortages, and I was distinctly deflated to hear that the vanilla (they had a specific name for it, which totally escapes me.  Frilly Foofy French Vanilla?) for my Tin Roof had just run out.

The strangeness begins when the cheery-in-the-onslaught-of-epic-Saturday-line fellow at the counter suggests instead making it with the Secret Breakfast ice cream (the aforementioned bourbon and corn flakes flavor).  Now, I initially thought it was simply bourbon-flavored ice cream, but after enjoying the custom Tin Roof, I suspect there might be a little something more in there.

First off, their sundaes are HUGE.  You should order one expecting to share it with either a friend or your invisible imaginary friend.  Secondly, I've eaten entire quarts of Ben and Jerry's to no obvious effect (save the ones my physician will inform me of in about 10 years) -- but after the sundae, I felt... high?  I hadn't had a sugar(?) rush like that in YEARS.  It makes me want to go back for more.  Do you think they put MSG in their ice cream?

Regardless of the ingredient list, I'll be back for the one-two punch of Mission Tacos and Narcotic Ice Cream very soon.
author: Adam E.

description:
I love the fact that they are Original AND Delicious. 2 Thumbs Up. My Favorite is the English Thyme. 

We arrived at 8:58pm, still a line out the door. Definitely worth it.
author: Seema H.

description:
This place is almost as good as Bi-Rite, but some of the flavors are just plain strange, not necessarily gourmet. Also, the ice cream is good but not quite mind blowingly awesome. The wait in line is about the same (40 minutes). 

Brown butter, secret breakfast, and salted chocolate are all delicious. I guess the one thing this place does have over Bi-Rite is that they're constantly changing flavors.
author: Shreya O.

description:
I'm not normally a fan of flower-flavored food--it makes me feel like I'm ingesting the contents of a Bath and Body Works store--but I taste-tested the Beet-Hibiscus ice cream and DAMN! Delicious. I was even more pleased to see a tiny tot, no more than four, expanding her young palette with a scoop of it instead of, say, cookies-n-cream. What a real San Franciscan.

I also taste-tested the Candy Cap, which is flavored with a mushroom that tastes like maple, and the Green Tea Jasmine, which is exactly what it sounds like. I can't even believe they're able to make ice cream out of this stuff!

I ended up having the Harvey Milk & Honey Graham and the Secret Breakfast, which were honestly a little difficult to tell apart visually because they're both white with little wheaty chunks of delicious in them, but delicious is the imperative word here. Really good stuff, folks. Interesting flavors, as everyone will tell you, but it's true. Also, I may have gotten a little drunk off the Secret Breakfast. Don't tell.
author: Stefanie L.

description:
3.5 stars, to be more precise, but I'd rather round up than down.

I've finally begun my quest to taste ALL of the great ice creams in SF (instead of just relying on Mitchell's). So far, Humphry has Mitchell's beat on atmosphere and general customer service. It was the ice cream itself I found most disappointing. 

I got a cup of ancho chocolate and Vietnamese coffee, and the girly friend got secret breakfast. The texture of each one was lovely and exceptionally creamy. However, across the board they were far too sweet for us, and the flavor of the ancho chocolate seemed a bit off somehow, to the point of abandoning it after a few spoonfuls. We made these choices after sampling several others, and all of them seemed overly sweet. 

Since Humphry changes the menu often I'll try again sometime...but only after I've tried Bi-Rite, Mr. & Mrs. Miscellaneous, and *everything* else on my wishlist.
author: Leslie S.

description:
Great menu of interesting flavors including salt & pepper, olive oil, and many more. Decided to settle on the blue bottle Vietnamese coffee, tasting the inspiration from strong black coffee mixed with condensed milk. 

I was hoping to try the prosciutto ice cream but they didn't have any on the day I visited. It gives me reason to go back again.
author: Brian C.

description:
After trying Bi-Rite the evening prior, Humphry Slocombe takes the lead...

Another huge line.  Worse, this one's not moving.  A couple steps in behind us and we ask if it's worth the wait.  They respond that, even though they live in the area, they don't know - the wait is too long every time they come!  Minutes pass, I peer in the window.  Why is the same group still at the counter?  Why is the server rolling her eyes?  Why, dagnabbit, why?

Because, obviously, the ice cream is so good that you must try every flavor.  And for some tourists, that apparently means trying every flavor twice and then haggling over the non-negotiable prices.  I see your pain.  Oh, my darling servers, can I "bounce" them for you?  Please?

So, Humphry has no preview menu; the flavors are simply written on the dipping cabinet.  And the line starts moving once the regulars are engaged.  And yes, it is worth the wait.  

The ice cream was decadently rich, without being overbearing.  Nor did I detect any of the iciness found at Bi-Rite.  More so, the flavors were equally creative and included more textural adventures than many of the gelaterias around do.  Humphry exudes a cool attitude that settles right into the flavors and service.  They "get it" if you get it and then it all feels right.  The touristy glaze that wore across their faces leaves when they see how excited you are about their ice cream; no longer is their service indentured.

Yes, the Secret Breakfast and Jesus Juice were that good.  And so was the caramel, coffee, and two other flavors we got (OMG, can't remember... did I pass out in some sugar coma?).  Portions were way bigger than Bi-Rite, actually second largest so far for the money!

Boy do I hate long lines, but this is one I'd stand in again and again!
author: Alan S.

description:
OMG! This is some good ice cream ya'll!

I eat ice cream once a year, yes once a year and going forth it will be here. Secret Breakfast, Bourbon & waffles? Yes Please! Blue Bottle coffee with your breakfast? Yes Please, throw it on top!

Can't wait till next year to try bacon or curry or whatever!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Yummy delicious! Too bad it's so out of the way for me, otherwise I'd stop here for dessert more often.

Salt n Pepper - weird how they make it taste salty...and peppery.
Black Sesame 
Brown Sugar Yogurt - the fresh and tangy flavors of the yogurt make this ice cream. It's creamy and not rich, making for a perfect 1 scoop wonder.

Do it.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
So i've been here many times now and can attest to why they were voted the best ice cream shop in the country. 

The first time I was here was for beer week 2011 and loved the great beerific flavors- if only I can remember. 

Must try's are the blue bottle vietnamese coffee and  the secret breakfast which are nearly always in the freezer. One of my favorites so far was the brown butter ice cream which you better believe i'm going to try to recreate. 
I'm glad I don't live closer or i'd definitely be a fatty!
author: Mike K.

description:
The words "Humphry Slocombe Fluffer Nutter" sound ridiculous when said aloud, but it is deelish!

Also, Secret Breakfast.  I'm a big fan of booze, particularly bourbon, so for me, this flavor was a no-brainer.  Yum!
author: Ms J.

description:
Delicious ice creams and interesting flavors.

Whenever I come to Humphry's I always get two scoops ($3.75) and try many samples of the 10 - 12 ice creams they have available.

This time I got the damn strawberry (fresh and sweet) and the tahitian vanilla.  One of the first times I got normal flavors compared to their balsamic caramel, thai chili lime, etc.
author: Joycelyn L.

description:
It's hard not to listen to the hype that you hear about places and that's what led me to Humphry Slocombe.  Ice cream is a real treat for me.  I barely eat it and if I do, I usually crave Bi-Rite.  This time, I had to fend off the Bi-Rite screaming sweet tooth and make my way to HS.

Clean ice cream joint, cool workers (a couple of them came out from the back with a birthday cake and started to sing happy b-day to a fellow co-worker while the patrons joined in on the singing, how cool is that?!?), and barely a line.  All pluses in my book.  Unique flavors is another plus.

So what flavors did I try?  In order of least to most favorite flavor:
1.  Tahitian vanilla:  Nothing to rave about.  Plain ol' vanilla to me.
2.  Secret breakfast:  Who would have ever thought of putting Bourbon in their ice cream?  Bonus points for that one. I liked how the corn flakes changed the texture of the smooth ice cream.
3.  Blue Bottle Vietnamese coffee:  I'm a java head and love coffee.  It was nice to taste bold coffee in an ice cream.  It was the best of both worlds.

My first experience at HS was good but I still prefer Bi-Rite to satisfy my ice cream sweet tooth.  I think Bi-Rite tastes a lot more fresh and is much more creamier.  Don't get me wrong though, I'll be back to try some of their other creative flavors.
author: Suzi K.

description:
It's that time to update my review! It's been a while since I came here and I was super excited since they have new flavor.

Tried Jesus Juice (Red Wine + Coca Cola).. it tasted different. I think only a spoonful is good but a whole scoop might be too much. I saw tried the FluffyNutter (Peanut Butter + Marshmellow) It was TOO peanut butter!

So, I stuck with Secret Breakfast and Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee. Of course these two are my fave but, they were too sweet for me! I couldn't finish it. Coffee was TOO strong but I didn't mind. I'll come here again but, I'll stick with a single scoop!
author: Lianne D.

description:
Have again: The beet sorbet was quite interesting and very good.
Not have again: The pumpkin 5 spice was good and worth tasting, but I'd rather have had some of the other flavors. By the way, when the sign says they open at noon, that is precisely the time they open. I got there early and stood outside trying to decide what to order. The workers, of course, saw me but they had lots to do to open so I don't blame them. But it would have been nice if they had opened a few minutes early...
author: Keith R.

description:
ah yeah! gourmet ice cream, a San Francisco treat! I finally got around to going here, right before I moved to Portland. I had always heard stories, seen the line, but somehow never knew exactly where it was. It is tucked away on the corner, in my personal opinion, and the afternoon I choose to finally go, there was no infamous line! yay! 
I tasted everything (no really, and they let me, and I didn't feel rude, as there was no line ;) and went with the secret breakfast. It was sooo delicious and creamy! I still would say I prefer Mitchell's, much as I do to bi-rite as well. There's just something lacking, something that makes it a bit melty. Still a delicious treat on a blustry SF afternoon!
author: Lexie L.

description:
Only been here once and tried just one flavor. It was the secret breakfast flavor, which I believe has hints of corn flakes and rum (not positive on that though). Definitely flavorful ice cream, although the rum flavor migh have stood out a bit too much. Will be going back and trying other flavors in the near future.

One cool little thing is that all their transactions are done through their ipad and reciepts are sent to your phone. Again, not too relevant but kind of cool.
author: Ajay K.

description:
I know I'm officially on the short bus, padded helmet, packed lunch complete with mushy banana and all, to Gourmandberg when it has taken me over a year to get off my ass and over to the Humph.

I've been fucking busy, OK?  I can't dedicate my life to being better than you in all that is food, alright?  I don't have time to overpay for varietal coffee, heritage salumi, intense and crazy named sandwiches covered in WAY too much sauce in the Mission, bacon apple donuts AND upscale adult ice cream, you know?

However, with that said --- Secret Breakfast, though no longer much of a secret, is kick-ass delicious.  Sweet, creamy and mos def alcoholic, it is a adult beverage thirst AND sweet tooth quencher wrapped up in a little recyclable cup complete with biodegradable spoon and 1,000 hipsters in hoodies and grey jeggings standing outside talking about how existential the Muse concert was.

Fuck, I hate* this city...

*heart
author: Rachel G.

description:
Very daring and interesting flavors here. 

I tried a scoop of all of the following (don't judge me):
Orange Clove Sorbet
Thai Chili Lime Sorbet
Kumquat Poppyseed
Secret Breakfast
Tahitian Vanilla
Bluebottle Vietnamese Coffee

I thought they were all good, but it took a few tastes to warm up to the Kumquat Poppyseed, Thai Chili Lime Sorbet and Orange Clove Sorbet.
author: Jacob P.

description:
weird and interesting!

-bourbon for breakfast? umm yes please?

-blue bottle vietnamese coffee: coffee and vietnamese= the two best things in life haha jk ;)

-olive oil gives you vitamin E :)))

-jesus juice? HALLELUJAH

tell me you're not itchin to check these crazy flavors out. your taste buds are in for an adventure
author: Maiden D.

description:
I ended up going to Humphry Slocomble Ice Cream right after I ate some $1.50 tacos at Taqueria Vallarta.

I sampled some of the ice cream and I ended up getting a scoop of funnel cake caramel in a cone. The funnel cake caramel taste so good! Customer service was great!
author: CeeCee M.

description:
i liked secret breakfast and blue bottle, but it was way too sweet.  it also tasted super fatty, i could feel the fat coagulating on the roof of my mouth.  

i'm a sucker for the secret breakfast.  it could've been amazing!  but it's still really good.
author: Erika C.

description: This is the best ice cream in the city - bar none. I basically always get Secret Breakfast + whatever happens to catch my fancy that day. Always a double scoop. Always.
author: Reed L.

description:
WOW!!  
There is so much hype about this place that I have been reluctant to try it.  Did I mention I'm a moron? The hype is well deserved. Humphry Slocombe is not to be missed. The staff was very friendly and the ice cream is delicous. Don't make the same mistake I did and get a double (which is 3 scoops), it's so rich a single is plenty. Currentley I'm nursing a belly ache and a smile. I'll be back!
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
On a hot day like today what comes to mind ? 
Ice cream !!  We decided to drive over here and see what the hype was about oh yes it's that good ! I had two small scoops - secret breakfast and blue bottle  vietnamese coffee. - divine ! 
My friend had the black sesame and limoncello sorbet also good but liked mine better 
super friendly staff nice clean place definitely will come again
author: lyn m.

description:
Super unique ice cream spot with amazingly creative flavors. In fact, it might be a little too unique. Some flavors are very "uhhhhhhh", and despite a traditional ice cream shop look, the place isn't overly kid friendly. What with the double-headed cow mounted on the wall, weird flavors, and booty-thumpin music. Not that I have kids, mind you, but it just seems a little disjointed. Pick a theme and stick with it.

Not that that really stops me from coming here, I've worked at several artisanal ice cream shops, and I'm like addicted to ice cream, and love being creative with it. I just think I'm going to have to visit the other good places for ice cream in the city before I pick a favorite.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Humphry isn't your typical ice cream parlor, they feature unique flavors that are on a daily rotation. I decided on the "Secret Breakfast" (bourbon + corn flakes) and the fluffernutter (peanut butter + marshmallow). "Secret Breakfast" happens to be one of their most popular flavors, and it's easy to see why! You can definitely taste the bourbon, but it's balanced perfectly with the smooth and creamy taste of the ice cream. The cornflake clusters gave a nice texture to the ice cream and were my favorite part!

It's popularity is apparent. There was a line and a constant flow of people coming in and out. The staff at Humphry are REALLY friendly! I usually feel a little guilty when I want to try more than one flavor, but the guy that helped me out was incredibly nice about it. Along with that, you can tell that there is a great dynamic between the staff. :)
author: Theresa T.

description:
Meh.  Overrated, seriously.  After the long wait (30 min!), this was such a let down.  Before I ordered, I tasted two flavors--Vietnamese coffee and balsamic caramel.  The balsamic caramel was really bad--I actually made a face (usually I try to be more polite).  And the Vietnamese coffee was just average.  I was seriously underwhelmed and irritated that I had wasted 30 minutes waiting for this shizz.  So, I ended up leaving with a scoop of Vietnamese coffee, but I didn't feel very good about it.  

Should have gone to Bi-Rite....
author: Sharyn F.

description:
I like the idea. The  rotating ice cream flavors are fine, but I feel as if execution could have been better.

You can taste the flavors coming through in accordance to their names however I felt like there could have been a better melding of the flavors.

Worth the try at least once in your life.
author: Winè C.

description: When I come here with my friends, I always order red hot banana ice cream. Creamy and full of banana flavor with small pieces of red hot candies. Love the combination!
author: Betty O.

description:
For all those who were disappointed in Humphry Slocombe, I think you're trying too hard to compare the businesses.  Instead, you should be enjoying them respectfully for their different flavors and different shop environment. 

Personally, I'm a big fan of HS.  I've been to HS many times, and compared to Bi-Rite, the lines are shorter and it's easier to find parking or get to.  When I think of crazy ice cream flavors, I think of Three Twins and Humphry's.  I absolutely love their unique Secret Breakfast flavor.  And the portion and the price isn't too bad.  You get the right amount of ice cream.  Also, because they change some of their flavors often, it's easy to ask them to get a sample of the new flavors.  

If you love ice cream and tasting unique, crazy flavors, definitely try Humphry's.  Don't be expecting an equivalent to Bi-Rite, as I honestly think they're unique in their own ways and in their own tastes.
author: Reb R.

description:
The ice cream at Humphry Slocombe isn't just an indulgence -- it's truly a sin. But I would GLADLY reserve my (waistline's) spot in hell for a scoop of ultra creamy, decadent Fluffernutter (marshmallow fluff + peanut butter), Chocolate Sea Salt, or my new all-time favorite scoop ever -- Secret Breakfast!

Thank god this place is so out of the way, or else I would probably have a Secret Breakfast, Lunch, and Dinner here every day. 

Other reasons why Humphry Slocombe scoops up SF's best (sorry, Bi-Rite diehards):
- HUGE portion sizes well worth $3.25 for a single scoop the size of most other ice cream shops' double scoops!
- Very generous with samples -- the personable and cheerful staff will just dole out spoonfuls of whatever they feel like with no reservations or limitations at all! (Backs up the line, but in this case, it's definitely a tradeoff worth making!)
- Wonderfully inventive, one of a kind, and unexpected but deliciously to-die-for flavors with perfectly balanced flavor profiles and a ton of character! Jesus Juice (wine+coke)? Just hilarious. And yummy. Who would think of that? And compared to the many other liquor-based ice cream flavors I've had, the alcohol in the Secret Breakfast isn't overwhelming at all, while the buttery, crunchy, but not too sweet corn flake clusters add the perfect amount of flavor and texture to highlight the richness and sweetness of bourbon.
author: Cam Y.

description:
for some reason, I expected the decor to be more subversive. I blame the NYTimes. I tend to describe this place to friends as Bi-Rite on crack.

there's not much more to be said about this place that has already been said. 

Secret Breakfast is AMAZING, very boozy.

1 scoop is $2.75

I suppose if we're doing comparisons
1. scoops (LA)
2. humphrey slocombe (SF)
3. bi-rite (SF)
4. toscannini (Boston)

sorry. LA still wins but mostly on the price, portion point, and their many dairy-free and vegan flavors (I'm not a vegan but they're actually really tasty). I like HS's sense of humor when it comes to creating flavors though (Jesus Juice anyone? It's tasty too). That's something it beats both ice cream shops in. 

oh! and HS sells pints. That's nice.

CASH ONLY. CASH ONLY
author: Andrea L.

description: Oh, Secret Breakfast! If only I could keep it a secret and have all of it for myself (omnononom). Humphry Slocombe is definitely one of the best icecream places in SF. They have very unique flavours. It is a matter of individual tastes and preferences - but I consider secret breakfast to be the absolutely best! They give you a spoonful to try whatever flavours you're interested in so you will not end up with two scoops of disappointment. The place is really tiny but cute. And kudos for using reusable spoons for tasting samples - really considerate of the environment!
author: Yuliya B.

description:
My favorite ice cream place in the bay area! The only downside is it's in San Francisco which means there's no parking! The place is located in the vibrant latin cultural Mission district.

I ordered two scoops, 1 of the secret breakfast and 1 of the vietnamese coffee. OMG TO DIE FOR! The secret breakfast is a bourbon flavored ice cream with cornflakes. And the ice cream really does taste like the strong vietnamese coffee.

The line was fairly lengthy but it's only long because people are tasting and trying to make up their minds. I so want to go back but the only thing that is preventing me to do so is the lack of parking!
author: Hayden P.

description:
It's a slow Tuesday and I'm in need of a sugar pick-me-up. Luckily it's Farmers market at the Ferry Building. I stop by their booth and most days I get there so late that the Breakfast Special is already sold out. But I went early and snagged a half a pint for $5, which is a hefty price. But it's worth it for treat-of-the-week for me. 

It was good and liked the crunch corn flakes but not crazy about the Bourbon flavor. The texture was creamy and not too sweet. I must try the Blue Bottle coffee flavor next time.
author: Candace F.

description:
So I pretty much gave up sugar and this is were I go to be bad and cheat once in a while... my kinda sorta crack den so to speak.

I had to have this Secret Breakfast that I've been hearing so much about, made with cornflakes and bourbon (the breakfast of champions), but it's ok to come here and not feel like a lush since they open when the clock strikes noon. I mean, technically you don't have a drinking problem as long as you don't drink before noon, right?

Amazing ice cream!!!
author: Thömas F.

description:
This was our group's conversation outside of Humphry Slocumbe ---

"Michael: I'm a writer too.
Me: Really. What did you write?
 
Michael: Psalm eighty-five. It wasn't called Psalm   
when I wrote it.  I didn't know they'd be collected and numbered.   
 
Michael: That was around the time I invented standing in line waiting for Ice Cream.   
 
Me: You invented standing in line waiting for Ice Cream?
Michael: Before everybody milled around Harrison & 24th. It was a mess.  So one day I said, "Why not make a line for ice cream?"
 
Me: For what?
Michael: To get in.
   
Rory: Ask him what you want to know.
Me: What do I want to know?
Rory: He wants to know why angels don't solve big problems.

ME: That is what I want to know. Why don't angels...
...solve big problems?

Michael: You can't change the nature of the world.

Rory: What can you do?

Michael: Small miracles, like inventing Secret Breakfast & Olive Oil Ice Cream."

--as paraphrased from the motion picture, Michael (1996)
author: Luke H.

description:
Be prepared for a line, non traditional ice cream flavors,  lots of sampling, all  for a very cheap price. 

My friend and I were on our way to the street food fair festival and saw this crazy line that wrapped around the entire store. I swear there was about 100 people in line, and it was for ice cream! Either this has to be the best ice cream in the world or they slip a lil crack in that ice cream.

We decided to check it out hoping the line would be shorter after the festival and it was. Even then we had to wait 40 minutes in line. The longest I have ever waited for ice cream! 

When we finally got to the front, I realized what the hold up was; people sampling the different flavors. I, myself tried about 4 flavors before I finally selected my choices. I had a double scoop over a huge waffle cone of the vietnamese coffee and the graham cracker. They gave me 2 heaping scoops of ice cream and I havent had ice cream ever since. It was ice cream overload but definately one of the best ice creams I had for a while.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
"Where's the corn flake?" I asked as I was eating the Secret Breakfast. 

That and the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee were delicious flavors. 

Still have the feel that it's a Bi-Rite rip off but with more strange flavors. 

And why is it SO HOT for an ice cream place? 

Most importantly, restroom available!
author: Kenny L.

description: I have a penchant for all things ice cream! I enjoy getting a scoop from Humphry Slocombe because there are always delicious flavor ideas to choose from. Secret Breakfast (bourbon with crunchy cereal pieces), Olive Oil, Brown Butter (especially delectable), among others. Great quality, and flavors.
author: K R.

description:
I first heard of Humphry's when the cooking channel featured it serving bacon ice cream.  When I finally got there, it wasn't on their menu and that's when I saw they have a menu that rotates with what's available or in season to keep with using the most freshest ingredients.

What's good is the Secret Breakfast and Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee.

If you're adventurous for flavor and want to try something different from your good ol' rocky road - try Humphry's.
author: JJAMZ C.

description: My friend was craving ice cream one day and as a full supporter of ice cream all day, every day, I naturally joined her.  She brought me to Humphry Slocombe and I was pleasantly surprised.  I have only lived in SF for a little over a year and have yet to venture around to find great little places like this.  I was very intrigued by the flavors offered at the time and after sampling the Blue Bottle and Olive Oil I went with the Candied Ginger.  So good and just the right amount.  My friend had the Secret Breakfast which I really liked as well.  I definitely find myself craving more from time to time.
author: Kristin P.

description: I finally got to go here after waiting for so long and hyping it up in my head and you know what?  It didn't disappoint.  With quirky unique flavors not found in other places, this place seems like it would be a haven for hipsters, but it really is much, much more than that.  The Salt and Pepper flavor is interesting and unexpectedly, I really liked it, but it's such a strong presence that I don't think I'd be able to handle a whole scoop of it.  The Vietnamese Blue Bottle Coffee is really pleasing especially for coffee lovers, but not as unique as their other flavors.  The Secret Breakfast is a whiskey lover's dream.  The ice cream isn't shy with the whiskey and the cornflakes add a nice sweetness and crunch.  Definitely would come back here and try more flavors.
author: Christine W.

description:
If Ben & Jerry's had a younger brother with a superiority complex, he's Humphry Slocumbe.

If you're looking for your typical run of the mill flavors, look elsewhere. You won't find any classic flavors here. While seemingly content to let the other ice cream shops do their thing, this place has carved its own niche as the ice cream shop that tries to push the boundaries of conventional flavors. 

As the Lady Gaga of ice cream parlors (if you will), they dare to combine Red Hots and Banana, Prosciutto and Cream, Bourbon and Corn Flakes, and Pepper and Mint (to name a few). Some may say the flavors are only done for pure shock value and novelty, while others will may find a genuine artistic and culinary value to it. Whatever it is, they've got the city a buzzin'. Count me amongst one of their fans.
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
I want some blue bottle Ice cream! its the best, but then again Im a coffee freak.
This isn't your everyday ice cream shop. They have Ice cream flavors you've never heard of but I've never got a complain from everyone that I have taken there, Oh and its kid approved My little man loved it!
author: Francisco R.

description: Nothing ordinary about the ice cream in this shop. Two scoops, Vietnamese Blue Bottle Coffee + Sesame, on after a hot day in the city hit the spot. The coffee ice cream was really flavorful and strong, while the sesame tasted like the candy I used to eat as a kid. Can't wait to try the other flavors.
author: Theresa D.

description:
They make ice cream out of bourbon and cornflakes y'all, they are NOT messing around.

Get thee there now.
author: Christine K.

description:
I crave the ice cream from Humphry Slocome's. They deserve five stars for their creativity and recipe quality.

Loved the Fluffer Nutter (peanut butter marshmallow goodness)! Brown butter and Harvey Milk with graham cracker pieces are also scrumptious. Did I also mention their Coconut flavor? Actually, during my two trips there, I liked all the flavors. Next time, I will go for the Secret Breakfast.

They've got a cute cow theme going on and aside from the crowds, they're pretty laid back. It would, however, be nice if they posted their current flavors at the door since there's almost no time to decide on your flavor(s) when you get to the front.

Also, I noticed they give you more than Bi-Rite does for the same price/scoop. So, you'll get a better value at Humphry Slocumb.

Don't forget: cash only!
author: Kelly T.

description: The ice cream flavors here are definitely not your average flavors.  Just reading the creative, funky flavor labels on the glass above the tubs of ice cream defintely makes you want to try all of em.  I sampled Jesus Juice (red wine + cola) and Fluffer Nutter (peanut butter + marshmallows).  Get Jesus Juice if you like red wine and get fluffer nutter if you're a peanut butter fan.  Both flavors are really intense.  I ended up ordering a cup of Secret Breakfast (corn flakes + bourbon) which I thought was also pretty darn good.  You definitely get that bourbon flavor but the best part is when you get a chunk of cornflakes that almost tastes like toffee.  Service is cool and there's indoor and outdoor seating as well.  Drinking water and a bathroom is available too.
author: Maya S.

description:
Order the Secret Breakfast! 

They let you sample every flavor and are very nice about it.  And the flavors are richer than Bi-Rite.  I love Bi-Rite, but to me richer = better.
author: K V.

description:
Disclaimer: I'm not a hipster, so I can't really appreciate the irony of eating gross food.

I came here with a bunch of people, and between the group sampled most of the flavors. These flavors were interesting, but not tasty. Call me crazy, but I want my ice cream to taste good. 

And since when has the Mission been filled with 20 year olds in skinny jeans?
author: Hayley L.

description: Secret Breakfast, Grapefruit, Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee. AAAHHHHHHH!!!!!!! Why did I ever move out of San Francisco?!?!?!?!?!
author: Suany W.

description:
Friend highly recommended this place and took us here to give it a shot. The bf Richard R and I split 4 scoops with 4 different flavors--hey, what can I say? We love variety. We tried:
 
Secret Breakfast--consists of Bourbon flavor and Corn flakes--yumm. I love the crunchy consistency of the Corn flakes in the ice cream but the flavor of Bourbon I wasn't TOO excited about. This flavor is definitely worth a try though if you stop by.
 
Tahitian Vanilla--just tasted like regular vanilla to me but we matched it with the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee ice cream, which goes together really well. 
 
Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee--I personally loooove coffee ice creams...Jamocha, Espresso, anything coffee in ice cream I'm willing to give a go J so this one was good for me.
 
FlufferNutter--consists of Marshmallow and Peanut Butter--blech (boyfriends choice). I'm not a fan of peanut butter...and I don't really like marshmallow that much either...it was definitely an interesting ice cream flavor to try though! The ice cream has texture like really fine peanut butter (where there are still little teeny tiny bits of peanuts) at the same time it was kind of thick and creamy like marshmallows. 
 
It looks like they probably switch flavors daily or something because when you go on their website they show a bunch of other flavors that they have.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I LOVE YOU WEIRD ICE CREAM FLAVORS!!!!!!

Humphry's is awesome awesome awesome and I don't know how I've gone this long without their ice cream! I personally like it better than Bi-Rite, maybe because their flavors seem more crazy cool!

I got one of the more popular flavors, Secret Breakfast! Bourbon & corn flakes?! HECK YEAH! Hmm if only they could take this flavor and turn it into a dry cereal! I'd eat it every day, all hours!

I admit that all their flavors aren't that yummy (uhh mint chip pepper), but I applaud Humphry's for being creative enough to come up with the unique combos! There are probably over 25 different flavors, but they rotate them each day, so I think there's only about 10-12 flavors available. 

The kids size (1 scoop) is quite generous and it's not expensive either ($2.95!)  Another great thing is that there is no extra charge for a cone!!! Sweet! 

I'll definitely make another trip out here because I have yet to try peanut butter curry and cucumber ice milk! Or strawberry candied jalapeno!! :)
author: Kei H.

description: The flavors are very interesting, definitely something to go and try. But for the actual quality and taste of the ice cream...not that amazing. It is not a place to go for rich and creamy ice cream.
author: Charles Z.

description:
I really really wanted to like this place.  I am probably the most daring person to try something--actually anything food related.  I went here yesterday with my sister and niece and we got a 3 scoop-brown butter, blue bottle vietnamese coffee and hot chocolate with smoked salt.  My niece-who btw is only 5 years old-got 1 scoop of milk chocolate passion fruit.  

My niece did not like the milk chocolate passion fruit and so we gave her the hot chocolate with smoked salt which she enjoyed but I think it was because it tasted like regular chocolate to her.  The aftertaste of the passion fruit was not to her liking.  But trust me when I say this, my niece has a interesting pallet for a 5 year old.  Her favorite fruit since she was 4 is a pomegranate...and how many 5 year olds do you know even eat and like pomegranates?  I kind of liked the milk chocolate passion fruit but it was just way to much after a while! 

The brown butter was  a disappointment and my sister agrees.  It has bits of butter??? I think it was just a little much.  I actually thought brown butter was going to be a "safe" flavor because brown butter is brown butter...its delicious!  I was wrong...I think it was a total fail for them to have those bits in.

Blue bottle vietnamese coffee was actually enjoyable and I can't say anything bad about it.

All in all....I liked the hot chocolate with smoked salt the best!  The ice cream was very rich and probably full of cream which is how ice cream is suppose to be but quite honestly, I really think that doing the gourmet style ice cream is scary.  But maybe that is just me being biased because the other reviewers rave about this place.  

Wait one last thing....LARD caramels and DUCK FAT pecan pie? WOW you are really testing the waters....LOL at least we know what is in it!  I think I will stick to good ole' Mitchells and Bi-Rite creamery!
author: Mary-Anne C.

description: I was excited to go to Humphrys because I have heard so many good things about it being the best ice cream in the city and blah blah blah. However, I was not so impressed with their flavors or even the texture of the ice cream. Most of the flavors were too weird to even want to try (Salt and Pepper or Pepper and Mint--why? why? why?) and the flavor that I got (rum and raisin) was good but not spectacular. The texture of the ice cream wasn't creamy at all but was more icy and almost hurt my tongue while I was eating it. Maybe thats how some people like their ice cream but it wasn't for me.
author: Melanie M.

description:
Continuing on our decadent food excursion, my friend and I decided to hang out in the Mission and stop by HSIC.

I tried: 

-Blue Bottle Vietnamese Ice Coffee - This was just as strong as the normal VIC.  Great Coffee flavor and just the right amount of sweetness to counter.

-Thai Chili - SAY WHAT?  This seriously tasted like a chili/basil sauce from a Thai dish... (I hate to say this, but 'too' much flavor)!  Am i going to food-hell now? LOL

-Dreamcicle-Creamcicle.  Tangerine and cream.  I like the concept and the sophisticated flavors, but compared to all the other flavors here it just fell a little short.  If you like super subtle this is the way to go though.

-Secret Breakfast ( Hennessy andCornflakes)  OH WHAT?  Henna-Henn!!!  I love me some Henn, but this was a bit over the top.  The cognac flavor overpowered the overall balance of what could have been a decent pairing.

Next time I hope they have the Prosciutto or Foie Fras.

Great place for the flavor-junkies!  So much to choose from, and every bite on every scoop was like a fireworks show of flavor!
author: Anthony L.

description:
Overrated, Over-hyped.

After standing in line for 15+ minutes we decided to try a few flavors before deciding what to get.  The first red flag was that only one or two of the flavors actually *sounded* appealing.  I'm all for being inventive and adventurous, but there are just some things that should not be used to flavor ice cream....  I would never drink red wine and coke mixed together, and the same concoction as an ice cream (Jesus Juice) was gross.  The Secret Cereal made of bourbon and cornflakes...also yucky.   The tempting looking chocolate ice cream was ruined by the addition of too much smoked sea salt.  I refused to try the Proscuitto ice cream, I mean come on, really?

I ended up with a Pink Grapefruit sorbet that after a few bites was bitter and watery, and the Tahitian Vanilla which was OK but certainly not worth waiting 15+ minutes in line for.
