I tried the secret breakfast, vietnamese coffee, malted milk chocolate, tahitian vanilla, peanut butter chocolate and salt and pepper.  I think any basic ice cream place should have an amazing vanilla and chocolate to start off.  I did not like either flavor.  The vietnamese coffee flavor was decent as well as the peanut butter chocolate which was what I ended up getting.  The salt and pepper is exactly what you imagine it tasting like (while making that sour face.) My bf thought the ice cream was way too salty and he for sure wasn't a fan.  The workers weren't the friendliest but the portion sizes were fair.  Like I said, if you're looking for unheard of flavors, you'll find it here and probably enjoy it, but I think I'll stick to ice cream flavors that don't taste like bourbon.
author: Trini T.

description:
Thanks to Humphrey's Twitter account - http://twitter.com/humphryslocombe - , I can now keep up with the flavors they have. I can't decide if this is a good or bad thing because I'm getting fat. 

and that watermelon wheat beer ice cream is GOLD.
author: Alicia V.

description:
Same ol' good service and crazy inventive ice cream.  Okay, I admit I've cringed each time I've watched somebody on Iron Chef America make some meat ice-cream, but I swear to Buddha that their Boccalone flavour mixed with their salt+pepper went together perfectamente!

My friend J had the Blue Bottle Vietnamese, DAMN!  I had a little bit of ice cream envy.
author: Aimee B.

description:
If there was a ranking of ice cream places in San Francisco - chains such as Baskin Robbins don't qualify - Humphrey Slocombe would probably rank within the top 10. As to where in the top 10, that would place, that depends on the rater's taste preference. HS specializes in interesting flavor combinations - I'm serious about that description. Want salt and pepper ice cream? Got it. Thought oolong was a tea? Wrong, it's also a flavor. I think the simplest ice cream is Blue Bottle Vietnamese coffee, which by the way is delicious; I now feel the need to try Blue Bottle coffee. I also suggest the balsamic caramel ice cream. It does a twist to caramel the same as Bi-rite did, only Bi-rite is salted caramel, which I prefer a bit more. 

Why the 3 stars as opposed to 4 or 5? I think the combinations get a bit too weird for me. I understand that being in SF, I should be proud that a place serves foie gras ice cream but I guess I am traditional enough that I want flavors that somewhat resemble classic flavors. Avocado ice cream (from Mitchell's) is about as far off the beaten path as I go. I also took off a star because while the website lists quite a few flavors, they don't serve all of those at once. In fact, there are some that I've never seen before. They only have about 8 flavors per day. =(
author: Gwen L.

description:
So my wonder twin & I decide we want something sweet; head down to Humphrey Slocombe to satisfy our sweet teeth, and now I can't stop thinking about their ice cream. Great! Just what I need while i'm on my so called diet (which should be called a non-existant diet or perhaps not be called a diet at all because let's face it, I love to eat). 
This place is awesome with their ice cream parlor-like table & red swivel chairs outlooking the street. You can now see the towns crackheads, hipsters & pimps walking down the street while you enjoy your ice cream cone. And I can totally say this since I am a crackheaded hipster pimp myself. And yes, i'm totally playing. So more about the decor, they have Campbell's soup paintings with a couple of their ice cream flavors as soup flavors (see photos or just visit), and there's an interesting painting of a wrestler or burgler wearing a mask, who looks like he's about to grab someone out their car! I found these paintings, which are the only paintings here, to be very fun. They have a water dispenser next to a bunch of stacked plastic cups which is nice because I know I love a drink of water when i'm having ice cream. They have a bathroom which is convinent. And last but not least, they have a few bamboo plants spread out in their little store. As you can see, the decor isn't fancy at all, but it doesn't have to be because the ice cream is absolutely scrumptious! I mean, after having some, I thought, this place is perfect. The ice cream was wild & the decor matched it all of a sudden. I'd say the one word to describe this place is unique. 
After sampling practically everything in the case with their tiny cute spoons, I decided on a scoop of Harvey Milk & Honey and a scoop of their famous Secret Breakfast. The Harvey Milk & Honey is the one I keep thinking about :) It tastes of sweet honey that explodes in your mouth, sweet creamy vanilla ice cream & chewy hunks of honeycomb (i think, whatever it is, it's heaven). Ahhhhhh, now that my mouth is watering.... 
The Secret Breakfast is of course vanilla ice cream, frosted flakes & bourbon, and I have to say I'd love to have this for breakfast any day. The bourbon is really shocking at first lick.... tantalizing your tastebuds, then, you learn to enjoy it. So much that you wonder why it's gone so fast. Well that's in my case. Basically, I was excited to go to Humphrey Slocombe for the very first time (thanks to my wonder twin who popped my Humphrey Slocombe cherry!) and I was very pleased. 
It's not the same ol' rocky road, strawberry, or caramel type flavors, but Szechaun Strawberry, Cayenne Canteloupe, Salt and Pepper, Foie Gras, White Chocolate Lavener, and other awesome flavors. I've tried two so far and want to try them all ;)  I never scream for ice cream but I certainly do now. Like really, I'm literally screaming for ice cream, so I have to go. Bye yall ;)
author: Amethyst Popkiss A.

description: I wasn't a fan of the Secret Breakfast. The bourbon was too overpowering for me. I ended up with Peanut Butter Curry, Tahitian Vanilla, and Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee. Coffee was my favorite, and vanilla my least. Vanilla got lost in the mix with the other, stronger flavors. Peanut butter curry was good, but in moderation. Their cookies, however, were amazingly delicious- crispy on the outside, chewy on the inside, and sweet all around. Both Humphry and Bi-Rite definitely know how to make high quality ice cream, but Bi-Rite has better flavors, so I'd stick with them.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Humphry Slocombe gets my vote for creative flavors that are true to the taste of the ingredients encompassed.  This past weekend I tried the Banana Rum and Peanut Butter Curry.  Peanut Butter Curry may sound a bit odd; however, somehow the peanut butter and curry go together well as an ice cream flavor.  Yet, I must make note the curry is quite strong (just like it tastes when eating Indian food) and not as sweet as one may like.  The ice cream is creamy and quickly melts in your mouth.

However, if you like a caramel or coconut ice cream, I would recommend trying Bi-Rite as their flavors may cure your ice cream craving or sweet tooth as they are more true to traditional sweet flavors with a few unique ones of their own (salted carmel).
author: Caroline Q.

description:
Calm, new, sparse ice cream shop with interesting flavors. 

After doing research, I stopped at Humphry Slocombe and tried a scoop of olive oil ice cream... after having a sample spoon to see what I was getting into. The olive oil scoop was flavorful, the dairy and ingredients were balanced, and the overall taste was very good. The flavor was sweet- but not overly- and exhibited how something fatty and complex can be made to taste great in another usage. 

I want to come back when I am visiting and try other flavors... maybe a coffee flavor next time- or that secret breakfast everyone is talking about... 

FYI's~ 
* Only had about 6-ish flavors available when I was there- mostly a little odd 
* Easy to find off of 24th 
* Regular- higher end ice cream prices- a scoop's under $3? 
* They let you taste little samples- just ask 
* Sell cute postcards and a tiny sampling of knick knacks 
* Only a few window stool seats available inside
author: Natalie W.

description:
So far, this is my favorite ice cream in SF, though I know I have a lot more to try.

The line wasn't quite as long as the other popular mission ice cream spot *cough* bi-rite *cough*. I also thought that the ice cream options were slightly better. 

I had the Secret Breakfast which contains corn flakes and bobbin (win win), along with the blue bottle coffee. I had these scoops in a cone because I am not a fan of all of that cup business.

There are few things more refreshing on a hot day in the mission than sitting on the corner of Harrison and 24th eating this stuff.
author: Eric G.

description:
Humphry's isn't like your typical ice cream shop.  They have the most unique flavors that you won't find anywhere else.  They can range from something simple as Tahitian Vanilla to Peanut Butter Curry (weird right?).  Each day their flavors change so you never know what flavors they'll have.  But one thing they always have is their Secret Breakfast.  By far this is my favorite, which is made of cornflakes and bourbon. Yumm....There's something about this flavor that makes me come back for it all the time. BUT don't over do this flavor as one time I got 2 scoops of Secret Breakfast and I was tired of it after my first scoop =/.  

The great thing about this place is you can sample as many flavors as you want before making a decision.  I do recommend trying it first before ordering.  Although the name of the ice cream sounds good or interesting, but once it gets in your mouth it can be a totally different than what you expected.  Trust me I've had friends who've done that and ended up not liking it.  

Also, they update their flavors for the day on Twitter so you might want to follow them to be hin the know =).
author: Bertie Y.

description:
Had the Balsamic Caramel. They were out of a lot of flavors, but there was no line on a Thursday night after 8 pm. We just walked right up, had a taste, and then ordered. It was good, not too sweet. Service was friendly and polite while still being very efficient.

This place may be a little overhyped (I read the whole long article in the NY Times), but I don't eat that much ice cream these days anyway. Once in a while, nice to know this place is there for a non-boring dessert treat. And, so far I don't have any of that nasty post-ice-cream yucky feeling. Maybe because this ice cream isn't full of preservatives? Hmm.
author: Sam Z.

description: Oh gosh.. Where do I start? I would have to say that the Vietnamese Coffee Ice Cream is soo dang close to the real thing! Just order this and enjoy it on a hot Summer day! YUMMM!
author: Anne T.

description:
Boutique ice cream like you would not believe.  Seriously, like way out there: balsamic caramel, foie gras, McEvoy olive oil...it goes on.  Very rich, but very, very tasty, and highly recommended.

The shop is cute, the staff is mad friendly, tasters are given out freely since the flavors are so intriguing, and there's some nice seating out front.  Don't worry, the line moves pretty quick.
author: Oliver N.

description: I think I am tired of Humphry Slocombe Ice Cream already. I came here yesterday and got the Secret B and the Red Hot Banana. I don't know why but it was a badddd combo! May be I should have sticked to the Blue Bottle Viet Coffee. Because the secret b and the red hot banana were OVERLY sweet and it wasn't good! I wanted to throw the whole thing away but I didn't want to waste food so I just finished it..but blahhh. I was thinking about buying a whole pint, but thank god I didn't..
author: Janet Z.

description:
The ice cream itself is okay but not great. It is all about the exotic ingredients/combinations that they put into the ice cream. 

Special breakfast is a common favorite and worth trying. My biggest advice is to SAMPLE everything before buying it. Once I winged it got Jesus Juice without sampling it first. I ended up pushing the Jesus Juice scoop into the trash can because it was so nasty. My friend refused to eat it too because she thought it was gross too. But some people like Jesus Juice so it all depends on your taste preferences. But overall, the flavors are hit-or-miss so make sure you sample before you decide!

Although I give Humphry Slocombe credit for their innovative flavors, Mitchell's is the best ice cream shop in the neighborhood.
author: Alex P.

description:
I LOVE this place. The first time we went, there was a line around the block, which seemed a bit crazy to me. We ate the ice cream (a beet flavored one... yum), loved it, but still weren't sure if it was worth waiting 30 minutes. The NEXT time we went, there was NO line... we walked right up to the counter, sampled some flavors (they'll let you try almost all of them, which is awesome) and ordered. This second experience (with little to no line) made me LOVE this place. We got the Vietnamese Coffee (amazing!) and the Bourbon with Corn Flakes (double amazing). If I could eat this every day without my waistline growing, I would. 

Definitely try the unusual flavors. That's what they're known for.
author: Shannon M.

description: This place is so creative and thought-provoking it's almost intellectual. I love how it always surprises and delights my palate and my sense of humor.
author: George L.

description: I went here last Sunday with a few of my girlfriends. There were five of us, and only one of my friends had tried this place before. I had a scoop of the Blue Bottle coffee ice cream. It was okay. I wish it had a stronger coffee taste. I don't know if I will come here again. I'll stick to Bi-Rite and Mitchell's for now.
author: Kayla V.

description:
Humphry Slocombe was a unique experience.  They offer a number of novel flavors you wouldn't expect at an ice cream shop.  For instance, I never expected to try prosciutto ice cream before (that was a bizarre experience, still not sure what happened there).  I came for the Secret Breakfast, but ended up trying some of the other flavors.  Other than the Boccalone Prosciutto, I really enjoyed everything I tried. 

My favorite was probably the Vietnamese Coffee.  Super strong, but delicious.  I also never thought I'd say something like this, but I really enjoyed the Jesus Juice. Red wine and coke sorbet. Soooo good.  The carrot mango was refreshing and the honey thyme was also solid ice cream.  As for the Secret Breakfast? I liked it, but all I could taste was the alcohol.  It's very strong, but I'd still recommend it. It was delish.

In the end, it was good ice cream and a unique experience and I'd love to come back another time to try some of their other flavors.
author: Alea G.

description:
I finally went to Humphry Slocombe--after waiting three weeks to go. The first attempt they were closed for a private event, the second time I only had plastic and no paper...the third time was definitely the charm.

Of course, I went with the bf and the bff on a cold but sunny and bright Sunday right after taco truck tacos and right before looking at some lofts/condos. I tried seven flavors...yes...seven.

Salt and Pepper: very salt and peppery. If they had fried egg flavored ice cream, I would have salt and pepper with it.

McEvoy Olive Oil: surprisingly tastes like olive oil. The guys didn't really like it much, but it was different and I love different!

Malted Dulce de Leche: don't be fooled. It is not like Haagen Daaz's or Ciao Bella's Dulce de Leche. It is like Dulce de Leche and sour cream mixed together. I don't know how I feel about it, but I was sad that I couldn't finish it. 

Dreamsicle: has real oranges in it.

Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffeee: definitely a very strong coffee and sweet condensed milk taste. It was the hardest and coldest ice cream. The other ice cream flavors were soft and more like gelato.

Fudgsicle: very rich chocolaty taste and has the exact consistency of a real fudgsicle. You know...a quarter icy, the rest ice creamy.

Balsamic Caramel: my favorite!!! So delightful in my mouth!!! It was very creamy with the strong flavor of caramel. Oh. My. Goodness. I think I want some more for today.

I will definitely come back to try the other flavors. I was sad that they didn't have Red Hot Banana, but maybe they will the next time around.
author: Maureen B.

description: Favorite flavors(in no particular order): oolong tea, I have a dreamsicle, strawberry margarita, Eton mess, chocolate smoked salt, and OF COURSE, secret breakfast.
author: Sofia O.

description: Riding this recent heat wave really makes me want to eat ice cream for every meal. I am a huge fan of bi rite but I just can't handle that long line especially when I'm jonesing for ice cream on a hot day. Took a walk over to humphry slocombes where there was surprisingly no line. That was nice because then we were able to sample some interesting flavors. I tried prosciutto which was actually pretty delicious but there were just too many other good flavors to turn up. Ended up with a scoop of secret breakfast (had to) and pumpkin spice. Amazing - both - but the secret breakfast needed more cornflakes and was pretty soupy compared to the pumpkin. I will be back to try goat cheese and fig. Well done.
author: Katie P.

description:
Food: 

As far as I'm concerned, the best ice cream you can get in the city.  I recommend getting some friends together and trying as many flavors as you can to figure out which ones are winners (Secret Breakfast, Jesus Juice, Thai Chili) and losers (Balsamic Caramel yechhhh) (that's just my personal opinion!)

And hellllloooooo bacon peanut brittle. Incredible.

Service:

Fast and friendly.  They let you taste whatever you want.  It will behoove you to follow them on Twitter/Facebook to see what new flavors they are serving each day - and get there early!  I wanted to bring some Brown Butter ice cream home for my roommate, but got there around 6pm and they said they couldn't even give me a 1/2 a pint so everyone else could sample it - which I totally understand.  And you can't beat saying the secret phrase on Monday to get free chocolate or butterscotch toppings!
author: Kat M.

description: Delicious ice cream.  Great for a busy Friday after all week's work is done!
author: Diego V.

description: Excellent ice cream shop with unique flavors.  My favorites are the Vietnamese coffee and secret breakfast, though you can't really go wrong with any of them.  The more popular ones may run out near the end of the day though, so keep an open mind and be sure to explore some of the other options.
author: Josh Q.

description: I love this place! Some of my favorites are the secret breakfast (bourbon and cornflakes) and Harvey Milk & Honey Graham. I really wish this place had the prosciutto ice cream, which I heard about on the Food Network. Other than that, they have different different flavors everyday. The ice cream I didn't like was the Strawberry Szechuan, the guy told me it was tart, but it taste like mint on overload. I won't be getting that one again.
author: Jeanie Ann D.

description:
Inner monologue of Mari C upon discovering the installation of a new ice cream shop a block from home:

Oooooh ICE CREAM! 

What's with their sign? No name? Just "ice cream" in American Typewriter? Who do they think they are?

They're going for a sleek-modern-minimalist look... SO not jiving with the local Mission flavor.

Pssshh. Yuppie alert, all systems set to "avoid."

[insert Yelp research, friend recommendations, and 12 mile line outside]

Ohhhhhkayyyyy, well its a sunny day and I GUESS I'll give it a chance.

[seven samples and a smile later] Alright, Slocombe.  You win this round.  I still don't like your style, but the creamies were definitely interesting and enjoyable.
author: Mari C.

description:
Definitely "Secret Breakfast" and "Vietnamese Coffee".  Before I even asked the guy who helped us out which one was the winners, I already picked them out.  

I tried a taste of the milk chocolate passion fruit, but it was just a little too weird for me at the time.  i needed something along the lines of dessert seeing that i had just had a hearty meal at Brickhouse.

The area here is all new to me.  i don't think I've ever stepped foot on 24th St and Harrison.  But the shop is really nice and I was really happy with the selection I made.  I still can't quite put my finger on what Secret Breakfast tastes like but it has something to do with maple syrup I bet.  And for the Vietnamese coffee...who knew how accurate ice cream can taste just like it.  

Def gotta come back.  And the prices are so cheap.  $2-3 for a cup.  I'm curious about the Salt n Peppa one too.
author: Vincent K.

description: The line was out the door when we went here! For the long wait, I don't think the ice cream was worth it. We had the famed secret breakfast, and although it was good, it didn't live up to all the hullabaloo. They have some really weird flavors, so maybe if you like creatively strange ice cream, come here.
author: Catherine N.

description:
Those in search of some innocent cookies-and-cream oughta look elsewhere. Humphry Slocombe has weird yet surprisingly good flavors, including brown butter, olive oil, and their most popular, Secret Breakfast (bourbon and cornflakes), which I did not try.

Bi-Rite is obviously a huge hit with ice cream aficionados in the Mission, but HS is next on the list to try. 

Get the almond crunch topping! Everything goes up a notch with a little CRUNCH.

Friendly staff, decent prices, yadda yadda yadda. Just go.
author: Tanya S.

description: It's the best thing going! No other ice cream, potentially in the world, can compare. Boom, shaka-laka.
author: Healey C.

description:
Pretty affordable, and very good.  I've had this place bookmarked for a while, so I was really excited when a friend took me here by chance.  The ice-cream itself was top rate and the line moved quickly.  I've never held "cash only" against an ice cream parlor, so no stars subtracted for that.  You should certainly make the effort to try Humphry Slocombe, but it might not become your go to for gourmet ice-cream.  If you are trying to decide between HS and Bi-Rite, it would be entirely legit to go to which ever is closer. 

The only other note I have for HS--and I fully realize that this won't be an issue for most sane people--is an irritation that is once again discursive.  I think some "Joshua Generation" type person might gawk at their flavor combinations, but do those people frequent Harrison and 24th?  I feel like we are at a point where not only do we all know that balsamic describes a vinegar, we're also all perfectly accustomed to associating it with dessert.  They write things next to their flavors like, "Yeah, we went there."  And I'm once again staring at a business asking, "you know where you are, right?"  I think they would present themselves better if they just said, "here's some chocolate curry ice cream," rather than, "Oh snap, chocolate and curry? No we didn't! " 

But that doesn't even factor into the 4 not 5 star final verdict.  To get to 5 stars they need to not run out of flavors, especially when I was there at 3:30-ish in the afternoon on a Saturday.  I appreciate "small batch" and freshness, but ice cream is one of those foods that "freezes beautifully" for at least a couple of days.  Make larger batches...stop running out of product in the middle of the day...get to 5 stars. Simple.
author: Luke M.

description:
I'd say it's all hype and that it's just ice cream, but it really is like nothing you've ever tasted before.  

I will say that I'm not as fond of the Secret Breakfast as many others are.  I love my alcohol as much as the next AA member, but I just don't think it belongs in a frozen dessert.  (The cornflakes are the best part of that concoction, I think.)  Oddly enough, my favorite flavors were the strange and unique, Salt n Peppa and McEvoy Olive Oil.  The BB Vietnamese Coffee I could see myself loving if I were a coffee drinker.   

Surprisingly, they don't over charge for these premium flavors; for two scoops, you're looking at three bucks and some change.  Five more stars go to the pleasant staff who didn't make me feel guilty at all for wanting to try almost everything twice.

If I had a gripe about Humphry Slocombe (love the name), it would be its location.  It's a trek from my place and I never feel safe in this neighborhood.  It'd be nice if they were closer to an area that I frequent (better yet, right next door to me), but life isn't always fair.  I'm just glad they exist.

Different is good.  In this case, really good.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Yummy in my tummy!

Jesus Juice: Coke/red wine. Not a very pleasant taste, but if you're into that, by all means, good for you.

Blue Bottle Coffee: Can you say YUM? But if you didnt get two flavors of ice cream, this taste is overwhelming, just like vietnamese coffee would be.

Tangerine: Simple, yet delicious. The citrus taste is most pleasant after a heavy/creamier ice cream.
author: Chieko H.

description:
Duuude! One of the best ice cream shops ever and I'm even saying it's better than Scoops in L.A. Here the ice cream is creamy and not so icy. Also you gotta give them props for their fun and creative ice cream names. Jesus Juice and Secret Breakfast to name a few.

BTW, I've only been here once but am convinced that the best flavor combination is that Vietnamese coffee ice cream with the Secret Breakfast. With the latter you can actually taste the bourbon.

I did find it interesting, though, that some flavors are subtle while others are sooo strong. The Milk Chocolate and Passionfruit was nasty! While the Cinnamon Brittle was subtle and not over the top sweet.

And that Jesus Juice actually does taste like Coke and red wine. Not necessarily a good thing.

Regardless, I wish we had a place like this back in L.A.
author: Caroline P.

description: Dessert got cut short because of our late dinner and dessert places started closing.  We chose to head to Humphrey Slocombe to get some secret breakfast ice cream, and end the night there.  It was super tasty, as expected.  Everything I tried there was really good.  I think I like it better than Bi-rite just because of the more interesting flavors.
author: Jenna L.

description:
The single most important reason that you need to get yourself over to Humphry Slocombe for a frozen treat is:

Secret Breakfast (Shhh!) = Bourbon Ice Cream with Corn Flakes
______________________________________________

Then try the Malted Dulce de Leche

Then try the Ooolong (Oooh) 

You will be spoiled for any other ice cream from that day forward.
author: Liz S.

description:
Interesting flavors but ice cream has more soul than that and after 3 times I can say that:
- the texture is granular
- it is way too fat and greasy
- it is actually too expensive!

But the Blue Bottle Vietnamese coffee one tastes exactly like Coppa del Nonno (http://tinyurl.com/nctccj), one of my favorite ice creams as a kid. Big points.
author: Dario B.

description:
Secret Breakfast.  Get it.  Eat it.  Love it.

Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee.  Imagine your favorite dirty Vietnamese pho restaurant.  Now clean it up, and add a bowtie.  Then order a coffee.  Now freeze.  That's the flavor.
author: Jenny L.

description: I love me some good ice cream, and I've had a good deal of awesome ice creams over the years, but the delectable dairy treats at Humphrey's stand out for taste, texture, and creativity. Only here can ice cream make me do a happy dance. This last I went I had the Vietnamese coffee mixed with the Secret Breakfast, while my bf had the Basil Lime Sorbet with the Summer Corn. Holy. Cow (literally). Give this place a try - you'll be in ice cream heaven.
author: Chelsea C.

description: Inventive/weird ice cream flavors that they will let you try (with eco-friendly metal spoons) if you ask make this a fun place to visit.  The line can be absolutely enormous, but it's a fun trip.  Tiny amount of seating inside may as well not even exist.
author: Sally L.

description:
Humphry's! What happened to you guys.. I loved loved your Special Breakfast, but this time it was just "Special" there was no "Breakfast" (Corn flakes) BOOO that was the best part. The last time my boyfriend got it, there was too much bourbon :( 

Really yummy, but to keep people coming back you guys should be more consistent with your flavors... just a thought...
author: Mandy H.

description:
I thought it was just okay.. maybe it was the fact that by the time I got to the counter, around 5pm-ish most of the flavors that other yelpers recommended were no longer available... 

I did try Secret Breakfast and the the spicy banana: 
Secret Breakfast: A-
Spicy Banana (not the exact name..): C

I will def go back and try the other flavors since everyone is fiercely pushing the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee and Balsamic Caramel.
author: Milee M.

description: Had the Secret Breakfast flavor at the Saturday Ferryplace Farmer's Market and it was like an orgasm in my mouth.  They definitely don't skimp on the bourbon and the alcohol definitely compliments the milky sweet taste of the ice cream while the corn flakes give it added texture and crunch.  After my first scoop, I couldn't stop so I went back for another (I literally thought I was gonna get drunk at one point).  Well worth the money for an unforgettable experience that I will continue to dream about after I leave the country.
author: Mona F.

description:
favorite flavors
-oolong tea
-vietnamese coffee

the other combinations are too extreme for me. 

side note: sugar cone goes well with the ice cream
author: Ann B.

description:
I like things that freak me out.

I like pugs because they look like they took one two many punches to the face and yet they persevere.

I like rickety old wooden rollercoasters that people may or may not have died on.

I like Buttered Popcorn Jelly Belly's.

I like the Olive Oil ice cream.

No one else seemed to like it, but I dug it.  I had a taste and Hallmark had 1/2 a scoop upon my reccomendation but then looked like he couldn't wait till the horror of Olive Oil ice cream was over.  

I was sad I overlooked the Salt & Pepper ice cream.  I struggled at the counter.  The pressure was on.  The woman behind the case looked like she had gone through this before, a million times over, as I stuttered and "uhh" and "mmm"  trying to make up my mind.

Eveyrone talks about the Breakfast Surprise and the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee.  So I got that.  Because I can be such a lemming.

(One day I'm going to drink the Kool Aid and this makes me sad.)


Both are excellent. I imagine the Breakfast Surprise overwhelmed the BB Coffee as I thought the coffee tasted a bit weaker then expected.  

I must come back for the Strauss Yogurt, which I really really really should have just bought a pint of because I know me and I know yogurt and I know that it's going to be love at first swallow.

Eeeeew.  Why do I gross myself out?
author: Jen I.

description:
This ice cream tasted SO good after a long day at work.  I had a scoop of the Secret Breakfast (bourbon and corn flakes) and the Tahitian Vanilla.  Both flavors were amazing.  
Only four stars because it's probably the most fattening ice cream I've ever had - I could feel the cream/grease coating the inside of my mouth as I was eating it.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
They should keep Marvin Gaye on repeat during business hours because THIS IS ONE SEXY-ASS TREAT, BABY.

These guys have it going on-- the textures are velvety-perfect and the flavors are really inventive.  Honestly, if I am going to go out to an ice cream parlor for a little lovin, I'm not interested in a strawberry cone.  I want to be titilated.  Damn right, I said it.  Titilated.

As everyone says, the secret breakfast / vietnamese coffee combo is pretty divine... but hey, you can taste them all-- so do it!
author: Laura F.

description:
Named after two characters from the British comedy Are You Being Served?, Humphrey Slocombe  offers quirky (Salt & pepper, Bourbon), creative (Red hot banana, Pineapple 5 spice) and classic (Vanilla, Chocolate) ice cream flavors.  The ice cream is obviously made in small batches with high quality ingredients by someone with a passion for ice cream and a sense of humor.  

Expect to find about 12 flavors (the most popular flavors, e.g., Secret breakfast, will always be available).  Once the sundae prep station is up and running, you'll be able to add homemade toppings like marshmallow fluff to your ice cream (sorry, it's not self serve).  They'll also have homemade cones.  

A single (1 - 2 flavors) will set you back $3.25, a kid's size is $2.25.

Flavors I tried:
* Thai chile lime sorbet - complex and interesting, the lime makes it refreshing while the coconut adds to the richness, the chile leaves you with a subtle heat (it's not that spicy but you do notice it)
* Blue Bottle Vietnamese coffee - loved this one because of the strong coffee flavor and the sweetness of the condensed milk, smooth texture, bold flavor.  I heard they were going to serve this at Blue Bottle.
* Guinness gingerbread - deep, spicy, rich flavor with chunks of gingerbread, yum 
* Secret breakfast - tastes like bourbon mixed with cream, I can see why some people would like it but it wasn't really my cup of tea, didn't get any cornflakes in my sample 
* Straus yogurt - icier and softer than the other flavors, nice and tarty but there were some ice chunks.  It's tarter than Harmony Yogurt and has more sugar than Culture (they also use Straus Yogurt in their plain fro-yo).  
* Olive oil - different from what I expected, the olive oil flavor isn't strong, it has orange and lemon zest but not so much of it that it tastes like lemon or orange ice cream, it's more subtle than that yet flavorful 

My favorites (for now) are the olive oil and Vietnamese coffee.  I'm looking forward to trying their other flavors (there are currently 50), including rhubarb, blood orange, Meyer lemon, dulce de leche, foie gras and peanut butter curry.  

Go now before the lines become too crazy.  You can sit outside or inside to enjoy your treat.

It's cash only for now.
author: Lolia S.

description: Cornflakes? Rum? Gingerbread?  Different.  Delicious!
author: James G.

description: Some of the best ice cream I've ever had anywhere. Sure, there are other great ice creams in the Bay Area, but I honestly can't say any of those are better. A few are just as good, but the scoops of Secret Breakfast & Guinness Gingerbread I had were right at the top. The girlfriend had Thai Chile Lime which she loved. I tried that also & thought it was excellent too. For anyone not afraid to try some offbeat and adventurous flavor combinations, some of the best ice cream anywhere can be found at Humphry Slocombe.
author: John M.

description:
I've worked in restaurants my entire working life--that's about 25 years (sigh).  So it pains me to give bad reviews, especially when they are based mostly upon poor service.  But my experience at Humprey Slocombe just can't be ignored, and I'm sure the owner would want to know.  Or maybe he/she wouldn't.

It was my first time at HS, and I was unfamiliar with their flavors, though had heard lots about Secret Breakfast.  The prices were a bit on the high side, so I wanted to make sure I was happy with whatever I chose, and usually, ice cream parlours are more than happy to give you a small sample of their wares.  I asked for a sample of Secret Breakfast, and decided I liked it.  Since I was going to order a combo of three scoops, I asked to sample the Caramel Balsalmic; my third choice was going to be Tahitian Vanilla and I knew that would be something I'd enjoy.  The dour gal behind the counter, who had been standing in the same position with her arms crossed and scowl on her face since I entered the store, (no welcome or even acknowledgement that I'd entered) REFUSED to give me a second sample.  And my first sample was a mere pea-sized speck.  I asked why, and in a very passive/aggressive sing-song tone, she told me that if she gave out samples to customers all day long, that no one would get any service.  Um, OK.  I was the only customer in the shop.  While she was scooping out my bowl, her body language, frequent sighing, and slamming around of utensils let me know exactly what she thought of my presence in her store.

As a seasoned front-of-the-house employee who has worked at establishments from vegetarian burger stands on the beach to Michelin 2-stars, it's *never* OK to make lacking service the customer's fault.  It just isn't done.  And if she had a less jaded attitude, I may have had some sympathy, but from the moment I entered the shop, her contribution to the ambiance was waves of ennui, like "my degree at a private East Coast university makes me way too good to be scooping out ice cream."  I just don't get why so many of a certain kind of restaurant--oh heck; I'll just use the H word and say *hipster*--insists upon hiring these types with obviously no customer service experience or desire to happily serve people.  Is it for the look?  

Anyhoo, the Tahitian Vanilla was good but not great, and the Secret Breakfast and Caramel Balsalmic were not at all anything I'd ever order again.  I guess HS's ice cream just isn't my cup of tea, but their atrocious service is unforgiveable.  And this is coming from someone who goes out of her way to give service people every last chance, and leaves super-gigantico tips.  So hey, HS patrons, you don't have to put up with this crappy service.  Vote with your feet!
author: Andrea W.

description:
New ice cream spot in the Mission with very creative flavors, but I'm still partial to Bi Rite at this point. 

I tried secret breakfast, balsamic caramel, olive oil, thai chili lime, valrhona fudgesicle, vietnamese coffee, and salt & pepper. All the flavors were definitely interesting, but my favorites were secret breakfast, olive oil, valrhona fudgesicle, and vietnamese coffee. 

I thought I would like thai chili lime, but I found the flavor a bit weird for ice cream, it even had a good amount of kick at the end. The vietnamese coffee was pretty similar to my favorite toffee coffee at Bi Rite, without the toffee of course.

Texture wise, I'd say Bi Rite is a tad better than HS, but once HS works out their flavors, they could give Bi Rite a run for their money.

I'll be back to try more flavors, but for now, 4 stars for their innovative ice cream.
author: Derrick V.

description: They have very unique flavors which is great, but the ice cream is too rich, heavy and creamy.  We tasted several of the flavors and ended up getting oolong tea and sesame.  They were good but not somewhere I'd go back again.  Three Twins ice cream is still our favorite.
author: Irene C.

description:
Man, I hate to be a hater, but I feel like I've really given ol' Humphry a chance and he's let me down. I've tried the stuff three times (once at Mission St Foods and twice at the store) and I've gone from hopeful to skeptical to naysaying. 

As one yelper hinted, HS is all about shock value, not actual value. The flavors are exciting, but they don't deliver. I've had Vietnamese coffee, balsamic caramel, olive oil, salt and pepper, secret breakfast and others that I can't remember and have never felt the need to finish my cup (not that I didn't, of course--I just didn't NEED to). Some of the flavors taste pretty good at first, but they all become overpowering after a few bites. Something about them is out of balance. PLUS--and I can't get over this--there were ice chunks in several of the flavors. Really? For $3/scoop or whatever it is?!

I'm sorry, I'm a Bi-Rite gal all the way. The only thing HS really beats Bi-Rite on (and the reason I give it 3 stars instead of 2) is the atmosphere of the store. HS is adorable and calm and has seating (indoor and outdoor). 

Hopefully they'll mature a little by toning down the flavors and learning how to keep the ice out of the ice cream.
author: haley b.

description:
Weird flavors.

Awesomeness!!!

Breakfast with curry is interestingly amazing!

Overall, two calf heads! ;)
author: Jay C.

description:
Secret Breakfast is my crack.  I think it's the best flavor to come out of the fantastic ice cream shop.

I love that they aren't afraid, and in fact have made it their mission, to explore new, unusual and interesting flavors.  Thanks to them I've had locally brewed beer ice cream, blue bottle coffee ice cream and I'm sure many more.  But I always go back to Secret Breakfast!

One thing to note, their ice cream is best eaten on the spot.  I've brought pints home on a couple occasions and the consistency can get a bit funky if it's in the freezer for a week.
author: Laura K.

description:
If this place *really* wanted to take it to the next level, they would invent the first ice cream tasting glory hole!

You cruise in, line up at the wall, and stick your tongue through the hole.  A complete stranger then lands a dollop of creamy cold splendor onto your taste-buds.  You never know what you're going to get... salty?  sweet?  pepper... chili lime... olive oil... maybe KUMquat poppySEED!?!?!  After it rolls around your tongue, and clears the back of your throat, an audible "whooah" is guaranteed.

Yes Humphry, since I just invented it for you, we can negotiate the royalties on said glory hole.

All of you chumps can take a number and stand in line at the old guard, Mitchell's and Bi-Rite, no disrespect.  But I will stroll my southern, ice cream loving ass over to Harrison where there's no waiting and my favorite blue-eyed bell greets me with an enormous smile and a cone full of the best, most adventurous ice cream in town.

Can I get a mothafuckin Amen!
author: christoph s.

description:
Pros: Shorter line than Bi-rite, exotic flavors appealing to all senses, generous scoops, friendly staff, free water, seating, clean
Cons: Pricey, but you get what you pay for

What's the point of writing a review for a place that has many reviews?  Simply put, this was a gem I didn't even know existed in my neighborhood until the buzz starting radiating like a siren in the last month.  And for that, I am almost ashamed.  Despite my love of Bi-Rite (annoyingly long lines), Bombay Creamery (the best the best), and Mitchells (sorbets are so good)...how could I have not known.  I am supposed to be the ice cream tour lady!

After breaking ym Humphry Slocombe virginity at Mission Street Food with Vietnamese Coffee and Cinnamon Brittle, I returned in glory to taste again.

Overall having ice cream is an experience.  Be sure that your palate is cleansed before trying a taste.  You taste something at first, something different in the middle, then something different at the end.

My boyfriend and I first got a double which comes with three scoops with Secret Breakfast, Strawberry Candied Jalapeno, and Chese 'N Rice.  The former is a mix of cornflakes and bourbon--which to my alcohol distaste--is better when combined with other flavors.  The Strawberry Candied Jalapeno is like Mexican spiced strawberries--the odd unexpected spice is startling, but then the strawberry flavor comes strong.  Oddly enough, the jalapeno flavor goes away after repeated tastings; perhaps due to adapation?  The rice adds a nice texture to Cheese 'N Rice, although I could barely taste the cheese as it was only like vanilla.

On my second visit, I got a single with Thai Chili Lime Sorbet and Coconut Sherbert.  It is true the latter flavor reminded me of the coconut ice cream I had on the streets of Bangkok--unfortunately minus the usual mixings like corn.  The former was...like the Strawberry Candied Jalapeno with a surprising kick with the chili and settling down into the lime.

It's hard not to pull down any ratings with the happy faces around me.  Everyone is always pleased with the experience.  Even the people behind the counter exude happiness as if they do truly love to work there.  People often came in and out greeting the employees, stepping behind the counter to say hello.  

If the light is off in the bathroom, the switch is broken and I believe you need to push.  There's a cool photo hanging above the toilet!
author: Jenn N.

description:
this was my last stop before i went back to socal. . .
being an ice cream fanatic. . .this place didn't do it for me. . .
homemade ice cream should be creamy, it tasted too salty for my taste buds. . .
The owner seemed to be pretty cool, he had ice cream on ice cream cones tatooed on his forearm, which i thought was awesome!
author: Remie M.

description:
I am not a big ice cream fan and normally when I do get a scoop I never finish it.  But then I tasted the brown butter ice cream at Humphry's.  Its really good as is the coffee flavor.  
I had a taste of the balsamic carmel and it was... interesting.  
Be prepared for a line!
author: Julie C.

description:
Chris Cosentino, the chef over at Incanto, raved about the Boccalone Prosciutto ice cream on The Best Thing I Ever Ate, a show on the Food Network. Ice cream infused with salty pig parts? Curiosity got the best of me...

I sampled the Boccalone Prosciutto and was pleasantly surprised. The meaty notes are subtle and balanced with the sweetness of the ice cream. In the end, we settled for two other delicious flavors -- the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee (I LOVE Blue Bottle) and, my new favorite, Peanut Butter Curry. The sweet nutty peanut flavor with just enough curry spice swirled up in a cool creamy concoction -- absolutely fantastic!

I love this place for its playfulness and creativity. I can't wait to try all the other flavors!
author: Joel A.

description:
Tried two flavors--Vietnamese Coffe (BB) and Secret Breakfast. 

The first one  tastes like you mixed  Blue Bottle coffee in a pint of Strauss Creamery Vanilla.  Strauss has a very rich flavor, totally elbowing out the coffee.  Mixing in booze is always tricky (makes the texture looser), and this one was drippy and felt more like spiked cream. Ciao Bella does it better with their Jack Daniels & Pecan (albeit sans corn flakes, which I admit is genius).  

My better judgement fought against 3/4 of the flavors on display and questioned why I'm not at the other end of the MIssion, at Bi-Rite, where the flavors vie heavily to get in my belly.   

Also, not very kid-friendly, even if the child is quiet and perfectly well-behaved, which loses another point from me. Cracking a smile won't kill your hipster cred, and you're an ice cream store...
author: Ms. Q.

description:
Heard about this place through a wine newsletter of all places - the person who wrote it (and lives in Seattle) touted it as the 2nd Best Ice Cream after Bi-Rite. Hmmm...I thought. Worth a visit then right?

Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee? So Blue Bottle AND vietnamese coffee both of which I love wrapped up in one and delivered as ice cream? Dude i gotta try this! Ya know what? What is true, the texture of the ice cream is excellent - I'm not sure if I was going gaga over the flavors - maybe it was cuz I was full from a day of eating heavy food, but I am curious to go back and try something else. 

Secret Breakfast was intriguing - I had the emotional response of "this tastes like Bourbon! but it's not bad!" Perhaps all the benefits of Bourbon without the nasty feeling on the way down (or the hangover)? 

I still rate Bi-Rite as my fave in SF but they do good work here.
author: Ross R.

description:
My hubby asked me if I wanted to have dessert after watching the NBA playoffs...and I'm like sure.  I was thinking about giving Humphry Slocombe a second chance after checking it out two years ago and not liking it as much.  So we drove down to the Mission after 9pm.  The line wasn't too bad compared to Bi-Rite.  I couldn't figure out how to look up their daily menu on Twitter, so I had to go there blindly to see if there was anything I would like.  The menu was limited: Secret Breakfast, Blue Bottle Vientamese Coffee, Harvey Milk and Honey, Tahitian Vanilla, Salt and Pepper, Candied Ginger, McEvoy Olive Oil, Strawberry Szhechuan sorbet, and a salted watermelon sorbet. Hmm...I wasn't feeling too adventurous so I stuck with the Harvey Milk and Honey (with crumbled graham crackers).  My husband went with Gabba Gabba Hey sundae.  The Harvey Milk ice cream was ok....it tasted grainy because of the graham cracker and it was a bit hard...not as smooth compared to Bi-Rite ice cream.  It didn't melt as fast compared to the Secret Breakfast and Tahitian Vanilla we picked up a couple years ago...makes me wonder about their ice cream now.  I sampled the Gabba Gabba Hey and it was surprisingly tasty....you couldn't taste the caramel because it was overpowered the balsamic flavor.  

The service was ok....some of the staff look tired like they wanted the night to end.  It's a bit pricier as well.  Humphry Slocombe ice cream is more for the likes of Anthony Bourdain...perhaps a bit too gourmet for me where I have to analyze every bite of my ice cream.  I'll stick my Bi-Rite ice cream, where their flavors stand out and get two different flavored ice cream scoops for $3.25!
author: Lisa W.

description:
Oh, not good.  Secret breakfast was over powering, blue bottle vietnamese was standard, and chocolate sea salt was over salted!  :((((((
$5 for 4 small pieces of their salt and pepper caramels was a bust too- had to spit it out :(((((((((((. Well, I guess I can check them off my list,.......gonna stick with Bi-Rite if you please.
author: Patty J.

description:
Yes, many of us are comfortable with our usual City faves- Mitchell's, Bi-Rite, or even Polly Ann's- but I dare you to come to Humphry Slocombe (someone please tell me who this is named after?!). Don't expect to find a Vanilla, Chocolate, or Mango. My first cone was McEvoy Olive Oil with Salt and Pepper on a cone. Woah! The flavors were outstanding, but most of all enjoyable. I also had the Valrhona Fudgsicle with the Malted Dulce de Leche which was awesome. Go to their website and check out their crazy roster of flavors, which rotate often. 

Here's another reason to come to Humphry's- local and organic ingredients. Their dairy comes from Straus Family Creamery in Point Reyes. Then there's Blue Bottle Coffee and the McEvoy Olive Oil. They're also adding more products- like sundaes and baked goods (go for the Chocolate Chip Cookies). Can't wait for my next round!!!
author: Leroid D.

description: You don't really need me to tell you to go to Humphry Slocombe's...over a thousand people are raving about it here. I will say that Secret Breakfast is my favorite ice cream flavor ever. Yes, ever.
author: Dave V.

description:
I absolutely love this place.  Was recommended this place about a year ago by a foodie friend, and have been going back every since.  They have many off the wall flavors like salt and pepper, thai chili, and my personal favorite government cheese (j/k I havent actually tried gov't cheese, but look forward to the day it's offered).  

One of my many personal favorites is blue bottle vietnamese coffee with balsamic caramel...yum!  Follow them on twitter and you'll be up to date with all Humphry Slocombe has to offer.  Keep doing what you do!
author: David M.

description:
While some of the flavors here are too far out for my tastes, I really appreciate the creativity. Unfortunately, they were sold out of fudgesicle when I was here so I didn't get to try it. I had the Blue Bottle coffee ice cream and the creamcheese and chocolate chip. Both were amazing. 

Like everyone else has already said, the staff is great and super friendly. I'm looking forward to trying all the crazy flavors these guys dream up.
author: Aaron V.

description:
I cannot remember the name Humphry Slocombe for the life of me even though I've been dying to try it since reading about it on the Beer & Nosh blog. Holcombe? Honey Comb? Wha? Regardless of the name, HS puts themselves on the map for making memorable and unexpected ice cream flavors that is light and smooth unlike other places.

Since 24th & Harrison isn't exactly next door for me, I didn't make an effort to try it out until Mission Street Food featured them last night. Since the wait was insane, I BEGGED AND BEGGED to let me get the ice cream to go.

Secret Breakfast - liquor flavor that is bourbon, cornflakes makes the chunks apparently.
Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee - nice and even not overwhelmingly coffee tasting
Balsamic Caramel - most complex of the three, is it sour? olivey? salty? sweet? gets better with each bite though.

I wish I had the three flavors in reverse sequence because Secret Breakfast was crazy delicious. But what's what happens when you randomly eat your ice-cream in a cab!

Another choice ice-cream spot in the city! San Francisco, I love you.
author: Faffy L.

description:
Not to have a giant piggy party or anything, but I am quite taken with ice cream. 

I have since the first review was written also had Peanut Butter Curry, Cinnamon Brittle, Blue Bottle Co. Cappucino and Brown Sugar Yogurt.  Weird but good, yum, yum and yuuuuuuuum.
author: Erica E.

description:
What a gorgeous day today! I live in Pacifica and no sign of fog in sight! Boys got off early today from school and decided to treat them to some ice cream at Humphrey Slocombe. 

Caught the Food Network's " The Best Thing I Ever Ate" last Saturday and Chris Cosentino picked Humphrey Slocombe's Prosciutto ice cream as his last meal on earth.  Was in the Mission a couple of weeks ago for the SF Street Food Festival, saw the line around the block and had to try this place. 

 It was the perfect day to go! Got there around 2pm and walked right in and even sampled several different flavors- score!

Tahitian Vanilla: Tahitian vanilla is lighter bodied than Madagascar vanilla and I like the creaminess better of the Madagascar. It was good, but pretty vanilla.

Secret Breakfast: The bourbon wasn't too overpowering and the cornflakes were still crunchy!

Pluot Coconut Cardamom: Like pluots, like coconuts, like cardamom, but this was interesting.. slightly tart with a hint of cardamom.. not a huge fan. I've had another brand of cardamom ice cream with pistachio and those two flavors seemed to meld better. 

Black Sesame:  Since it was a hot day and it took about 45 minutes to get home after making a couple of stops, the pint of ice cream which I brought home had softened to perfection. Creamy vanilla swirled with black sesame was divine! 

Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee: The freshness of the coffee really stands out! Yum!

Here's a great write-up about H.S. from the New York Times:
http://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/04/magazine/04icecream-t.html?pagewanted=all
author: M.A. L.

description:
a.w.e.s.o.m.e!!!!!!!!!!!

ive been here several times and it never disappoints! 

besides the famous blue bottle coffee and secret breakfast, i also really love their other flavors that are not as popular, for examples:

1. salt and pepper: that's actually my FAVORITE in the whole store, maybe im just really into the whole sweet and savory combination to begin with, so when i tried it for the 1st time, i fell in love ever since! too bad i havent had a chance to see it again since the last time i got it b/c they dont make it regularly (i actually checked with the cashier and he said that it really depends on the chef's mood)

2. peanut butter curry: it's very interesting, even thought those 2 things dont really sound like they go together, but surprisingly they go together very well! the peanut flavor blended with that deep tumeric curry flavor, it definitely gives my palettes a "hello there!"

3. candied ginger: im a ginger lover in general, so this flavor is right up my alley! i like how i can taste big pieces of candied ginger in my ice cream and the background ice cream isn't loaded with overwhelming ginger flavor. Instead, it's just the right creaminess and subtle flavor to complement the flavor coming from candied ginger pieces
author: Joyce C.

description:
Really like the inventive flavors, and the fact that there's some variety. It's also a bit more reasonably priced than Bi-Rite.

The texture is creamy and the flavors pronounced and they generally work. The clerks are happy to give you a sample if you're not sure.

My favorites were peanut butter curry and salted licorice. Both were divine.

I'd give it 5 stars if they managed to use some sort of social media to display what flavors are currently available. (Their Twitter feed does nothing of the sort)
author: Jason M.

description:
Their innovative ice cream flavors really are that good. Some experiments don't always work, but the ones that do are well worth the line out the door.

Best I've had were the black pepper ice cream and the chocolate stout ice cream.
author: Patrick Z.

description:
We came last Saturday around 2pm, line was not super crazy which is always good. By the time we left, line was half way done the block.  We got a table and the staff were quick and friendly.

We got one cup with 2 scoops - one each of  Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee and one of balsamic caramel.

The balsamic caramel was liked whipped cream it was so light and airy, but even with 2 of us eating it, we thought the balsamic was overpowering and muted the caramel flavors.

The Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee was FANTASTIC and I could eat that all day, it was so good. 

$3.75  for 2 scoops, great deal

Great unusual flavors to try and I will be back
author: ORLA L.

description:
OK, OK...I get that mixing savory and sweet can be a mind-blowing experience. Sometimes odd flavor combinations can be surprisingly good. But then again some flavors are just not meant-to-be.

For example, olive oil plus vanilla ice cream is well, not so pretty.  I tried it and it is exactly like what you can imagine. In fact, you can probably make this at home. Get some olive oil. Pour it over your ice cream and enjoy!

I also tried "salt and pepper" and this had the same effect.

As you can probably tell, the obscure flavor combinations didn't enthrall me. However, the more common flavors, like coffee, were good.

Don't let me detour you from checking out the less popular flavors. My advice: try some a few flavors before you invest in one.
author: Lauren T.

description:
Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee and Secret Breakfast. Get it. You won't be sorry. It'll make your day..better yet, it'll make your week.

Plus, those little metal tasting spoons are so cute! Yes, I'm easily amused.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Since I just FINALLY wrote my first review on Yelp I had to get out a couple of extras for my Favorite Things in San Francisco.

This is one of them.

Slightly tough on vegetarians (salty pig parts etc), but more than makes up for it with secret breakfast ice cream, hibiscus-beet sorbet, salt-and-pepper ice cream, and just general awesomeness in the wild wild world of ice-cream-fads.  

Humphry Slocombe simply cheers me up when i need it.
author: Moya W.

description:
yup, secret breakfast is amazing.  

also tried the brown butter...should definitely stay away if you're anywhere near full.  this will make you puke, but it's damn delicious (for at least 3 bites)

tahitian vanilla - very vanilla-y which is never a bad thing

vietnamese coffee - should have gotten this...it tastes EXACTLY like vietnamese coffee...amazing.

i went with the plum and earl grey sorbet which actually went really well together.  it was refreshing and a little bit savory at the same time, which was perfect after gorging myself at the food festival.
author: Jeff N.

description:
Ohhh, that is good!!! The Vietnamese coffee is an intense creamy heart-racing caffeine delight. The mild Honey & Thyme, a nostalgic softness. And, the ever infamous Secret Breakfast... the trend to bring morning sweets as anytime sweets just makes simple, delicious sense. 
I haven't quite gotten to the stranger flavors of the Humphry Slocombe repertoire but did get a quick tasting of the Boccalone Prosciutto--uhm. It's interesting. I'm still undecided whether I love or hate the whole cured-meat on dessert trend but it's definitely not one of my favorite.
Still, that Vietnamese coffee ice cream... kick ass.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Tasty ice cream, loved the chocolate and peach mmmmmm.
CASH ONLY though, so don't forget to bring some $$
author: Kerem S.

description:
its honey thyme all day everyday!

a must try. delicious~
author: Nami C.

description: Humphry Slocombe serves up some world class ice cream. After checking the website and reading about all of the crazy flavors, we were excited to sample some of the wilder offerings, but the location's selection was limited. Either way, the breakfast flavor is great, even though the ice cream is a bit overpriced.
author: Christopher B.

description: Love the secret breakfast and sweet summer corn ice cream!
author: Jenna C.

description:
Humphry Slocombe has *the* most unique and interesting ice cream flavors....Boccalone Prosciutto, Peanut Butter Curry, Szechuan Strawberry, Balsamic Caramel...and the list goes on. It's so fun to try all the crazy flavors, but the key is to find one that you'd want to eat a whole scoop or two of. 

For me, it's all about the Secret Breakfast - bourbon ice cream with little crispy chunks of cornflakes. Such creamy goodness! The bourbon provides a nice punch but isn't too strong, and I love the textural contrast of the crunchy cornflakes scattered throughout the ice cream. 

The Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee ice cream is a close second. It's the BEST COFFEE ICE CREAM I've tasted....intense coffee flavor infused with rich creaminess. Mmmmm.

Now if only they'd have their Foie Gras ice cream in the rotation during one of my next visits...I've been dying to try it...
author: Karin V.

description:
it didn't wow me the first time I went but giving the secret breakfast flavor another shot....i just totally fell in LOVE with this ice cream.   great texture and combo (bourbon and corn flakes....who would've ever thought they would go so well together).  I wondered why didn't I like it last time??  (then I remembered...i had two restaurant foods and a dessert back to back before stoping by this place).  Maybe I was a bit full??

the staffs pull out sample spoons as you enter into the joint and asks in a friendly manner "would you like to try any samples??"   What a best way to greet there customers.  I wait for a steakhouse that would do the same....MmmmMMm.

it is priced fairly and simple in ambiance.   gotta love it.  yes, you are cool for using ipad for your cashier counter.
author: Jang David K.

description:
Wow...there's a party in my mouth, and everyone's invited! Especially some Humphry Slocombe ice cream!

It's a little out of the ways for me (seeing that it's completely on the other side of town from where I live), the husband and i were up for the journey. Hidden away, we found parking right away, and walked up to the counter.

We were greeted right away, and were encouraged to try every flavor, which we took full advantage of! Finally deciding, the husband got a scoop of the olive oil and the secret breakfast flavors. I got the pistachio-bacon and the balsamic caramel flavors. The secret breakfast had a strong bourbon flavor and the balsamic caramel was also very strong, which worked perfectly with the olive oil and the pistachio-bacon,  which were a little milder than i thought they would be. 

There was even some peanut bacon brittle to munch on as I waited in line. YUM!

Definitely, a place to check out. You leave wanting to come back for more. Great staff, great flavors, great establishment. If you are craving for something fun and different, RUN (don't walk) to Humphry Slocombe.
author: Jan Z.

description: This is the place to go when you want crazy concocted out of the box delicious ice cream. Their ice creams have names that you wouldn't really guess it's ice cream unless you knew. My fave is the secret breakfast, has cereal bits and bourbon in it, so good! They even have a flavor called Jesus juice.. Was rly sweet lol
author: Patrick L.

description:
4.5 stars for the ice cream, extra 0.5 star for being green!

If you want to try interesting ice cream favor, this is the place to be. We sample salt&pepper and balsamic favors; they're a bit odd but very interesting. We settle with coffee and coconut favors. I think it'll be really awesome if this place can offer like a sampler ice cream plate that let us taste all 12 favors for like $5 or so.
author: RicknKeyna W.

description: Salt and Pepper and the Blue Bottle Coffee flavors are delicious flavors. There are always other interesting ones to try. It's been hit and miss with trying new flavors, but mostly hits.
author: katrina w.

description: I'm a sucker for good ice cream, especially unique flavors that you just can't get anywhere. I stopped in here with some friends and immediately went straight to sampling. Sometimes, I feel a little self conscious trying everything and a little bit like the scoopers can get a little annoyed, but not here. They were happy to let me try anything my heart desired and even encouraged it! After hearing about all of the crazy flavors and even browsing the website,  I was a little disappointed in the selection(they rotate flavors based on the season). I was really hoping for the peanut butter curry or something beet related. However, I ended up falling in love with the secret breakfast (bourbon and cornflakes)!
author: Diane T.

description: My favorite ice cream place in the mission. My go to flavors include brown butter, eton mess, miso peach, salted watermelon, and their blue bottle coffee.
author: Elaine N.

description:
The Secret Breakfast:  was good in the beginning and I liked the cornflakes they added.  But after awhile it tasted weird.  It had a strange after taste like vomit on my tongue and started feeling greasy film.  I have never experienced this with ice cream before..and my friend who came at a different time said the same about the greasiness on the tongue so it wasn't just me.

Vietnamese Ice Coffee:  Tastes good but kinda of on the icey side..which I expected to be more creamy like ice cream.  

The owner is really nice and takes pleasure in using his iPad to conduct business.  He will welcome taste testers so don't worry about asking for samples.  

I like ice cream, not sure how I can ever really give it a bad review.  I am open to trying other adventures here since this place is all about exploring crazy flavors!
author: Peachie Y.

description:
The boys in the back whipping up these flavors are pure genius! I walked into the shop, giggling like a school girl. I was dreaming about sampling all the exotic flavors all week!

First, the gents scooping these amazing flavors are so friendly, fun and their love of making their ice cream really shows. At first I was feeling a bit greedy wanting to sample everything, but I can see now why they're so generous with the samples - just like a proper drug dealer, the first one is always free!!

With that said, I'm hooked like a crack head junkie! I am anxiously waiting the rollout of the rest of the flavors.

My favorites:
Guinness Gingerbread - OMG! YES!
Secret Breakfast (Shh) - This is a MUST try! Breakfast of champions!
Vietnamese Coffee - it's like they took all the deliciousness of iced Vietnamese coffee, and made it into ice cream
Balsamic Caramel - another hit, the flavor is addicting!
Red Hot Banana - who knew Red Hots and banana ice cream could taste so good!

Oh yes, the brownies are also a must have!

Look out Bi-Rite and Mitchell's - there's a new dealer in town!
author: Christy L.

description: Oh ice cream...how you make me so happy.  Went here on a random night with friends and was surprised they were still open and it was relatively late.  They have some interesting names and flavors from mulled wine to a breakfast one (had cereal in it).  I went form the pumpkin allspice.  I heart pumpkin so much.  It makes me smile just thinking about it.  Honestly speaking this isn't the best pumpkin ice cream I had but it's pretty good.  I'd come here again to try out more flavors if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Kim D.

description: This could be the best ice cream I've had. There was a long line but we were there with family and had fun as we waited. I sampled a bunch of flavors including the Tahitian vanilla, Magnolia stout, malted milk chocolate, Vietnamese coffee and then - Secret Breakfast! This is bourbon and corn flake ice cream, people. And it could be my secret breakfast every day. I got a two scoop cut, Secret Breakfast and Vietnamese Coffee (what they call a "Complete Breakfast") and loved every bite with its incredible creamy mouthfeel and complicated strong flavors. In San Francisco? Love ice cream - or even just like ice cream? Get yourself to Humphrey Slocombe.
author: Adrien L.

description:
chocolate with smoked sea salt - 5 stars
secret breakfast (bourbon and cereal) - 4.5 stars
brown sugar and fennel - 4.5 stars
brown butter - 4.5 stars
lime basil sorbet - 4.5 stars
author: Scott W.

description: YUM!  Checked out this place after seeing it on Yelp and thought it lived up to all the hype.  They make a wide variety of flavors but offers only about 10-12 at a time which is probably plenty to choose from unless you're ultra picky.  The good thing about that is that it makes you keep wanting to go back.  There can be a pretty lengthy line but when I've been the line seems to go pretty quickly unless you get behind a group of people who insist on sampling the entire freezer case.
author: Kent W.

description:
Pretty unique stuff.  Great & Different flavors.  I like to get coffee (made with blue bottle) and Secret Breakfast (bourbon & cornflakes) on a waffle cone.  So, sinfully delicious!  

There is sometimes a line on weekends but it moves pretty quickly and then 10 minutes later you have in your hand some yummy ice cream.
author: Ka C.

description:
5 stars for consistently taking risks with their flavors.
I am comparing HSIC to Bi-Rite, Delise, and Naia, which all have fantastic ice cream and gelator, however, err on the more traditional side of their flavors. In the two times that I have visited HSIC, I have had Limoncello and Peanut Butter Curry. Both were incredible and unique flavors that were delicious and savory.
author: Michael S.

description: Moved out of SF.  Can't stop trying to find something equivalent to the Mexican (salted) chocolate.  It had to be hands down the best ice cream I've ever had in my 50 years of eating the stuff.  Please, if you're in SF, do me a favor and go down to Harrison Street and eat some now.  Please.  For the love of all things sweet/salty/umami.
author: Liz W.

description:
I've gotta be honest. The flavors solely based on their names first scared me off. You have to have an open mind coming here since they don't make your average joe ice cream like cookies and cream or mint chip. My bf finally convinced me to give it a shot and I'm happy that he did. The past 3 times I've gone, the Secret Breakfast has gotten better and better (meaning more bourbon!). Other flavors I've enjoyed are Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee, Fudgesicle and Tahitian Vanilla. I tried the Jesus Juice, but no likey since I'm not a red wine fan to begin with. They sell flavors by the pint and also have cookies and ooh their bacon peanut brittle is frickin awesome.  

Parking in the neighborhood stinks, but I think it's worth the trip out here. Seating is very limited (about 8 stools inside and a few tables and chairs outside). They're pretty patient with customers asking to taste every single flavor and they also provide you with water which comes in handy after inhaling 3 scoops of ice cream. Their bathroom is pretty clean, too.  

Follow them on Twitter for entertaining updates on their daily special flavors (@humphryslocombe).
author: Joy L.

description:
Apparently, fancy, artisan ice cream is all the rage, especially in the Bay Area, and I am all for the movement and popularity of such a delicious food item. With the opening of so many new places, it is definitely hard to stand out among the rest, but Humphry Slocumbe is trying their best to do so. Exotic flavors such as Passion Milk Chocolate, McEvoy Olive Oil, Salt and Pepper, and Secret Breakfast scream out to the patron, "TRY ME, TRY ME!" The flavors stimulate my palette, but to be honest, sometimes they just aren't for me. Up until last week, I wasn't sure how I felt about this newcomer to the ice cream world, but that all changed last Thursday when I had one of the best desserts I've ever tasted.

When I enter any ice cream shop, I do my fair share of sampling of the exotic and outlandish, because hey, you only live once. After sampling Hibiscus Beet Sorbet and Passion Milk Chocolate, my eyes were averted by another curious sounding menu item: Fois Gras on Gingersnap. There was no doubt in my mind that I was going to order it. The server even warned me that it was super fois-grasy and offered an additional sample, but I still went for it, and boy was it AMAZING! The ice cream hits you with the richness and heartiness that fois gras brings, but it finished sweet and creamy. It paired so well with the crisp and chewy housemade gingersnap that I wish I had bought two of them! It is a must try if it is available again on the menu.
author: Christina N.

description: Excellent ice cream.  I loved the Brown Sugar/Fennel and the Peanut Butter/Curry.  So creative.  So good.
author: Lily W.

description:
Day of Visit: 05/01/2010

Came here on a Saturday around 8pm thinking it would be crowded but luckily there were only 3 people ahead of us.  I think the only reason why the line would move slow is because the staff are so nice they encourage you to try some of the flavors before buying.  The line would move a little slower, but at least they aim for customer satisfaction.

The flavors we tried were the Vietnamese coffee, which was probably one of the tastiest coffee-flavored ice-cream one can encounter, and the Secret Breakfast, which I anticipated a lot of crunch from the corn flakes but didn't get too much of it, but the bourbon flavor was definitely there.  I'm not sure if I actually had a buzz or if the bourbon was so strong it might have just been psychological.  The flavors were true to their name and the texture was perfect.  

I think we got there at the right time because at about 8:15pm, the line started to grow outside the door...but it's well worth it.
author: Raymond L.

description:
I LOVE ice cream and i try to have it as often as i can.  I've now been to Humphry Slocombe four times, and i can easily say that i am a big fan of the ice cream. 

I've tried...

1). Double Scoop... Tahitian Vanilla and Secret Breakfast
2). Single Scoop... Blue Bottle Coffee
3). Single Scoop... Salt and Pepper
4). Double Scoop...Tahitian Vanilla and Magnolia Cypress Brown Ale

As you approach the selection, you can not help but be intrigued and excited about the names alone.  The folks behind the counter are super friendly, so take your time "tasting" the varied selection.  

After your first taste, you can not help but comment something like..."oh yeah... that's blue bottle coffee" OR... "oh yeah... i can really taste the Brown Ale in this."

The ice cream is creamy and the portions are perfect.  You can sit inside on the counter and watch people as they come in, sit outside on the sidewalk, or go for a walk in the colorful mission neighborhood.  JUST GET THERE AND GET SOME ICE CREAM.

I love this place and look forward to tasting ALL of the flavors (they change daily).

BTW... CASH ONLY
author: saum z.

description:
Sure, we cursed the hipsters when we arrived, but in this case it's because they're making the line so long. When I got to the counter I figured out why the line is so long. You've never heard of their flavors, so you're going to need to sample a few. And a few more. It makes sense that if you're going to pay that much for a scoop of ice cream, they want to make sure you get ones you actually like. Kudos for the customer service. 

The ladies in our the house love the Salt and Pepper (not for me), I dug the Cinnamon Brittle, and we all agreed the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee made the wait worthwhile. 

A great place to explore when you're up for an adventure.
author: Michael N.

description:
mmmmm...thai coffee ice cream under secret breakfast. 

straight to my ice cream stomach. yumms. inventive and friendly service, the line is well worth it I believe.
author: Orian I.

description:
Humphry. 

This place needs to have two lines.
One line for the indecisive, first-timers, you know, the serial-samplers, pointing at all the different ice cream flavors.

The second line for those who know what they want. Like myself. After reading Genevieve Y's review and her listing of all the flavors (thanks =)) I knew I had to try to the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee. It was amazing. 

The rest I'll need to try some other time: Guinness flavored ice cream, Secret breakfast (that one I got a sample of and it was incredible), and the oolong tea.

I like this place. It's different. I wonder if the owner was really poor at some point, opened his cupboard and decided to make ice cream flavors out of whatever he had: olive oil, balsamic vinegar, oolong tea, some Guinness from the fridge. Whatever he did works. I'll be coming back.
author: Vanessa W.

description: I came here because of the hype. Prosciutto ice cream?!?!? I love all porky products and boy did this place deliver. The flavors are not for those who probably like Baskin Robbins. These flavors are imaginative and inventive. They challenge your taste buds and really push the envelope on the whole ice cream experience.
author: Tess R.

description: Loved the Ice Cream...very tasty; creamy; yummy...I would give 5 stars if the service is not so slow.  It always a line in front of the store.  If they can improve the service...provide more help...then I will give a 5 stars.
author: Ally M.

description:
Yep. My new #1 ice cream place in San Francisco.

I still love Mitchells, Bi-Rite, and anywhere else....

but this takes it.

secret breakfast, cream cheese and chocolate chip, PEANUT BUTTER-CURRY, thai chili lime, salt & pepper, mc evoy olive oil, valhrona fudgsicle, vietnamese coffee....

YUMMY.

and.......wait for it....... BACON PEANUT BRITTLE! (not ice cream)

environmentally friendly cups, bowls, spoons.....super nice service! free samples....nice bathroom

cash only

twitter to get new flavor updates....can't wait to try hibiscus beet!
author: Kelley N.

description: I came here during a random Friday lunch in the city = no wait. It was fun to try several flavors before settling on brown sugar fennel. IMO, the texture of Humphry's ice creams is a little bit more icy than Bi-Rite's. Although it was interesting to taste test the more adventurous flavors at Humphry, Bi-Rite has my vote.
author: Mindy C.

description:
So I'm aware that I'm in the minority here, but I'll post anyway. I had previously tasted their olive oil ice cream at the farmer's market, and it was better then I thought it would be. This time I stood in line and tried tastes of four different flavors: balsamic caramel, coconut sherbet, milk chocolate passionfruit, and a miso pear flavor. The balsamic caramel was good, but I don't like caramel so I couldn't imagine eating a scoop of strongly flavored caramel ice cream. The coconut was decent, but not mind blowing. The other two were too salty. I don't know that I've thought ice cream was salty before, but these definitely were.
