I guess I just prefer my traditional ice cream to these gourmet flavors. I think some flavors are done well, but I'm usually looking for flavors from my childhood when I want some ice cream. So what flavor did I end up getting? Nothing. Yup that's right, I just ended up walking out. The guy behind the counter looked a bit surprised, and I'm probably the first person to go there and not get ice cream. I may have ordered the coconut if they sold by the scoop, but the single has two scoops.
author: Humaira M.

description:
Let me start out by saying if you drive too fast you might miss it!  This business does not boaster a huge sign of any sort it's just the cutest little neighborhood ice cream joint that prides itself on being "different"...truly different.  Their flavors include Ancho Chocolate, Balsamic Caramel (for you true balsamic fans), & the Secret Breakfast (my favorite).

La la land is where you're going to be after trying this.

......almost forgot:  CASH ONLY!!!
author: Stacy L.

description:
I love ice cream. A lot.

I also love odd and intense flavors. 

For a long time, I resisted checking out Humphry Slocombe because I don't need that many extra calories, but I started following them on twitter, and the temptation just became too much.

I've since been there twice, and had the same experience: the flavors were pretty good at first, but quickly became bland on the tongue. If you're brave enough to put peanut butter and curry into ice cream, or prosciutto, for heaven's sakes really DO IT. The flavors were too mild for me, in other words, and I'm going to save my temptations for elsewhere.
author: Beth W.

description:
Guiness ginger bread, buttermilk, balsamic caramel, secret breakfast, ancho chocolate, brown butter, I don't even know where to start...  It's always an overload of excitement and indecision to go in here   (I keep hoping that one day they'll have the government cheese flavor listed on the website!  And I've always missed the corn one when they've had it, too :(  )

In fact, the only misfire, IMO has been the salt and peppa, which was just a bit too salty for my taste.  (And this from someone who loves salty yogurt and buttermilk drinks)

It's a good thing I live 3,097 miles from them so that they're special occasion food for binges when I'm out visiting, or I'd be in serious need of a diet right about now... :)
author: Adam A.

description: Humphrey Slocombe is my favorite ice cream place in the city because it's not afraid to be totally out there.  In the world of bespoke ice cream, this place goes out of their way to get some of the strangest flavors and they do it with flair.  The location is a little less than desirable but I'll continue to trek there just to get a morsel of the Secret Breakfast (cornflakes + bourbon = heaven) and Vietnamese ice coffee.
author: Karen N.

description:
I would give this place like a 3.5 -- but it's hard to say if, without the hype, I would have rated it higher. I had eagerly anticipated this place ever since reading about it a while back -- I'm a sucker for curiously-flavored ice cream--the stranger the flavor, the more tempted I am to try it.

After overhearing one ice cream buyer commenting on how the peanut butter curry tasted more like curry than peanut butter, I became a bit gun shy. Instead of ordering the Boccolone Proscuitto or Salt and pepper ice cream flavors (can we say Bertie Bott's, anyone), I instead opted for the more common vietnamese iced coffee and secret breakfast, and my bf tried Jesus Juice (wine and coke flavor). To me, the flavors could have been pushed just a little bit more with a more harmonious balance between the flavors. The Jesus juice tasted like a cabernet coke slush. Secret breakfast tasted like bourbon and cream (could use more crunchy corn flakes), and vietnamese coffee (which was my favorite of the 3), tasted like a really creamy coffee ice cream w/some coffee grounds sprinkled in.

The concept is great, the ice cream is good, and they don't totally rape you on the price or scoop size. But I guess for all the hype, I was expecting something mind-blowing.
author: Sabine S.

description:
My favorite ice cream in the city (thus far, and I've tried most).  Their flavor combinations are creative and spot-on.  Prosciutto?  Bourbon?  Microbrews?  Balsamic?  Chevre?  
OH YES.

I've not found the lines too long and the folks scooping are friendly.

I do think it's hilarious that one time out of 12 flavors I could only offer my kids 2 in good concience due to high alcohol or caffeine content in the remaining 10.  Absolutely perfect.
author: Laura K.

description:
When we last left our heroes they were leaving Specchio in search of ice-creamy goodness (http://www.yelp.com/biz/specchio-san-francisco#hrid:8yzr1NljvH5AGBKaX0tNPA). Read on to find out what happens next.

In short, bright white walls, chrome and red leather stools in front of a counter, a little kitty waving at you and mood-altering ice cream. 

I sampled a few different ones, liked 'em all, settled on the salt 'n' peppa and on the recommendation of the scooper paired it with the Vietnamese coffee. The lady had the Oolong tea with the olive oyl. Holy moly, it was good- the flavours subtle yet distinct, the texture smooth and creamy. It came to $6.50 for the two of us, which is not bad.

While sitting in the window we saw this guy leaving, cone in hand, looking at his ice-cream, positively beaming. Hurrah for ice-cream that makes us this happy. They should hold international summits at ice-cream parlours.
author: S K.

description: Superb secret Breakfast and Fudgecicle flavours really stood out, this is a cut-above most ice-cream shops!
author: Alec M.

description:
1. If you are going to name your flavors something obscure such as Secret Breakfast don't roll your eyes at me when I ask what is in it.
2. If you're going to have a bunch of of obscure flavors don't get annoyed when I want to sample more than 2 flavors when I am buying 2 pints.
3. Please don't act as if you are doing me a favor but allowing me to purchase something for you.
4. Do you really need to let me know you are annoyed that I "made" you hand pack a pint by sighing and sucking your teeth intermittently?
5. I put salt on my potato chips so if I find your ice cream salty it is extremely salty. Both the Pumpkin and Gingerbread ice cream were salty.
6. The Fluffernutter was also salty which is not so egregious since it is PB but I really couldn't tell there were any marshmallow in at all and it could use some texture (Nutter Butter cookies or nuts or mallow ripple would have helped.)
7. The Lemon Buttermilk sorbet was also salty and icy with bad consistency and lacked a pronounced lemon flavor
8. The line is slow because everyone needs lots of tastes because all the flavors are unusual and change all the time.

I don't see how the owners are going to turn a profit on poorly executed edgy flavors with too-hip-to-serve-you staff. I actually threw away the entire pint of Lemon sorbet after two bites and I never throw away ice cream. The Flutternutter pint was not inedible but usually my husband and I can polish off a pint in one sitting and there is still a half pint in the freezer after a few weeks.

Thank you for not using disposable tasting spoons and using Strauss Organics but.....

I'm just not that impressed.
author: Kim L.

description:
This is a review by a vegetarian

The Vietnamese blue bottle coffee is excellent.
The balsamic caramel is a failed experiment. The caramel notes are fine but.. acid with dairy?? I guess I should have accepted the proffered taste before ordering. Also, this flavor melts faster than the others.

Vegetarians be on alert: there is bacon about.

I like the counter with the swivel chairs for instant eating in solitary with no distractions.
author: Bob R.

description:
With rich, novel flavors like Vietnamese Blue Bottle Coffee and Harvey Milk & Graham, it's no surprise that this tiny sequestered shop still sees long lines and a full house most weekends. With quick, friendly service though, these long lines move fast.

My personal favorite is the vietnamese blue bottle coffee, but the rotating selection is what really keeps things interesting.
author: Alvin Y.

description: Another gourmet ice cream joint found! I think it's pretty comparable to Bi-Rite or Mitchell's. They have some pretty unique flavors, like their vanilla lavender (which I tasted tested and it was pretty dang good), but I opted for the simple Blue Bottle coffee flavored one which was oh-so-yummy and creamy. :)
author: Emy s.

description: Really unique flavors. I had the red hot banana (banana ice cream with bits of red hots) and it was really good! Their honey thyme was amazing. I think I'll try their basil lime sorbet next time.
author: Theresa M.

description:
I heard about Humphry Slocombe from co-workers & then I saw them on the Food Network (the outrageous eats show) and really wanted to go.  

On my first visit I got the Secret Breakfast & after a hard week it was really nice to have a sweet treat mixed with bourbon! 

The next time I went I had the smoked sea salt chocolate which was the perfect mix of sweet and salty. 

I love the metal tasting-spoons, very eco-friendly. 

My only gripe is the somewhat sketchy location... all the way down 24th (at least if you're walking.)
author: Jenna K.

description:
Eclectic, yet delicious ice cream shop

Surprisingly awesome- I highly suggest you try it!
author: Meggie M.

description:
This gets 5 stars simply because I can't get these flavors anywhere else.  No not even by that place by the park.  Not that I have anything against them. Their Blood orange sorbet, is probably the best sorbet I've EVER had).
 
The good thing about taking my daughter to soccer at Garfield  playground is that I have an excuse to stop and get to try all the new flavors, and since you never know what's going to be on the board, ya gotta keep going back.

While some of the flavors sound odd, I haven't had one that tasted bad. AND they let you taste them BEFORE you commit.  C'mon TRY SOMETHING new!

So far this is what I've had:
Guinness shortbread- Perfect on St. Patricks day
Secret Breakfast (shh) - Try it. It is as good as everyone says
Strawberry Jalapeno- Could've had a bit more jalepeno for me, but still good
Thai Chile Lime-  By far the BEST flavor EVER
Salt and Pepper- Just like it sounds
McEvoy Olive Oil- Surprisingly smooth
Valrhona fudgesicle- My kids stole this from me- couldn't blame them
Hibiscus Beet  Sorbet- Try it. Do it. NOW
Foie Gras & Ginger IC Sandwiches- Seriously, don't look at me like that!

And if they've got it while you're there, pick up some of the  Bacon Peanut Brittle as well. 

They get bonus points for the friendly staff and short lines.
author: Michael M.

description:
I've acquired this addiction to frozen treats.  Rain or shine, heat wave or freezing, I have to have my ice cream or froyo.  I usually finish a large froyo even before we make it back walking to the car.

Humphy Slocombe changed the way I ate ice cream.  I took time to cherish every flavor as it tickled my taste buds.  Call me boring, but I wasn't feeling the odd flavors such as balsalmic caramel.  I do love that  Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee flavor and the Secret Breakfast which has a great bourbon flavor.  Do try.  Next stop, Birite for comparision.
author: Bert N.

description:
My unorthodox-ice cream-flavor-virginity has been popped. Waiting in line really made me even more excited to try the different flavors since we kept getting wafts of waffle and chocolate. Tried the olive oil (unusual, but not bad) peanut butter curry (pretty good) and ended up getting the Secret Breakfast (solid A) and the Honey Thyme (B-.) Got a lot of honey, but no thyme (har har) until the end - but even then wasn't too impressed. 

Can't wait to come back for more!
author: Vicki L.

description: Shout out to all my lactose intolerant homeboys and home girls out there! Luckily Humphry Slocombe serves a couple of dairy-free options. On the particular day I went, they offered Jesus Juice (red wine sorbet) and a lemon sorbet. I sampled both but not being a huge red wine fan, it was unsurprising that I opted for the lemon.  The sorbet was good - creamy and flavorful. I find that sorbet frequently is too icy which makes me even more depressed about not being able to eat real ice cream. Thanks Humphry Slocombe for providing a bit of consolation!
author: Courtney C.

description: Possibly my favourite place to get ice cream in the Bay Area. The flavour combinations may seem absurd but they work well and they always rotate new flavours. I would probably expect a long wait but it isn't for naught.
author: M C.

description:
* Olive Oil + Hibiscus Beet Sorbet = 5 stars combo
* White Miso Pear + Pistachio Bacon = yummy too!
* Foie Gras Ice Cream on Ginger Snaps - Ginger Snaps = can I lick the bowl?
author: Katie K.

description: BUTTER BEER flavor is one of the best icecream I've ever tasted.  It tasted very unique and buttery.  Very very buttery (flavor, not texture).  I couldn't detect the beer flavor but my friend said she did.  I'll be going back and get a pint size next time.  I also had Eden Mess (strawberry meringue) ---- also VERY good --- slightly salty strawberry icecream.  Very strong strawberry flavor!  And i had blue bottle vietnamese coffee flavor which i thought was just OK.  Tasted like strong vietnamese coffee, nothing unique.
author: Jessica N.

description: I absolutely love this place! I seriously think I'm going to die of high cholesterol and whatever else is wrong with eating as much ice cream from here as I do. So far my favorite is the secret breakfast! How can you go wrong with Bourbon and cornflakes? I always look forward to all the different flavors and their quirky names. I recently tried their pear and miso ice cream and that was delish! I can't wait to come back!
author: Diane M.

description: MUST TRY. the consistency of their ice cream is unparalleled and their unique flavors are cool too!
author: H K.

description: Secret Breakfast is one of the best ice cream flavors in the city. I pass by it everyday and it's hard to walk by without stopping to get a scoop. The line can get long on nice days, but wait it out, it's worth it!
author: Deepi S.

description:
If you're a parent then you are accustomed to the ever so fun decision making process of children, particularly ones under the age of six.

Enter Humphry Slocombe:  "Son, would you like vanilla, Thai chili lime or vinegar and caramel?"  

Unique.  Straight forward storefront and you can follow them on twitter and they'll let you know when they have a new flavor and will NOT tweet about things like "Hey, sweeping the floor waiting to get off work".

Twitter: humphryslocombe 

Nope, don't work there, just another zealot.

-------------
Ancho Chocolate - WOW!
author: Roque V.

description:
This ice cream will for sure evoke some emotion in you.  While eating it, I couldn't stop quietly moaning.  

Had the olive oil and oolong tea.  Huge fan of both.  Only $3.25 for 2 generous scoops.

Even if this place was a shithole, I'd still skip tra-la-la all the way there.

Need I say more??
author: Liezl C.

description:
I put off writing a review because for some delusional reason I thought that would stop hoards of people from crowding this place... but I guess the cat's out of the bag and Secret Breakfast isn't a secret anymore with 1400+ reviews. hah, silly me.

Really, I do wish I knew their secret!
How do they keep the cornflake like crunchiness when it's IN the ice cream?!

hmmmm.... well in the mean time, I'll just have to enjoy it and wonder.
author: Angel L.

description:
Artisanal ice cream executed w/ valor & pizazz. A really really lovely experience all around.

I came for the salt & pepper ice cream, which was unfortunately out of rotation on that Sunday afternoon. I did however sample the balsamic caramel and Secret Breakfast (I was eyeballing the coffee one too, but I felt like a douchebag asking for yet another sample). The former was deliciously tangy and earthy, while the latter contained a little too much bourbon for my palette (the alcohol taste is NOT subtle, people... if you think it is, it might be time to put the bottle down). 

Ultimately, I settled on the pistachio bacon and the olive oil flavors. My favorite was definitely the olive oil, with delicate hints of orange and a slightly viscous, velvety texture (while maintaining it's creamy integrity). Normally I detest pistachio ice cream, but Slocombe's version is in a class of it's own. It has great balance and is vaguely reminiscent of a salted spumoni.  My homegirl gobbled down the equally impressive Valrhona fudgesicle, highly recommended for our vegetarian amigos out there.

The ladies behind the counter were patient, knowledgeable, and accommodating with all our sampling requests. Indeed, they also suggested informed flavor pairings.

For those of you who think $3.50 is too much for 2 delicious scoops of gourmet ice cream, Rite Aid eagerly awaits your return.

As for the guy who referred to Slocombe as more "vanilla" than Bi-Rite -- Foooo, you MUST be trippin'. Slocombe CRUSHES Bi-Rite in flavor intensity and innovation.

I will be back for the Foie-Ginger contraption, and hopefully the Thai Chili-Lime will be back around sooner or later too (hint hint).
author: Matthew H.

description:
+super courteous servers!  they were so nice even though it was already 8:45 (near closing) :)
+yummy ice cream :)
+chain on the door was a nice way to say "we're closed" without blocking exiting folks
+pepper and mint chip had a great kick yumm 

Definitely get the coke float. Definitely.
author: Margaret S.

description: The salt and pepper ice cream punished my taste buds for a few seconds. It was nice to be able to try the ice creams before I committed to them. I ended up with the Harvey Milk and Honey ice cream, as well as the Secret Breakfast. I absolutely love the Harvey Milk and Honey because you could really taste the milk and the honey haha plus  it has grahammy bits in there that I enjoyed immensely.In the  Secret Breakfast, you can taste the bourbon, and it was also delicious. It is a bit small in there, but it is only an ice cream shop. Despite the cold San Francisco weather, people were lining up around the block for this chilly destination! I heard they have butter beer ice cream here, but they do change their flavors so I didn't get any.......=(!
author: Tammy L.

description:
Best part was the older woman behind me who very happily ordered a scoop of secret breakfast. YAY for old booze hounds. 

Secret breakfast was a bit too bourbon-y for me so I ended up with jesus juice, a magical combination of coke and red wine. Did I mention that this was my second ice cream trip of the day? I had to get a sorbet or risk dying of a heart attack. I had a bit of my friend's black sesame, which was sooooo good!
author: Angela S.

description:
Humphry Slocombe is such a mouthful that I usually refer it as "that ice cream place we still haven't been to."  Finally we made a trip out to the mysterious Harrison and 23rd street, in a neighborhood that looks like what Mission would have looked like before it gentrified.   The streets are lined with beautiful trees, taquerias and coffee shops.  An ice cream shop seems to be an excellent addition.  

Despite its huge popularity, it was pretty empty when we arrived around dinner time on a Sunday night.  I was looking forward to try Oolong (I did my research online) but it wasn't one of the 8 or so options available.  So instead I tried Secret Breakfast and Blue Bottle Vietnamese coffee.  Both were delicious so I got them in a cup.  

A single is quite generous, for a little over $3.  The Secret Breakfast wasn't something I'd expect myself to like, since I was never adventurous when it comes to ice cream flavors.  But it was really delicious!  It tastes a bit like a bowl of cereal and milk, but with more intense flavors, and by intense flavors, I mean, there's bourbon in it.  

Vietnamese coffee was delicious also.  Both were airy and really sweet.  My husband had the secret breakfast and nectarine/blueberry.  Nectarine/blueberry was pretty light in flavors and sorta resembles a Noah's blueberry bagel.  

Anyway, I am excited that there is yet another wonderful ice cream shop in San Francisco that offers interesting, experimental flavors!
author: Candice B.

description:
Last weekend, Mike and I went to the city to have brunch and dessert with some of the best friends ever. Humphry Slocombe is worth it for the entertainment factor alone--and it doesn't hurt that the ice cream is pretty good. We tried Balsamic Caramel, Secret Breakfast, Blackberry (?) Cobbler, and Vietnamese (?) Coffee.

The Balsamic Caramel was worth a try just to see how they would do it. It was delicious, but after a few licks, I could have been done.
Mike got the Secret Breakfast (bourbon and cornflakes), and we loved it. The consistency was excellent, and it got finished right away.

Next time, we want to try Sweet Corn.
author: Gabriella H.

description:
I don't think I have ever been to a ice cream shop that had funky flavor names such as peanut butter curry. Surprisingly, most of them actually taste like what their names are.  They had a special called kitten fetal which kind of scared me. I ended up getting the secret breakfast to be safe.

Different, weird, but good.
author: David W.

description:
If you're into the whole "interestingly named ice cream flavors" craze, then going here will get your wheels turning. My sister wanted to go here just to try out these crazy flavors and I think it was worth it. 

Have no fear: they let you taste what you want. I first tasted the olive oil flavor which, not really strangely, tastes like olive oil. I think I was just stunned that these things all tasted like what they were called. Kind of like those Harry Potter jelly beans, though I doubt that they'll have flavors like vomit and earwax.

None the less, what I ended up getting a single of the fudgsicle flavor and the balsamic caramel. And let me tell you: this is a bad combo. While both were good on their own, together they do not go well. The balsamic caramel was way too sweet, and it was just painful for me to eat at the end. If it wasn't for my sister's secret breakfast and vietnamese tea (? I think that's what it was called), I would have called this visit a bust. 

Besides that... I had a good time, and i'm willing to go back for more. I did enjoy their freshly baked chocolate chip cookies and their old school decor. Very cool.
author: Caroline L.

description:
The flavors are interesting, and original, and in the case of secret
breakfast, they're even good. Odds and ends, like the bacon brittle
are also pretty good. And hey, the girls who work the counter are
pretty cute.


Why the four stars? It's just not that great. Yeah, interesting, creative,
original, fresh, cool, hip, etc, etc. In the end, Mitchel's just makes better
ice cream.  Smoother, tastier, any way you slice it, Slocombe is just
not as good.


On the other hand it's better than most every other icecream in the
city, with the possible exception of Bi-Rite; they're about on the
same level.
author: Max R.

description:
Valrhona Fudgsicle and Malted Dulce De Leche made my Friday afternoon. Creamy and flavorful, I was so happy with each spoonful. I wish the scoop cost $3.00 instead of $3.25--it just looks like it should be less because it is on the smaller side. 

They also have a few baked goods like cookies and brownies. I got a chocolate ship cookie that would be just right for a future coffee.

Clean and simple shop with some chairs outside. Perfect for a warm day. I love that they are eco-conscious and use compostable cups and spoons.
author: Kat H.

description:
Blah blah blah ice cream is awesome blah.

BACON PEANUT BRITTLE.  It's hidden off to the side on a shelf.  Do yourself a favor and get some.  Amazing.  Next time, I'll have to try the lard caramels sitting right next to the brittle...

Oh and I wasn't belittling the ridiculous awesomeness of Secret Breakfast and Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee with my "blah blah."  I just know you've heard it a skillion times by now.  But worth mentioning: Limoncello.  Yum.  Also, if you can manage to just order Vanilla, their Tahitian Vanilla is perhaps the best vanilla ice cream anywhere.
author: Caitlin M.

description:
Incredible, life-altering, delicious.

The peanut butter curry ice cream is as yummy as it is complex, and everything else I've ever tried is really unique and really, really good.
author: Andrew L.

description:
I have been checking by every so often for Humphry Slocombe's arrival. It was really the draw of foie gras ice cream that had me, but I was happy to sample most of the available flavors on their opening day (12/30/08). I enjoyed the Guinness gingerbread with sizable chunks of gingerbread cookies. I also liked the Thai chili lime which would make for an interesting dessert after an Asian meal. Many people are reporting that they loved the balsamic caramel but that one fell a little flat for me. As a clear alcohol drinker, I was surprised to find that I liked the secret breakfast, with bourbon and cornflakes. 

The place is neat as a pin inside with a slight retro air of cuteness. The pay as you wish Radiohead mentality on opening day was nice as were the free cookie samples and supersweet counter service. I'll be back to check out what they come up with as time goes on. A welcome addition to the neighborhood.
author: Candice L.

description: Humphry Slocombe is a place you have to try at least once in your life.  The Blue Bottle Coffee flavor is my favorite, but the flavor is so rich I can never finish my scoop.
author: Alessandra S.

description:
This is better than Bi-Rite. And this is better than Mitchell's (which is better than Bi-Rite). And it makes me angry to see that people think otherwise. Yes, they can be compared. It's still all ice cream, made from the same basic ingredients. People instantly dismiss it as a novelty, and then claim Bi-Rite is better. But no. Feel the texture in your mouth. It's like no other ice cream you've had. Get the Tahitian Vanilla. Nothing fancy, just the best vanilla ice cream ever. If you're not adventurous, don't get an adventurous flavor. There's always at least one tame flavor on the menu. No one's forcing you to eat prosciutto ice cream, so don't order it and complain if you don't like that type of stuff.

I almost wonder if people come here set on bringing this place down and intentionally order the least appetizing flavor so they can say Bi-Rite is better.
author: Mark A.

description:
I just had a cone of the Double Chocolate Stout and I'm seriously thinking of coming back at 4PM for a Double Chocolate Stout float!

This place is dabomb but sometimes I feel like I'm cheating on St. Francis Fountain...
author: Jason S.

description: Love love love this place!!! Secret breakfast is my ish!!! Definitely have to try the float! The blue bottle coffee is also another one of my favorite. All the other flavors are awesome too and you could try each flavor to find your own
author: Alda H.

description:
Exclude the fact that something as interesting as this gives you ample counts of calories.  This ice cream parlor has done it right with its heavy dosages of gourmet flavors like pepper and salt, secret breakfast (cornflakes and bourbon), and vietnamese coffee.  I'm jumping quickly on the bandwagon for this crew of folks who know how to make that sweet tooth hurt like a mo'fo.
Thumbs up to you guys...I can't wait to try all the other flavors with those cute little metal spoons.  
It's a nice trip out to 24th and it's still relatively unknown.  Unlike Bi-Rite which is right next to the park, on a sunny day, ride that bike to this place and you won't have to wait in line.  It's open every day until 8pm, even on Sundays (when you really need that sweet punch to the mouth!). 
Dessert is fun to eat again!!!
author: felix c.

description:
I generally lurk around yelp and never get around to writing any reviews (whoops?) but I'm breaking my rule for this one.

5 stars for the staff alone. They were incredibly nice, despite the massively long lines (seriously, out the door) and that was pretty remarkable.

So here's my story--
I was happily consuming my (Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee flavored) ice cream cone and I guess I was a little overzealous and my ice cream fell!!! Luckily, the lady behind the counter witnessed the tragic event and kindly gave me a whole new scoop (+ cone).

If this isn't grounds for returning, I'm not sure what is.
author: arthi r.

description:
#45. Secret Breakfast  on the Big Eat SF list (2010)

gotta love sf and their crazy ice creameries that keep thinkin' up new flavors. and the usual eco friendly cups and composting areas.

secret breakfast is bourbon + cornflakes. 
funny thing is i mistook the scribble on the glass to be "bon bons" so  I was in for a surprise on that first bite ;o) but still good!

glad they have a "kid" size of one scoop.

also, caramel balsamic (tasted) was very balsamic... too bad they were out of peanut butter curry, that would have been interesting! checked out their postcard... I can't wait to try the gingerbread one.
author: S V.

description:
It was love at first lick!  Seriously, these guys are Geniuses, (that's right, with a capital G.) I was visiting San Fran while on tour with my dance company and a friend I was visiting advised me to try, no, insisted I not leave California until I try the ice cream at Humphry Slocombe. Well I was glad she did. I had their famous "Secret Breakfast" flavor which is burbon Ice cream with corn flake cookie bits. I enjoyed every last drop.
Once got back home to NY I bought their book which divulges their not so secret recipes in a voice that I appreciate as witty, humorous and real. My first trials from the book were Strawberry Jalapeno and  Pepper & Mint Chip. Both had more flavor than any other homemade ice cream recipe I'd tried in the past. The Strawberry Jelepeno could have been spicier (next time I might leave the seeds in for some extra heat) but the Pepper & Mint Chip was out of this world amazing. Can't wait to try more flavors.
Keep up the good work HS!!!
author: Abbey R.

description:
Any place that can make prosciutto taste good when it's cold and creamy gets 5 stars. Paired that with balsamic/caramel.  Nice.

Second time I went I had secret breakfast + blue bottle vietnamese coffee.  Fab. Guy behind me ordered the coffee with a scoop of olive oil.  Don't know if that is a sophisticated palate, or just kinda gross...

I almost got Rosemary's Baby + Olive Oil.  The Rosemary was INTENSE. A scoop would have been a lot, imo.  

Friendly servers aren't annoyed when you want to try like, every flavor ;)
author: Michelle L.

description: The best!  Our favorite ice cream here in the neighborhood.  Two words: Secret. Breakfast.  Flavors come and go, which adds to the tasting fun.  Salt and Pepper really has salt and pepper (I didn't like this one, but talk about dedication!). Right after John Hughes died, there was a Pretty in Pink flavor.  Line out the door, so line up!
author: John D.

description:
Not your typical ice cream parlor. They only have about 12 different flavors but they're definitely more unique than any I've ever seen before.  It was our first visit so after trying the Boccalone Prosciutto (yes, ice cream - eh, it was kinda weird), Pepper-mint chip (contained black pepper), among others, I ended up with a scoop of the famous Secret Breakfast - doesn't really taste like breakfast like you would expect, but the buttery taste of bourbon and crunch of the corn flakes made for a pretty unique ice cream flavor. Hubby got the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee - one of the best coffee ice creams I've ever tried. 

The ice creams are super rich and creamy - a kid's size is the perfect amount. They change flavors often so we must keep going back!
author: Amy H.

description:
Secret breakfast is great. Everything else is weird. The pb curry is pretty good but I don't want an entire serving of it.

Middle of nowhere
author: Christopher L.

description:
Never in my right mind would I ever have thought that I would dream of ice cream day in and day out.

Every single morsel of ice cream is deeply infused with an attention to detail that is unrivaled.

Thai lime chile - what a journey: start with a big of tang, a bit of brightness on the midpalate finishing with a jolt of spicy freshness. WOW.

Secret breakfast - won't be a secret much longer. This flavor is whimsical and inventive. Each cornflake is as crunchy as if it came straight out of the cereal box. And be forewarned: if you eat this in the car, pray that you do not get pulled over. The nose of bourbon will infuse your immediate surroundings whether you like it or not!

coconut - as rich and refreshing as a freshly opened young cocunut, without the fear of losing your hand to a over zealous machete chop.

When I went with a friend, it was pay what you wish. I will gladly give Humphry Slocombe all the money in my pocket for a scoop of whatever they make. 

Well played, gentlemen.
author: Harrison M.

description: I gotta say, a lot of their flavors are just not very good, and their basic supplies for things like hot fudge and whipped cream are kind of gross.  I wish they'd try to get the basics right before they work on the next crazy flavor.
author: Daniel W.

description: The secret breakfast was nasty... i'm sorry, I just don't get how people like it. The liquor flavor is way too overpowering.
author: Julie W.

description: Yum!  Secret breakfast (cornflakes and bourbon) is definitely the one.  I bit pricey, but things that stand out from the pack these days usually are.  Best in the city.
author: chris w.

description: Secret breakfast is all you will ever need! Always try the flavors as they want you to try them all and most flavors rotate every week or so but Secret Breakfast goes no where. Every time im in SF im here!
author: Matthew H.

description: Ice cream was just ok, kind of disappointing after hearing all the hype about this place. I sampled a few before making my decision. The secret breakfast was what I was looking forward to trying the most, but after just one little spoonful, I felt like my entire mouth was coated with a layer of butterfat. Tried a few more flavors and finally settled with peanut butter curry and Vietnamese coffee. PB&Curry was really good at first, but then after a while I just felt like I was licking a cold stick of butter again :( I think the flavors of their ice creams are on point but I wish they didn't leave that awful feeling in my mouth. The plus side of this place was the delightful service and cute-sy charm of the ice cream parlor. In terms of ice cream, I guess Bi-Rite will always be #1 in my heart :)
author: Krizia M.

description: Most of the flavors were a little too sophisticated for my taste buds.  But the Chocolate Smoked Sea Salt was so good that I wanted to go back for seconds almost immediately after I finished my first cone.  Yum!  And speaking of cones, the sugar cone was particularly fresh giving the ice cream a nice crunch.
author: Kristin P.

description:
This place is very cute, very shop-around the corner like. 

My friend and I came here on a weekday in the middle of a really dreary day. It was the store's birthday, so they had free cake. That was great, I doo love cake. 

Anyway, on to the ice cream. Honestly, anyone who knows me knows that I am freakishly obsessed with Bi-Rite Creamery and am on a mission to conclude that Bi-Rite is, in fact, the best creamery in Northern California.

Anyway, I ordered the Secret Breakfast, which was very delicious. I can't even remember the other flavor I ordered, but that tells me it wasn't nearly that memorable enough for me to recall what it was.

My friend ordered the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee, and he thought it was fantastic.

I just don't like the texture of really creamy ice creams. Humphry is one of those creamy creamy places. The Secret Breakfast was really interesting; it had corn flakes in it, I think.

I would go again, but it's not something I would have a huge craving for or really bring many people to.
author: stacy c.

description: We picked up a pint of Secret Breakfast and two spoons. Delicious! and this flavor is oddly refreshing. Can't wait to try more, peanut butter curry, you're next!
author: Claire b.

description: Loved the Pepper-Mint, light and subtle. The Ancho-Chocolate-watch out. It's innocent at first, but it has a heavy punch at the end.
author: Helen L.

description: i've had the curry peanut butter, the thai lime something, the salt and pepper, secret breakfast...what else? i'm gonna keep coming back. this is my kind of ic joint. i love everything about it, execution, concept, location, decor of space, salespeople...what do you want?  the limited selection that always switches it up, the straightforward flavors (meaning, salt and pepper ice cream actually tasted like THAT), the serving size, the simple space, blah blah blah...the stars speak
author: Rrrona 7.

description:
This place is definitely starting out as a 5 star... Really great attitude about their first week -- super friendly with a pay what you want pricing structure until after their "soft" opening.
The stars were indeed the ice cream. As everyone says secret breakfast is awesome. I tasted 6 or 7 flavors (I shared them... really... I'm only partially piggy). Was very pleasantly surprised by the thai lime chile. The guinness w/ gingerbread was nice but a bit on the sweet side.
The cookie they gave us was also awesome. I loved the decor and the service was beyond friendly. Will definitely go back and can't wait to try more of their flavors.
author: Margie L.

description:
one might thought going to an ice cream shop on a wet and dreary rainy day isn't the best idea - let me tell you this place had pretty much non stop business while I was there - for about an hour middle of a lazy sunday afternoon...

Humphry Slocombe is a quaint little ice cream shop with about 8 stools so you can sit by the window, chat with your friends and watch the world go by outside. I saw a lady with a full safeway paper bag on her head proudly walking in the rain - riduculous or not, her hair was not going to be crazy rained out.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

they had me at bacon.

having never been here, but have yelped this place, i know that they offer unconventional type of flavors - but i was a bit shocked at the bravery of a place that doesn't offer you anything plain and simple. they make a statement with their unique flavors, and boy is the statement unique.

amongst the other flavors mentioned, I had to try the pistachio bacon, and the balsamic caramel. WOW.

i love pistachio ice cream - but don't bother looking for chunky greasy bits of bacon here - the smokey bacon flavor comes through - but does not overpower, the pistachio ice cream. The bacon layers a quiet but strong undercurrent of flavor here (flavor only, not texture)... i can eat this all day long.

the balsamic caramel SOUNDS like it can possibly go wrong... however, upon tasting this, i had to get a full scoop. it's so COMPLEX... the SLIGHT tanginess of the balsamic, the rich, buttery taste of caramel, combined together so that with every single spoonful, the ice cream tastes different - it's a chameleon that surprises in depth with every bite.

I didn't try the Secret Breakfast, or the Beet Sorbet, or some of the other flavors. but definitely will do so next time i'm in the neighbourhood.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

this place is CASH ONLY. there's samples of the bacon peanut brittle for tasting (so good that i bought a pack to enjoy in private). it's a perfect getaway when you want to catch up with a friend and don't want to go to starbucks or yet another sit-down meal.
 
The service is friendly, and they are not grumpy about you trying all the flavors. the tasting spoon are real silverware (as supposed to plastic disponsible ones) - so you don't feel so bad having tried all the flavors.

this is one of my favorite ice cream places in SF, and definitely some place to take folks from out of town to amaze & impress. I know i was. Bravo!
author: amy c.

description:
after seeing all the great reviews, and also being an avid ice cream lover, i just HAD to drag booboo down here!

we sampled:
~jesus juice [red wine & coke]
~secret breakfast [bourbon & cornflakes]
~milk chocolate passion fruit 
~blue bottle vietnamese coffee
~salt & pepper

i ended up getting:
~blue bottle vietnamese coffee
~salt & pepper
~secret breakfast

he got:
~tangerine sorbet
~secret breakfast

the secret breakfast had a slight touch of bourbon, paired with the crisp crunch of cornflakes, yumm!  the blue bottle vietnamese coffee was delicious, sweet and slightly bitter, just the way i like my viet coffee!  the salt & pepper was interesting...starts out sweet and creamy, then hits with the pepper, and ends with a salty note.  i felt that the pepper was a bit too overwhelming, but the salt and pepper was delicious none the less :D  

the tangerine sorbet was so refreshing!  the dark chocolate passion fruit was good as well, the bitter sweetness of the dark chocolate and the tanginess of the passion fruit went well together :D 

the bottom line?  i love the crazy flavors and i want to try them all! xD
author: Dee W.

description: Mmm so rich and creamy, had the Brown Sugar & Fennel, and to my pleasant surprise the Fennel did not overpower the other flavors at all. Also tried the Vietnamese Coffee and Salted Chocolate, all were amazing but will definitely give the Secret Breakfast a try next time. In any other city Humphry would be a hands down 5 star, but in SF where the competition is high, I have to give Bi-Rite the top nod.
author: Renae K.

description:
I don't know if you've noticed, but the Mission is a war zone these days. It's Humphry versus Bi-Rite, Four Barrel versus Ritual, and every Mission establishment has got to pick a side. 

While I'm trying to remain impartial, I still treat Humphry like that perfect little secret it was on opening day when Adam and I accidentally stumbled in. From the loveliest staff to the pitch-perfect flavors (honey thyme tops my list), HS feels like my private, personal ice cream shop, regardless of how many reviews it gets, how popular it's become, and how many neighborhood businesses rally behind it as their ice cream champion (I'm looking at you, MSF, Spork, and the downtown Blue Bottle). 

My only wish? Stay open past 8:00 PM so I can enjoy some after dinner.
author: Carla C.

description: As much as this place gets made fun of for its thinking-outside-of-the-box flavors, I think the ice cream is tasty and I for one appreciate the creativity in their offerings. I had the Secret Breakfast and loved it, as well as the Vietnamese Ice Coffee. Will definitely be back for more fun flavors, hell yeah!
author: Donna A.

description:
POPULAR CASH ONLY ICE CREAM SHOP WITH UNUSUAL FLAVORS

I had to try this place because of the inventive ice cream flavors.  It was hard to decide with such flavors as balsamic caramel, pink grapefruit tarragon, and government cheese.

Secret Breakfast
I tried the secret breakfast (bourbon and corn flakes) and the combination worked.  I could really get addicted to this stuff.

Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee
I liked the intense coffee flavor.

 What a great way to start your day; corn flakes, bourbon, and coffee.
author: Rob L.

description:
There's an old-school almost apothecary sort of vibe when one enters.  Maybe it's the glossy pristine white walls and small hand-lettered signs scattered about.  Or maybe it's the extreme lighting.

We almost didn't see the fois gras ice cream sandwich sign, and to have missed that would have been extreme tragedy.
author: Mutant O.

description:
Good god.  I wake up in the middle of the night CRAVING the ice cream here.
For anyone that knows me, I have a serious/dangerous/ridiculous sweet tooth.  
I'm embarrassed to say that I've been here about 8 times in the past 4 days.
Shame.
Try it.  Love it.  All the flavors are incredible.
author: Meh M.

description:
no! hipsters all lined up on 24th street. yikes! i guess i've been in denial about the extent of the gentrification of my fair hometown. 

a few flavors were 'aite. but some tasted strangely similar, like they had the same base. and some were downright strange. granted i was there during beer week, so they had beer flavors. super gross. if i want bitter, i'd drink a beer, not eat ice cream. yeah, yeah, the coke float w bourbon and cornflake ice cream (aka special breakfast) WITH bourbon caramel (but doesn't caramel have cream? why does it look like karo korn syrup?!) did give me and my partner in crime inga m. a buzz. but i'm still not a fan of cornflakes in ice cream. (see! i'm bitter enuf, i don't need bitter ice cream!)

but not even a buzz could distract me from the surliness of the ice cream scoopers. okay, one dude gets mad props. he was tasting samples himself and clearing enjoying the fact that he was serving up cold sweet ice cream to the masses (did i mention the line of hipsters?), but one chick was a sourpuss. nary a pleasant word or a smile. and if you work at a ice cream shoppe, or a candy shoppe, or a cupcake shoppe, or a sex shoppe, anywhere where sweet fun is had, you are not allowed to be a grump. get over yourself and have a coke float. the buzz will carry you through the day!

i do like their cute tasting spoons.
author: Wanda D.

description: Sampled all the different flavors here on 11/11 and wasn't really impressed with any of them. Ended up ordering the secret breakfast, brown butta, and blue bottle vietnamese coffee. Meh!
author: Tony L.

description: This is pretty much what ice cream is all about.  Smooth and creamy, with whimsical flavors and unique takes on the traditional.  This is what makes San Francisco the hub of gastronomy that it is.  Secret Breakfast, Salted Chocolate...I could go on, and on, but I'd rather just have another scoop!
author: Toni C.

description: My review lies somewhere between and 3.5 and a 3.7. Don't get me wrong, the ice cream flavors are AMAZING (I got the Browned Butter and tried the Vietnamese Coffee, Secret Breakfast, Black Sesame, and Tahitian Vanilla), but the portion size in combination with the uber rich and decadent flavors tends to make my taste buds feel a bit strung out. I had a hard time enjoying the last few bites of my cup. So my advice would be to take someone (or 3 someones, in my case) so you can dabble in a bit of several different flavors. Oh and get your scoop(s) in a cone. You dont think its necessary but it definitely is.
author: Melinda L.

description:
I never thought Twitter had any practical use until I saw a sign in Humphry Slocombe stating that *yes* they "tweet" their flavor batches when they're ready!

Jesus Juice turned my mind inside out via my taste buds. Can't wait to visit again and bring friends. Who knew olive oil ice cream could melt in your mouth so good...(um, that's what she said.)
author: Kelly O.

description: Bourbon and cornflakes ice cream. If you think that's an awful idea; you're wrong.
author: Erich V.

description:
5 stars for unique ice cream .

Minus 2 stars for BAD ATTITUDE service .
Seriously, who stuck their dick up your ass today ?

Minus 1 star for really melty ice cream .

Plus 1 star for FREAKINGAWESOMEDERICIOUS cookies .

I will come back for cookies, but I will not come back for ice cream . If you're going to have unique flavors, then you better expect me to want to try more than two . 

I ended up getting the balsamic caramel . It's good for the first 5 bites, but after it gets all liquidy, the vinegar in the ice cream intesifies, and it just got too overwhelming for me . 

My friend had this jesus thing with this corn ice cream . The corn one was pretty good . The jesus thing tasted like 7up plus wine .

Definitely check it out for its uniqueness, but don't expect to try more than two without getting a faceload of bitchyness . -_-"
author: Jenny Y.

description:
The olive oil ice cream is definitely tasty (I spotted some orange peel in it, good call.)  Try the Thai Chili Lime with the Coconut. The Balsamic Carmel is so-so (Bi-Rite Salted Carmel puts it to shame.)  

I went there to try something new and will surely be back for more olive oil and to try more of the new flavors to come.
author: Tina D.

description:
Unique tastes, charming and helpful staff, all while getting to eat ice cream. hooray!

I went for the first time to buy a few pints for a dinner party. Despite the long line the staff was really helpful, and managed to keep the line moving alongside my voluminous order ;)

Although I like mitchells as well, there is something about this (texture and flavor) that is almost in a different category. It reminded me a little of otto (nyc) gelato but lighter? I really didnt think I'd find anything better than otto's olive oil gelato but the secret breakfast is a serious contender. very addictive. (i am also curious if people do eat their cornflakes with bourbon? maybe that is winter survival in the midwest? they do heart their bourbon)
author: Christine B.

description:
While the ice cream here is good, and inventive (if often failing- banana red hot??), I really don't like the ambiance and attitude there. I brought my nine year old nephew there today and a hipster douchebag dropped his baggy of coke in front of him. I *really* don't appreciate things like that around the kids in my life. 

As well, as I was paying, I noticed an ad for their new book, which will include recipes for such masterpieces as the "tranny smackdown". I was completely floored by this and asked what it was. "its a big mess of a sundae." oh. great. a big, tranny, mess of a sundae? humphry slocombe, you can suck it. Bi-rite it is for me.
author: Photo D.

description: The best Ice Cream the city has to offer! I love coming here in the evenings after my daily events have slowed down. The line is long but so well worth the wait. I always get Blue Bottle Coffee, Balsamic Caramel, or the Bouron flavored crunch one. So good! The people in line are usually good company too. Staff is very friendly and somehow very patient! All in all a great ice cream stop :^D
author: Ezequiel R.

description:
This place is great! I love Bi-Rite as well, but the flavors here are so unique. (Trust me, try Secret Breakfast) The owner is great and will answer any questions that you have... you can tell that he really takes a lot of pride in what he does. Extra points for using reusable metal instead of plastic tasting spoons.

It's a little out of the way, but well worth the trip.
author: Miranda C.

description:
As a huge fan of Blue Bottle coffee, you can imagine my excitement when I found out they used it as the base for their Vietnamese Coffee Ice Cream.  It was a rich, smooth, sweet caffeinated treat!  Paired with the Secret Breakfast, a boozy breakfast treat with a saucy edge, I had a quite spectacular first experience at Humphrey Slocombe.  The chocolate chip cookie was good and I liked the size, but it wasn't the best cc cookie I've ever had.

I dig that this is handcrafted artisan ice cream with a rotating menu mainly focused on flavors that will appeal to the majority, but I REALLY dig that they have off the wall flavors that push the envelope.  That they want to challenge people to be adventurous in trying unique flavors they wouldn't have thought to be appetizing is way cool.  Eating is an adventure!

I'll be going back to try the other flavors soon!
author: Janet L.

description:
* One star for the reference to a British sitcom
* One star for the humor (mmm Jesus Juice and Secret Breakfast)
* One star for the rotating selection of flavors- it's a devious trap to force me to keep coming back
* One star for the creative flavors (balsamic caramel, olive oil, salt n peppa, white miso peach...)
* One star for the owner who made another batch of foie gras ice cream sandwiches, just because my wife asked about it

In total- five stars for my new favorite ice cream shop.

Oh and a sixth star if they ever do make Fetal Kitten a real flavor
author: Wen H.

description:
Some bizarro flavors (thai chili & lime which tastes like thai green curry) and some that actually taste like dessert (malted dulce de leche). The secret breakfast flavor is pretty good. 

Bonus points for using metal spoons for sampling.
author: Marina N.

description: Oh yes.. I scream, you scream, we all scream for ice cream! U want to try some crazy flavors this is the spot!  Secret breakfast hits the spot hands down..  I sampled the one called Jesus juice it was too funny to pass up!  I can't wait to go back to try other flavors!!
author: Akiliano T.

description: sweet baby jesus!  i got two cavities on a brownie with cherries on top. The Secret Breakfast was delicious.  Also, the peanut butter curry was pretty spectacular.
author: Lyz L.

description:
Finally! After seeing this all over the Yelp welcome pages, I got a chance to figure out the buzz about Humphry Slocombe.

Cool place and it kinda sticks out like a sore thumb, it being smack in the middle of all these Carneceria's, Mexican Markets, etc. But inside is such a treat.

I kinda scared my pal Anne A. and her bf when I was listing the names of flavors on our way there. For instance, who really salivates over Balsamic Caramel, Government Cheese, Sour Cream and Foie Gras!? 

Well, we went in and were sold by their flavors. I opted for the Secret Breakfast (bourbon and corn flakes) and Blue Bottle Vietnamese Ice Coffee. The flavors are so intense. You can really taste the bourbon and the Coffee definitely has Blue Bottle written all over it.  

A single comes with 2 scoops for $3.25. Definitely worth it and we were quite satisfied.
author: Alyson C.

description:
5 Star ice cream.

2 Star place to be after dark, but it is worth the risk for this fantastic cream.  

I don't think it is fair to call it a Bi-Rite knock-off.  They simply are the only gourmet ice cream shoppes in town.  They are both wonderful.  The only downside to Slocombe's is the location.  The staff are nice and the wait was not as long as Bi-Rite.  Balsamic caramel, kumquat-poppyseed, and Secret Breakfast are DYN-O-mite! (Think J.J. Walker!)
author: Neuro G.

description: It's been a tradition since high school that after dinner my gf's & I would go out for ice cream.  This time around we happened to be in the Mission for brunch at Foriegn Cinema and decided to walk over to Humphry's for a mid day dessert.   They have a lot of unique flavors, but my favorite is the Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee.  The ice cream itself is a bit softer than most and started dripping down my cone after a few minutes of being scooped out of the feezer.  I felt like I couldn't enjoy it and had to hurry and bite the ice cream or it would melt all over my fingers.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Secret Breakfast: Bourbon, Cornflakes, and Cream. Great pick me up at noon. 

Vietnamese Coffee: OMG! Straight up Viet coffee! So good I wanted to lick the bowl! 

Honey Thyme: A milky farmers market honey taste with a hint of thyme at the end. 

Miso Pear: Like a sweet Miso soup with cream. It was weird 

Hibiscus Beet: Dude....it tasted like frozen Beets.....it was definitely beet icecream.

Olive Oil: A very fresh lemony cream. Just couldn't get over the fact that I was eating oil. 

Poppyseed Kumquat: Like a frozen version of a orange poppyseed muffin. The seeds kinda threw me off. 

Every flavor tasted EXACTLY how its ingredients said it would...it is definitely for a refined palate. Its good that they let you get 2 scoops for a small...small doses of each flavor is key since they are so intense. The girl helping us was super nice and let us try almost EVERYTHING. Prices were a little high but understandable since they do make it all fresh every morning and their products are very high quality. I did enjoy their "green" environment. I little retro/minimalist decor with ecofriendly cups, spoons, and napkins....even the taster spoons were metal and reusable. 

In the end, I was wowed by the originality but felt like going to Mitchell's to get a honkin scoop of White Pistachio. Maybe I just wasn't ready for ice cream at this level. I'm just a girl who likes ice cream the old fashion way...scooped out of a pint into my mouth!
author: Tammy H.

description:
The very first time I ever set foot in Humphry Slocombe, there were signs taped to the front door saying "Food Network is here today filming us because we're super bad-ass, so make sure your hair looks nice enough for national TV before you come in for your ice cream fix".

If you are reading this review, I am at Humphry Slocombe, agonizing over which incredible, whimsical out-of-this-world gourmet ice cream flavor to choose.  

Maybe today I'll have "Jesus Juice": Red wine and Coca Cola Classic.  So tasty, so bubbly- totally perfect for hot days!

I want to hug whomever it is who comes up with these flavors.  Next time I go in, maybe I'll ask to do just that.

I'm sure they get that a lot.
author: Marisa D.

description:
The flavors at Humphry Slocombe is definitely one of a kind.  I had the Vietnamese Coffee and i believe chocolate chip creme cheese or something.  Though i did have a taste of the secret breakfast and it was pretty good.  

Too bad i didnt get to try some of the other ones because i felt the server didnt want to help us in the first place.  Dont get me wrong, the flavors are unique and my friend was please with her choices too though as far as service went, it was out the door.  Maybe it was the day we went but talk about not wanting to even serve.

The ice cream itself is a bit on the pricey side because for the price of the two scoops/service given i could buy myself a half gallon of Dreyers and share it with a bunch.  

Understandable with the flavors, though going back again... not so much.  Maybe in a looong blue moon.
author: Mabel C.

description:
Secret Breakfast / Strawberry & Jalapeno.
Sample of their Bacon Peanut Brittle.

This place is giving Bi-Rite and the venerable Mitchell's a run.

I love their unique flavors.
author: Geordie E.

description: Truly bizarre flavors, incredibly delicious! Bring a spouse, a friend, a group so you can try each and every flavor.
author: Doug L.

description:
No chocolate ice cream? Really?! (Maybe not every day, but the day I went.)

Fancy flavors are all right for those who want that kind of thing, but you can't forget the basics.

Stars only because the stools are comfortable to hang out and chat.
author: Michael J.

description:
The flavors here are unlike any ice cream shop I've ever seen.  Each flavor is super unique, but not to the point where your face cringes when you read the name.  Throughout the line you hear people let out intrigued sighs while deciding. 

Secret Breakfast was far and above the best flavor!  Cornflakes make the world go round.  AND they team up with Blue Bottle for a delicious coffee ice cream!

The downside however was the wait in line.  Everyone wants to try every flavor.  Be prepared to wait.
author: C J.

description: I can see why Humphry Slocombe is so popoular IF (and only if) you are into that whole weird ice cream flavors thing.  I personally am not.  We tried this place once.  My wife got the Blue Bottle Coffee ice cream and she enjoyed it.  She only chose that b/c it was the closest thing to a normal flavor.  I decided to be more adventurous and I tried the Beer ice cream and.......it tasted like beer.  I like my alcohol in a bottle or a glass; not in my ice cream.
author: Joe L.

description:
Humphry Slocombe is an example of why I live in San Francisco and not Walnut Creek.  Their ice cream is innovative, pushing the boundry of what you think ice cream should taste like, yet is rich and delicious.

I've found the staff to be friendly and patient and let you taste every flavor if you want to. This is a good thing otherwise I might not want to try many of the flavors.  Olive Oil was quite a surprise to me.  Yes it tasted like really good olive oil but it also had citrus highlights, mostly lemon and orange, that really made it special.  I actually bought several pints ($7.50) in different flavors for a dinner party.  Olive Oil was the solid favorite, even over the more approachable Secret Breakfast (corn flakes and bourbon) and Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee. 

The portions ($3.25) seem small but my gf and I usually share one portion and are more than sated.

ps Check out the picture of JFK eating ice cream.
author: John S.

description:
Mad Scientist Dr. Humphry Slocombe working on his concoction in his evil ice cream laboratory.  I wish I could try them all but then I'd get the evil eye from the impatient customers lurking in line.

Secret Breakfast
Peanut Butter Thai Curry
Thai Green Chili Italian Ice

The flavors are so EVIL they're GOOD.
author: Po L.

description: what can I say, I love ice cream, i can eat it on hot days or cold days. This place is excellent, it has all these different  flavor that you would not find it in a regular ice cream parlor. Want to try something different in life go check out Humphry Slocombe.
author: Dave N.

description:
sometimes its hard to distinguish the different ice cream places in sf.  they all seem like they serve the same concept...i-will-take-random-ingredients-and-infuse-them-into-ice-cream.   bourbon?  rose? balsamic? prosciutto? foie gras?!?!  no ingredient is safe.  some work and some dont.  most times with enough sugar ANYTHING works.  so when these ice cream places start selling their version of a salty caramel ice cream, one begs to ask...in the attempt to be unique have they all assimilated into the same type of ice cream vendor?  

but that doesnt mean they arent all equally awesome.

balsamic caramel. yes.
author: Paran Y.

description:
I don't even like ice cream that much, but if Humphry Slocombe was in my neighborhood I would have to hire an army of Oompha-Loompas to roll me around. 
It's hard to stop yourself from overindulging when the flavors are so inspired and intriguing - every new bite is like turning the page of a scrumptious suspense novel. Try to go when the line isn't too long so you can sample the flavors freely, and bring cash - they don't take credit cards.
Don't be afraid to taste something that seems crazy - because chances are it's crazy good.
author: Max G.

description:
3.5 stars for the ice cream (i prefer creamier tastes), but 4 stars for the concept and the smile it brings me. however, I think most people will love this ice cream.  i'm a little too simple for HS (i only ate chocolate ice cream until i was 12 when i discovered mocha, and then i only ate that until i was 15 when i discovered coffee ice cream).  that said, i had a really great vahlrona chocolate, and i enjoy (but don't love) their blue bottle vietnamese coffee.

odd flavors i've tried: salt and pepper (just like you'd imagine) and honey thyme (couldn't taste the thyme...)

i do however love their 75 cent chocolate chip cookies.  the staff is really friendly too!
author: Priscilla T.

description:
As Rachael Ray would say... YUMM-O!!!

It was an unseasonably warm winter afternoon in San Francisco.  So what to do.  Ice Cream.  Good choice.  Although this place is sort of out the way for me, it is definitely worth the visit.  The Secret Breakfast was Bourbon and Corn Flakes.  You had me at bourbon.  And they had this Guinness Ginger which i also got.   Yes i am an alcoholic.  But with other flavors like the vietnamese blue bottle coffee and more, you cant really go wrong.

I love ice cream places because they let you sample the flavors.  But i always feel like a total tool if i sample too many.  

The thing about this place is that it somewhat looked like it didnt fit into the neighborhood where it was located.  Im glad it was there dont get me wrong, but taqueriuas and other businesses around it was a little weird.
author: Terence P.

description:
This place was okay, not as great as i was hoping. The ice cream portions may seems small, but they are SUPER rich, you don't want to eat too much. 

I got the Fois Gras and gingersnap ice cream sand which, special breakfast ice cream, and Dulce Du leche. 

All the ice creams seem to be a play on salty and sweet tastes. The special breakfast was my favorite, i think its a Bourbon flavored ice cream with crunchy cereal inside. 

I will go back next time i have a dinner party. i think it would be fun to pick up a few pints for a tasting after dinner. 

The flavors change daily, so that makes me want to go back too 

The best thing there was the free pieces of bacon peanut brittle. SOOO YUMMY. Again a play on salty and sweet, but yummmmmmm!

Dynomo doughnut is around the courner, so you can hit up two of the new trendyv treat places in one stop.
author: Samantha S.

description: Secret Breakfast nuf' said. Two scoops of that and i'm good.
author: Darnell L.

description: This place was worth the long line I had the balsamic Carmel and my friend had the hot mess!!!!!! Yummy!
author: Destiney F.

description: Tried HS again at the ferry building farmers market and the chocolate sea salt ice cream was a little melted and so overwhelmingly sweet that it burned my throat. Posing as gourmet ice cream for five dollars a half pint, it sure wasn't up to par.
author: Claire C.

description: I've only ventured out here a few times. Every time I was amazed by the ridiculous Flavors, every one of them delicious.  Can't wait for their cookbook to come out!
author: jessica b.

description:
Love this place, but perhaps not quite as much as Bi-Rite.  It's really fun to try the crazy flavours, but when I've ordered full scoops of them I've always ended up disappointed, and now just get the more traditional flavours.

Awesome awesomeness: Secret Breakfast, brown butter, malted chocolate.

Wouldn't recommend whole scoops:  thai chili lime; black sesame; Jesus Juice.
author: Sarah B.

description:
It's a cute diner style ice creamery. I tried their famous 
Secret Breakfast (Bourbon and Cereals) - what a delight! It'll give you the bourbon taste but in a dessert form. I don't drink bourbon but this is a good flavor. 
Vietnamese coffee - The initial taste was a pretty strong vietnamese coffee taste. The way i like it. Althought, the after taste left my tongue on the sweeter note. 
Cinnamon brittle - the worker's favorite. If you like cinnamon spice then definitely go for this, if not, it'll be a mediocre taste in your mouth. 

Price is similar to Bi-rite and Mitchell's. This is my 3rd choice.
author: Hebert J.

description: Who doesn't like beet flavored ice cream? I sure as hell don't, but the malted chocolate with toffee was blow-your-socks-off goodness. I think crack is illegal in this state, especially when slipped into a vat of ice cream that is sold to the public. These people should be ashamed. But please don't report them.
author: Lisa H.

description: I tried a whole bunch of flavors:  strawberry szechuan, chocolate passion fruit, orange clove, fennel something.  But I ended up getting the secret breakfast (bourbon and cornflakes)- delicious!!
author: Angela L.

description:
Well, I rather enjoyed the inventiveness of the Secret Breakfast Ice Cream; it was a nice combination of bourbon flavors (none-too-subtly applied) with just a little crunch from the corn flakes.  Enjoyable, and the tastes all complemented each other.

But I was really bothered by the mouthfeel of the ice cream, since it left a really heavy, greasy film on my mouth.  Usually, this means it was overchurned and the fats start to agglomerate.  Very disappointing, since it degraded what should have been an excellent ice cream to a merely good one.

I would have been tempted to write it off as a bad one-off, but my Vietnamese coffee ice cream was even greasier.

So while they get an A for inventiveness, they get a C- for the actual execution of making a good ice cream.  Sorry, but I expected better.
author: Rich K.

description:
3.5 stars, rounded down.

I was telling my friend this weekend that I think ice cream (well, gourmet ice cream, to be exact) is making a huge comeback.  It's like the new "it" thing.  Remember when all those froyo places were sprouting up all over the city?  I feel that way about ice cream now.  

So, Anh-Thu N.  and I had just finished a slice of pizza at Arinell's for dinner, and we thought it'd be great to follow it up with some ice cream.  We walked all the way from 16th/Valencia to Harrison/24th because we didn't anticipate how far it would be.  So much walking = SUCKS FOR US!  But it's cool, because On2 is quite possibly the funniest and greatest person in the world, so it was worth it.

Anyway, here's what I liked and didn't like about this particular adventure:

DIG: 
+ I got Secret Breakfast (tastes like BOURBON = WIN!!) and Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee, and both were quite delicious.  Especially the Secret Breakfast, as you may have guessed.  It totally surprised me how awesome and alcoholy it tasted.  It was unlike anything I've ever tasted.  I also tried peanut butter curry as well as a couple other flavors, and they were all. . .unique, to say the least.
+ They don't charge for a waffle cone, which is awesome!  But note: if you get a cone on top of your ice cream (like, in addition to putting it into a cup), they do charge. 
+ It's $3.25 for a "single," but the single includes two scoops, so that, compared to other ice cream places, is a decent price - even though, if you think about it, paying that much for two scoops of ice cream is a luxury that many can't afford, so it's kinda problematic that we're all so accepting of this price, right?
+ The people working here are very friendly.

NOT DIG:
- It's CASH ONLY.  If you hang out with me enough, you know that I HATE cash only places because I never carry around enough cash with me.  This time, I had to pay for my ice cream with 13 quarters because that's all I had on hand.  (Ask me later why I had 13 quarters on hand) The good thing, though, was that the sales person was super nice, so I'll give them that.  
- Okay, so the flavors taste pretty good, but the consistency was not good to me and WAY too soft and creamy.  About 30 seconds after I got my ice cream cone, the ice cream started melting all over my hands.  I had to eat very hastily, which was not enjoyable, and I grabbed many napkins to wipe the sticky sweet drops that were dripping all over me.  Maybe this is a certain special type of ice cream, but it really shouldn't melt this fast.  It wasn't even a particularly hot day!
- Too far from public transit!   Or maybe I'm just too lazy to walk.

So, overall, it tasted good, but consistency was terrible. I'm still also trying to get used to ice cream being this price.  If you get a tub of ice cream at the store, that entire tub is like $5 or so.  Compare that with this.

I do think, though, that ice cream in general makes people very happy, so as long as it keeps doing that, it's a very good thing.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Finally got to check out what all the hype was about at this ice cream place and now I understand why so many people love it.  I'm more of a gelato fan but I love crazy flavors of ice cream that tastes great too.  Once I got there I had to sample the Salt and Pepper to see what the buzz was all about.  Well, I have to say it was quite interesting but no thank you.  It definately had strong pepper flavors, salty, and had the sweet ice cream flavor to it.  Maybe if I continue having a few more bites the flavor will grow on me but thought I'd pass on it this time.  Other flavors I tried were:

Hibiscus Beet: Yummy..sweet and tangy.  Definately could taste the beet and definately refreshing.

Secret Breakfast: Love the bourbon in this! Nothing too exotic but great taste!  This one melts pretty easily too.

Red Hot Banana: Wow! Never thought cinnamon with bananas would go together so well.  Actually bought a tub of this with the Secret Breakfast and both of these flavors complement each other very well!

Maple Walnut: Hmm..nothing exciting but I love maple walnuts! =)

Too bad I didn't get to try their Vietnamese blue bottle coffee since it was all gone by the time I got there.  =(  In the end I ordered a single scoop with the maple walnut and hibiscus beet and brought home the tub of ice cream to enjoy at home.  Also bought their bacon peanut brittle and it sure is good! Pretty pricey though considering one bag costs $6.  

Only thing I didn't like about this place was how easily the ice cream melts.  Should bring a bucket of ice with you if you plan on buying a tub home that is more than 15 minutes away.
author: sidney c.

description:
This is bad.  Real bad.  All I need is another place with a mouth-watering selection of creatively diverse ice cream flavors.  To top it off, the ice cream is close to the best I've ever had anywhere.  Only a cute little ice cream parlor in Prague's Jewish quarter tops it.  I had the small serving (one up from child's size), which was not small at all.  Two large scoops for $3.25, one Glenlevit (yep, that's right) and the other balsamic something-or-other, which tasted like super-duper yummy cheese cake to me.

Very friendly service, too.  The scooper immediately asked if we'd like to taste something as we walked through the door and then offered up additional tastings without us even asking. 

All I can say is I'm glad HS isn't within walking distance to our place.  I'd have to run 10 miles a day to keep the pounds off. :)
author: Kevin M.

description:
Um... if you're into weird ice cream then this is the place to go! I like to think that I'm very open minded and will always try anything once but some of these flavors were pretty weird.

For example they have ice cream like salt & pepper, peanut butter curry... uh salt & pepper or curry in my ice cream??? Maybe I'll pass on that. :p I tried the balsamic caramel and it was still kinda odd tasting... 

I ended up getting the Tahitian vanilla which was pretty yummy and safe.. haha.. What I had was really good so they get 4 stars for that! :) Bi-rite is still by far my favorite ice cream ever!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Came on a Tuesday night around 7:00 PM after dinner at Flour + Water which is 4 blocks down the street.  No line.

I had a scoop of cinnamon brittle on a sugar cone.  The ice cream has an ethereal, "just right" creaminess to it when it begins to melt in the cone and isn't overly sweet.  

I had written that Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous was the best ice cream I've had in SF...now I'm not so sure.
author: Steven Y.

description:
Jesus Christ, that's some of the most intense ice cream I've ever tasted. Get the Dulce de leche or the Secret Breakfast -- you will be in heaven. 

The chocolate may be for ladies only -- ie, it tastes like dark chocolate, which the girls dig more than the guys. Why is that? 

Want to try the poppyseed one next.
author: Dan S.

description:
And I thought Polly Ann's Durian was exotic...! [but still love them =) ]

Oh no, Humphry has got them beat! 

From the many reviews on Yelp, I read that they are really nice with their samples so... I tried some even though I held up the line outside... sorry guys! I couldn't help myself! The Thai Chili Lime - whoa. Strange to taste my thai eggroll dipping sauce in my sorbet! Jesus Juice - my reaction, "hmm." Peanut butter curry - also, "hmm." I couldn't really see myself having a whole scoop of either of those flavors.. until I tried the Secret Breakfast - my reaction went from "hmmm" to "mmmmm". Wish it had more corn flakes though. And of course I had to have 2 scoops... what did I choose to go with my breakfast ice cream? The Vietnamese coffee of course! The flavors compliment each other very nicely. 

We enjoyed our desserts outside at their tables because it was hot inside... but we enjoyed them guiltily though because the people in the long line were giving us horrible looks. =T
author: Christine C.

description: Good ice cream!  Got the secret breakfast (bourbon and cereal) which was tasty, in combination with the vietnamese coffee.  Open on Labor Day!  Lines relatively short compared to Bi-Rite!
author: Ken L.

description:
Yup... it is now official.  Humphry Slocumbe is my new favorite source of ice cream.

Finally made it in today after having it on my "to do" list for months, and I am both kicking myself for taking so long to roll through and looking forward to coming back again soon.  Had their "single" size, which actually has two scoops, on a cone with Secret Breakfast and Guiness Gingerbread.  Went the booze-related route this time around.  Both were amazingly creamy and hit the right flavor notes.  Picked up some Bacon Peanut Brittle also, but have not busted it out yet.

Do you guys offer classes or internships?  I would provide you with some free slave labor in exchange for the Secret Knowledge of the Ice Cream Gods.   Bow down to Humphry Slocumbe!
author: Chris C.

description: Thick, creamy and VERY tasty ice cream with flavors that will knock your socks off. Secret breakfast flavor was by far the most ordered as we stood in line so we got one and was very, very glad. Also got the plain but incredibly tasty Tahitian vanilla which makes you rethink the standard for ice cream and set your bar much, much higher after eating Humphry's!
author: P G.

description:
Fun ice cream. Savory ice cream. Salt and pepper flavor was too salty for me. However for you with hypotension, this is the flavor for you.

Secret breakfast is where its at (bourbon, vanilla and corn flakes). Should kids be eating this stuff. i swear there alcohol content is still in the ice cream. Never too young to get that secret breakfast on.
author: Judy L.

description:
Humphry Slocombe needs another 5 star review like I need a 2nd anus, but they deserve it.  I really like the ice cream.  I like the fact that they change things up every once in a while.  I like the fact that it's pretty close to my house.  It is incredibly expensive but I feel worth every penny.

Whenever I have guests over from out of town or even for a dinner party I always grab a few pints of HS ice cream it makes the dessert portion of the meal super easy and I always hear the same thing, "That is the best ice cream I have ever had."

Quick tip:  When it is 47 degrees outside around 6 o'clock there usually isn't a line.  Any other time there usually is.  Parking is also a bitch.
author: Anthony Y.

description: The innovative flavors are what makes Humphry Slocombe stand apart from your standard ice cream parlor. Secret breakfast ice cream is just pure genius. I also had the curry ice cream and while I wasn't a fan of the after taste... I do salute them for trying. The only knock would be that it can be really rich and my wife and I can't finish an entire carton without feeling sick... which may be a good thing.
author: Steve K.

description:
Finally got around to checking this place out after realizing it's only 1 mile away from my regular lunch spot. So I took advantage of a break from the rainy days and trekked over. Location-wise it's totally random in the Mission off of Harrison and a little dark so you might pass it by without a glance unless you were looking for it.
